we close out November, here is a recap of the past month for Overclock Labs and Akash Network.\\n\\nAkash Network successfully completed the upgrade to Mainnet 4\\n\\nOn November 17th, Akash Network completed the upgrade to Mainnet 4. This upgrade is yet another significant milestone in Akash's ambition to become the leading peer-to-peer marketplace for cloud compute. This upgrade also paves the way for a GPU marketplace on Akash.\\n\\nThe upgrade to Mainnet 4 is the culmination of months of hard work from our engineering team. Now that Mainnet 4 is live, the upgrade\u2019s four major features are now available to everyone on the network:\\n\\n1.  IP Leases\\n2.  Provider Services Split\\n3.  IBC3\\n4.  Interchain Accounts\\n\\nWe\u2019re thrilled to finally ship Mainnet 4 and provide everyone on Akash access to these powerful features.\\n\\n## Akash Weekly continued through November\\n\\nOur Akash Weekly series continued into its fifth month. Catch up with our November events with the recaps below:\\n\\n[Akash Weekly: Mantra](https://akashnetwork.substack.com/p/akash-weekly-mantra)\\n\\n[Akash Weekly: Lex and Arel Avellino](https://akashnetwork.substack.com/p/akash-weekly-lex-and-arel-avellino)\\n\\n[Akash Weekly: Geeks Pics](https://akashnetwork.substack.com/p/akash-weekly-geeks-pics)\\n\\n## Greg Osuri spoke at Dcentral Miami\\n\\nLast week, [Greg Osuri](https://twitter.com/gregosuri) (Founder and CEO of Akash Network) [spoke on the mainstage at Dcentral Miami](https://twitter.com/akashnet_/status/1597282620056154113?s=20&amp;t=fNgL56soQr0KRPVOgkO_gwhttps://twitter.com/akashnet_/status/1597282620056154113?s=20&amp;t=fNgL56soQr0KRPVOgkO_gw) alongside Joshua Noble, CEO &amp; Co-Founder of [Filebase](https://filebase.com/), on the topic of&nbsp;decentralized cloud and storage in web3.\\n\\n[Check out the full recording of the panel here](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=uGlflVLgYjI).\\n\\n## The Overclock Console open beta is almost here\\n\\nWe are getting very close to launching the open beta of Overclock Labs\u2019 flagship deployment tool \u2014 Overclock Console.\\n\\nConsole will make it easy to create and manage deployments on Akash with a convenient, web-based tool.\\n\\nFollow [@akashnet\\\\_](https://twitter.com/akashnet_) and [@gregosuri](https://twitter.com/gregosuri) on Twitter, and [subscribe to our newsletter](https://akashnetwork.substack.com/) here to keep up to date with the latest from [Overclock Labs](https://ovrclk.com) and [Akash Network](https://akash.network).\\n&quot;],&quot;collection&quot;:[0,&quot;Blog&quot;],&quot;data&quot;:[0,{&quot;title&quot;:[0,&quot;Overclock Labs: November 2022 Horn&quot;]]],&quot;bannerImage&quot;:[0,{&quot;src&quot;:[0,&quot;/_astro/banner-image.tMhh9rNP.png&quot;],&quot;width&quot;:[0,1500],&quot;height&quot;:[0,844],&quot;format&quot;:[0,&quot;png&quot;],&quot;fsPath&quot;:[0,&quot;/home/runner/work/website/website/src/content/Blog/overclock-labs-november-2022-recap/banner-image.png&quot;]}]}],&quot;render&quot;:[0,null]}],[0,{&quot;id&quot;:[0,&quot;introducing-ip-leases-on-akash-network/index.md&quot;],&quot;slug&quot;:[0,&quot;introducing-ip-leases-on-akash-network&quot;],&quot;body&quot;:[0,&quot;\\n[Overclock Labs](https://twitter.com/ovrclk_), the parent company of Akash Network which is developing tools, protocols, and infrastructure that support the evolution and adoption of Web3, is excited to announce the general availability of \u201cIP Leases\u201d on Akash Network.\\n\\nIP Leases allow Tenants of Akash Network to request reserved, publicly routable IP addresses for the services they deploy, and allow Providers on the network to monetize their acquired and available IP space. IP Leases are supported in version [**0.18.0** of the Akash CLI](https://akash.network/docs/mainnet4-upgrade-docs/akash-v0.18.0-cli-release-notes) and are also available for use via the [Cloudmos deploy tool](https://cloudmos.io/). The on-chain code changes to support IP Leases were already released as part of the recent Akash Network [Mainnet 4 upgrade](https://www.mintscan.io/akash/proposals/27), so this feature is ready to use right now.\\n\\n## Why We Built It\\n\\nAs Akash Network has gained popularity among Web3 developers, we have been listening closely to feedback and prioritizing things that make it easier for them to manage and scale applications and workloads on a decentralized cloud. While Web3 applications have many differences from \u201ctraditional\u201d Web2 applications, they also have a lot in common when it comes to their underlying infrastructure needs. So it was no surprise that one of the most highly requested features from our community and customers was one that we take for granted when deploying services on existing cloud providers (like AWS, Azure, and GCP) \u2014 the ability to have a public, reserved Internet routable IP address assigned to a service running on public cloud infrastructure. IP Leases are also a key piece of our broader product strategy as we move into the \u201cparity\u201d (with respect to Web2) phase, as [highlighted by Greg in a tweet](https://twitter.com/gregosuri/status/1587858044108488705) recently:\\n\\n![](https://www.datocms-assets.com/45776/1669215218-screen-shot-2022-11-23-at-9-53-27-am.png)\\n\\nWhile Akash users have had ways to expose endpoints of their services, using HTTP endpoints connected to ports provided by Kubernetes \u2014 they had no control over the ports. Further, some services (like a VPN, for example) must use standard ports in the 0-1024 range, which isn\u2019t possible unless you have a dedicated IP address. The ability to lease a dedicated IP address removes these limitations and broadens the types of applications that can be deployed on Akash Network.\\n\\n## For Tenants (Developers &amp; Other Users)\\n\\nUsers deploying workloads on Akash now have the option to request a public IPv4 address as part of their deployments. Users needing dedicated IP addresses for their applications and services specify that in their bid request and submit it to the Akash marketplace. Providers that have dedicated IP address pools configured to respond to the request, and the user is able to pick one of the providers to deploy their service on. Once deployed, the user gets an IP address in addition to an HTTP endpoint, either of which can be used to access the service publicly:\\n\\n![](https://www.datocms-assets.com/45776/1669215272-screen-shot-2022-11-23-at-9-54-17-am.png)\\n\\n_(\u201cUser 03\u201d here wants a dedicated IP address, and \u201cProvider 02\u201d has this capability available)_\\n\\nIP addresses are a new _kind_ of _endpoint_ and can be requested when declaring each service in a deployment (in the SDL). Each declaration returns one single IPv4 address that may be bound to one or more ports in the standard (0-65535) range.\\n\\n![](https://www.datocms-assets.com/45776/1669215359-screen-shot-2022-11-23-at-9-55-49-am.png)\\n\\n- Users only need to lease one public IPv4 address for all the services included in their deployment as long as they use a unique port for each of the services.\\n- The leased IP address is only reserved for the time that the lease is open with the specific provider unless explicitly migrated to a new lease.\\n- Leased IP addresses are retained when deployments are updated.\\n\\nHere is an example of an Akash SDL file and the resulting lease, showing the IP address allocated to the service for which the IP address was requested\\n\\n![](https://www.datocms-assets.com/45776/1669215407-screen-shot-2022-11-23-at-9-56-36-am.png)\\n\\nTo see a full detailed explanation of how to use IP Leases, check out our [documentation](https://akash.network/docs/features/ip-leases).\\n\\n## For Providers\\n\\nCurrent and new providers on Akash Network can use the new IP Lease functionality starting today, offering their users more value and increasing revenue by monetizing their unused IP space. Providers interested in making IP Leases available to their users have a set of steps to perform:\\n\\n1.  Decide on the pool of IP addresses you wish to make available. If you are running in a colocation facility, you would lease this pool from your hosting provider.\\n2.  Associate those IP addresses with a node on your Kubernetes cluster. This is the pool of IP addresses that will be available for lease.\\n3.  Install and configure a [Metal LB](https://metallb.universe.tf/) instance to work with your Kubernetes cluster. This is a load balancer that will take care of assigning and unassigning IP addresses from your pool to services as they come and go.\\n4.  Define a Kubernetes Service that makes the monitoring endpoints (APIs) of the Metal LB instance accessible to Akash services.\\n5.  Add Kubernetes Custom Resource Definitions (CRDs) declaring the IP addresses available.\\n\\n## Digging Deeper\\n\\nWe would love it if you used IP Leases in your next deployment. To get you going smoothly, we have updated our [documentation](https://akash.network/docs/features/ip-leases) to cover all technical details. If you are curious about the high-level details of how we implement this feature, stay tuned for an upcoming technical blog post outlining how we use [MetalLB](https://metallb.universe.tf/) and [Kubernetes Custom Resources](https://kubernetes.io/docs/concepts/extend-kubernetes/api-extension/custom-resources/) under the hood to make IP Leases possible.\\n&quot;],&quot;collection&quot;:[0,&quot;Blog&quot;],&quot;data&quot;:[0,{&quot;title&quot;:[0,&quot;Introducing IP Leases on Akash Network&quot;],&quot;description&quot;:[0,&quot;Overclock Labs, the parent company of Akash Network which is developing tools, protocols, and infrastructure that support the evolution and adoption of Web3, is excited to announce the general availability of \u201cIP Leases\u201d on Akash Network.&quot;],&quot;pubDate&quot;:[3,&quot;2022-11-23T00:00:00.000Z&quot;],&quot;draft&quot;:[0,false],&quot;categories&quot;:[1,[[0,&quot;Product&quot;]]],&quot;tags&quot;:[1,[[0,&quot;Product&quot;]]],&quot;contributors&quot;:[1,[[0,&quot;Anil Murty&quot;]]],&quot;bannerImage&quot;:[0,{&quot;src&quot;:[0,&quot;/_astro/banner-image.DSdyMEzT.png&quot;],&quot;width&quot;:[0,1500],&quot;height&quot;:[0,844],&quot;format&quot;:[0,&quot;png&quot;],&quot;fsPath&quot;:[0,&quot;/home/runner/work/website/website/src/content/Blog/introducing-ip-leases-on-akash-network/banner-image.png&quot;]}]}],&quot;render&quot;:[0,null]}],[0,{&quot;id&quot;:[0,&quot;week-in-review-with-greg-osuri-nov-14th-nov-18th-2022/index.md&quot;],&quot;slug&quot;:[0,&quot;week-in-review-with-greg-osuri-nov-14th-nov-18th-2022&quot;],&quot;body&quot;:[0,&quot;\\nThis weekly recap series covers the ecosystem updates you\u2019re used to hearing in our Akash Weekly Twitter Spaces in around 500 words. This is the fastest way to get a weekly rundown directly from the Founder &amp; CEO of Overclock Labs \u2014&nbsp;[Greg Osuri](https://twitter.com/gregosuri).\\n\\n_Looking for an expanded recap?_\\n\\n*Sign up for*&nbsp;[_Akash Network\u2019s Substack_](http://akashnetwork.substack.com/)&nbsp;*for expanded updates, features from guests, and a weekly Q&amp;A delivered straight to your inbox.*\\n\\n*Or, read it on the web at*&nbsp;[_akashnetwork.substack.com_](http://akashnetwork.substack.com/)_._\\n\\n---\\n\\n### Akash\u2019s Mainnet 4 is LIVE\\n\\nMainnet 4 is now live on Akash Network after a successful upgrade yesterday. For more information on Mainnet 4 and resources for upgrading \u2014&nbsp;[check out this post](https://akash.network/blog/mainnet-4-upgrade-timing-resources-and-more)&nbsp;on Akash\u2019s blog.\\n\\nUpdated CLI release notes:&nbsp;[https://akash.network/docs/mainnet4-upgrade-docs/akash-v0.18.0-cli-release-notes](https://akash.network/docs/mainnet4-upgrade-docs/akash-v0.18.0-cli-release-notes)\\n\\nCLI detailed steps:&nbsp;[https://akash.network/docs/guides/cli/detailed-steps](https://akash.network/docs/guides/cli/detailed-steps)\\n\\n### Overclock Console is coming soon\\n\\nNow that Mainnet 4 is live on Akash Overclock Console will be next to launch. We\u2019re currently testing the product internally and will provide more information over the next few weeks when we have a date for the public beta launch. Follow Akash\u2019s official social channels, and head over to&nbsp;[Akash\u2019s Discord](https://discord.com/invite/akash)&nbsp;to keep up with the latest news on Overclock Console.\\n\\n### Cloudmos Alerts\\n\\nICYMI:&nbsp;[Cloudmos](https://cloudmos.io/)&nbsp;launched its Alerts product, which lets users keep an eye on the balances of their escrow accounts. This makes it easy to get notifications to top up wallet balances so that deployments don\u2019t run out of escrow funds \u2014&nbsp;which is one of the main reasons we see closed deployments on Akash.\\n\\nCloudmos alerts will also keep users up to date on current governance proposals.\\n\\n### Token Economics 2.0\\n\\n_Not financial advice._\\n\\nAs the AKT utility token secures Akash Network, we are exploring potential options to implement a value accrual mechanism. The token price directly correlates to the network's security, so Akash should incentivize token holders. The most likely mechanism that Akash accomplishes this will be through a burn mechanism tied to stable/fiat settlements. We will keep the community updated as we get closer to releasing a governance proposal.\\n\\n---\\n\\n[Read the rest of this week's Akash Weekly here.](https://open.substack.com/pub/akashnetwork/p/akash-weekly-mantra?r=1ov19w&amp;utm_campaign=post&amp;utm_medium=web)\\n&quot;],&quot;collection&quot;:[0,&quot;Blog&quot;],&quot;data&quot;:[0,{&quot;title&quot;:[0,&quot;Week in Review With Greg Osuri: Nov 14th - Nov 18th, 2022&quot;],&quot;description&quot;:[0,&quot;This weekly recap series covers the ecosystem updates you\u2019re used to hearing in our Akash Weekly Twitter Spaces in around 500 words. This is the fastest way to get a weekly rundown directly from the Founder &amp; CEO of Overclock Labs \u2014&nbsp;Greg Osuri.&quot;],&quot;pubDate&quot;:[3,&quot;2022-11-18T00:00:00.000Z&quot;],&quot;draft&quot;:[0,false],&quot;categories&quot;:[1,[[0,&quot;News&quot;]]],&quot;tags&quot;:[1,[[0,&quot;News&quot;]]],&quot;contributors&quot;:[1,[[0,&quot;Zach Horn&quot;]]],&quot;bannerImage&quot;:[0,{&quot;src&quot;:[0,&quot;/_astro/banner-image.CoErdqDQ.png&quot;],&quot;width&quot;:[0,1920],&quot;height&quot;:[0,1080],&quot;format&quot;:[0,&quot;png&quot;],&quot;fsPath&quot;:[0,&quot;/home/runner/work/website/website/src/content/Blog/week-in-review-with-greg-osuri-nov-14th-nov-18th-2022/banner-image.png&quot;]}]}],&quot;render&quot;:[0,null]}],[0,{&quot;id&quot;:[0,&quot;mainnet-4-upgrade-timing-resources-and-more/index.md&quot;],&quot;slug&quot;:[0,&quot;mainnet-4-upgrade-timing-resources-and-more&quot;],&quot;body&quot;:[0,&quot;\\n_Note: this post will be updated with news, updates, and links to resources throughout the day._\\n\\n---\\n\\nToday is the day! Akash's Mainnet 4 upgrade is on track to reach the specified block height within a few minutes of 6:15 PM GMT / 1:15 PM EST / 10:15 AM PST.\\n\\n[Keep an eye on the estimated upgrade timing here](https://www.mintscan.io/akash/blocks/8526250\\\\).\\n\\n## Mainnet 4 features\\n\\n1.  **IP Leases**  \\n    IP Leases will allow tenants on Akash to request a publicly routable IP address for the services they deploy. Today, you get an HTTP endpoint connected to your service, and Kubernetes assigns the actual port. With IP Leases, a tenant on Akash can request a dedicated IPV4 address, allowing users to assign a specific port instead of a randomly assigned port.\\n2.  **Provider Services Split**  \\n    This feature will separate parts of the behind-the-scenes development process for Overclock Labs and make it easier to iterate quickly and efficiently.\\n3.  **Cosmos IBC3**  \\n    IBC3 allows one chain to send transactions to another chain. This gives users access to the latest IBC Cosmos features and opens Akash Network to the rest of the Cosmos ecosystem.\\n4.  **Interchain Accounts (ICA)**  \\n    By enabling Interchain Accounts, we will provide access to interchain composability and significantly improve the user experience on Akash Network.\\n\\n## Mainnet 4 upgrade resources\\n\\nAkash Network's documentation: [https://akash.network/docs/mainnet4-upgrade-docs](https://akash.network/docs/mainnet4-upgrade-docs)\\n\\nAkash v0.18.0 CLI Release Notes: [https://akash.network/docs/mainnet4-upgrade-docs/akash-v0.18.0-cli-release-notes](https://akash.network/docs/mainnet4-upgrade-docs/akash-v0.18.0-cli-release-notes)\\n\\nAkash Mainnet 4 Node Upgrade Guide: [https://akash.network/docs/mainnet4-upgrade-docs/akash-mainnet4-node-upgrade-guide](https://akash.network/docs/mainnet4-upgrade-docs/akash-mainnet4-node-upgrade-guide)\\n\\nAkash Provider Upgrade: [https://akash.network/docs/mainnet4-upgrade-docs/provider-upgrade](https://akash.network/docs/mainnet4-upgrade-docs/provider-upgrade)\\n\\nAkash Provider Enablement for **IP Leases**: [https://akash.network/docs/other-resources/experimental/mainnet4-upgrade-docs/ip-leases-provider-enablement-optional-step](https://akash.network/docs/other-resources/experimental/mainnet4-upgrade-docs/ip-leases-provider-enablement-optional-step)\\n\\n## Follow the Mainnet 4 upgrade in real-time\\n\\nHead over to [Akash Network's Discord](https://discord.com/invite/akash) and jump into the conversation on the **#general-chat** channel to connect with the Akash Community.\\n\\nToday, we'll be focused on real-time updates and discussions around the Mainnet 4 upgrade. The Overclock Labs team and the [Akash Insiders and Vanguards](https://akash.network/community) will also be there to answer any questions and assist with technical support.\\n\\nPlease help us spread the word with the share buttons below!\\n&quot;],&quot;collection&quot;:[0,&quot;Blog&quot;],&quot;data&quot;:[0,{&quot;title&quot;:[0,&quot;Mainnet 4: Upgrade Timing, Resources, and More&quot;],&quot;description&quot;:[0,&quot;this post will be updated with news, updates, and links to resources throughout the day.&quot;],&quot;pubDate&quot;:[3,&quot;2022-11-17T00:00:00.000Z&quot;],&quot;draft&quot;:[0,false],&quot;categories&quot;:[1,[[0,&quot;Updates&quot;]]],&quot;tags&quot;:[1,[[0,&quot;Updates&quot;]]],&quot;contributors&quot;:[1,[[0,&quot;Zach Horn&quot;]]],&quot;bannerImage&quot;:[0,{&quot;src&quot;:[0,&quot;/_astro/banner-image.B2TG3HzQ.png&quot;],&quot;width&quot;:[0,1920],&quot;height&quot;:[0,1080],&quot;format&quot;:[0,&quot;png&quot;],&quot;fsPath&quot;:[0,&quot;/home/runner/work/website/website/src/content/Blog/mainnet-4-upgrade-timing-resources-and-more/banner-image.png&quot;]}]}],&quot;render&quot;:[0,null]}],[0,{&quot;id&quot;:[0,&quot;week-in-review-with-greg-osuri-nov-7th-nov-11th-2022/index.md&quot;],&quot;slug&quot;:[0,&quot;week-in-review-with-greg-osuri-nov-7th-nov-11th-2022&quot;],&quot;body&quot;:[0,&quot;\\n## Akash\u2019s Mainnet 4: The governance vote is pending\\n\\n[The governance proposal is currently out for voting](https://www.mintscan.io/akash/blocks/8526250)&nbsp;and is on track to pass with a 99%+ \u201cyes\u201d vote. If you are an AKT staker,&nbsp;[please vote](https://wallet.keplr.app/chains/akash/proposals/27)&nbsp;to ensure the Mainnet 4 upgrade is completed as scheduled.\\n\\nThe flagship feature of Mainnet 4, a dedicated IP address marketplace, will not only bring Akash closer to parity with large public cloud providers but will also enable new applications and use cases, such as Solana nodes&nbsp;\u2014&nbsp;which have received significant interest over the last few weeks due to recent shocks to the Solana network.\\n\\n[As Hetzner continues to remove web3 from its platform](https://twitter.com/zacharyhorn/status/1587844722168664064?s=20&amp;t=9mX24LvwGFlgUjn91bhGuA), more projects and protocols realize that now is the time to move to the decentralized cloud. Akash is leading that transition.\\n\\n![](https://www.datocms-assets.com/45776/1668206206-screen-shot-2022-11-11-at-5-36-33-pm.png)\\n\\nWe appreciate the recent interest and engagement from the Solana community. We look forward to working together to get Solana nodes up and running on Akash once Mainnet 4 is live.\\n\\nWe also look forward to new features from projects like&nbsp;[MASQ](https://masq.ai/)&nbsp;that Akash\u2019s dedicated IP marketplace will enable.\\n\\n## Alani Kuye: State of the Akash Ecosystem\\n\\nIn case you missed it: Check out&nbsp;[Alani\u2019s](https://twitter.com/AlaniKuye)&nbsp;ecosystem update to get an overview of all the projects building on Akash.\\n\\n## Spheron\u2019s web3 masterclass\\n\\n**Tomorrow 11/12/22:**&nbsp;[Spheron](https://spheron.network/)&nbsp;is hosting a web3 masterclass in Delhi, and Alani will speak on behalf of the Overclock Labs team.\\n\\nCheck out the event details and find the link to sign up in the tweet below.\\n\\n![](https://www.datocms-assets.com/45776/1668206447-screen-shot-2022-11-11-at-5-40-37-pm.png)\\n\\n## Blog Series: Building the Open Cloud\\n\\nPart 4 of our&nbsp;*Building the Open Cloud*&nbsp;series by&nbsp;[Anil Murty](https://twitter.com/_Anil_Murty_)&nbsp;is coming soon. In case you\u2019ve missed any of the previous entries, check out the past installments below:\\n\\n[Building the Open Cloud, Part 1: The State of Web3 Infrastructure](https://akash.network/blog/building-the-open-cloud-part-one)\\n\\n[Building the Open Cloud, Part 2: Re-Imagining the Cloud With Akash](https://akash.network/blog/building-the-open-cloud-part-2-re-imagining-the-cloud-with-akash)\\n\\n[Building the Open Cloud, Part 3: The Growing Akash Ecosystem](https://akash.network/blog/building-the-open-cloud-part-3-the-growing-akash-ecosystem)\\n\\n---\\n\\nRead the full summary of this week with [Akash Weekly: Lex &amp; Arel Avellino of Passage.](https://open.substack.com/pub/akashnetwork/p/akash-weekly-lex-and-arel-avellino?r=1ov19w&amp;utm_campaign=post&amp;utm_medium=web)\\n&quot;],&quot;collection&quot;:[0,&quot;Blog&quot;],&quot;data&quot;:[0,{&quot;title&quot;:[0,&quot;Week in Review With Greg Osuri: Nov 7th - Nov 11th, 2022&quot;],&quot;description&quot;:[0,&quot;The governance proposal is currently out for voting and is on track to pass with a 99%+ \u201cyes\u201d vote.&quot;],&quot;pubDate&quot;:[3,&quot;2022-11-11T00:00:00.000Z&quot;],&quot;draft&quot;:[0,false],&quot;categories&quot;:[1,[[0,&quot;Updates&quot;]]],&quot;tags&quot;:[1,[[0,&quot;Updates&quot;]]],&quot;contributors&quot;:[1,[[0,&quot;Zach Horn&quot;]]],&quot;bannerImage&quot;:[0,{&quot;src&quot;:[0,&quot;/_astro/banner-image.DcIBOs-c.png&quot;],&quot;width&quot;:[0,1920],&quot;height&quot;:[0,1080],&quot;format&quot;:[0,&quot;png&quot;],&quot;fsPath&quot;:[0,&quot;/home/runner/work/website/website/src/content/Blog/week-in-review-with-greg-osuri-nov-7th-nov-11th-2022/banner-image.png&quot;]}]}],&quot;render&quot;:[0,null]}],[0,{&quot;id&quot;:[0,&quot;week-in-review-with-greg-osuri-oct-31st-nov-4-2022/index.md&quot;],&quot;slug&quot;:[0,&quot;week-in-review-with-greg-osuri-oct-31st-nov-4-2022&quot;],&quot;body&quot;:[0,&quot;Welcome to our new blog update series. This brief weekly rundown will cover the ecosystem updates you\u2019re used to hearing in our Akash Weekly Twitter Spaces in around 500 words. This is the fastest way to get a weekly rundown directly from the Founder &amp; CEO of Overclock Labs \u2014 [Greg Osuri](https://twitter.com/gregosuri).\\n\\n_Looking for an expanded recap?_\\n\\n_Sign up for_ [_Akash Network\u2019s Substack_](http://akashnetwork.substack.com) _for expanded updates, features from guests, and a weekly Q&amp;A delivered straight to your inbox._\\n\\n_Or, read it on the web at_ [_akashnetwork.substack.com_](http://akashnetwork.substack.com)_._\\n\\n* * *\\n\\nSF Tech Week\\n------------\\n\\n[SF Tech Week](https://sf-techweek.com/) is back and currently ongoing from November 1st-6th. Greg Osuri spoke on a panel at Draper University on Thursday alongside Adit Gupta ([Mirana Ventures](https://mirana.xyz/)), Jazear Brooks ([Sifchain](https://www.sifchain.finance/)), Jayendra Jog ([Sei Network](https://www.seinetwork.io/)), and Neel Somani ([Eclipse](https://eclipse.builders/)).\\n\\nSpheron\u2019s web3 Masterclass\\n--------------------------\\n\\nAkash Network ecosystem partner [Spheron](https://spheron.network/) is hosting a web3 masterclass with our own Alani Kuye, Technical Program Manager at Overclock Labs.\\n\\nThere are two sessions:\\n\\n1.  [November 5th in Nigeria](https://lu.ma/zaw0r0ug)\\n    \\n2.  [November 12th in Delhi](https://lu.ma/spherondel)\\n    \\n\\nLuna\u2019s Akash Terraform Provider\\n-------------------------------\\n\\nAkash Insider Luna\u2019s Terraform Provider is gaining traction. Greg highlights that the Provider has received more than 800 downloads. We want to spotlight the work of the incredible Akash community&nbsp;\u2014&nbsp;who do so much work to build the Akash ecosystem.\\n\\n[Follow Luna on Twitter](https://twitter.com/luna_4_go), and check out the [Terraform Provider here](https://registry.terraform.io/providers/cloud-j-luna/akash/latest/docs).&nbsp;&nbsp;\\n\\nMainnet 4, MASQ, and Urbit\\n--------------------------\\n\\nMainnet 4 enables IP Leases: an open IP marketplace on Akash. IP Leases will open up functionality for projects like Urbit&nbsp;\u2014&nbsp;whose users can host nodes on Akash via IP Leases.\\n\\nWe believe Urbit should run on the decentralized cloud. Stay tuned for the launch announcement of Mainnet 4.\\n\\nCheck out [MASQ here](https://masq.ai/).\\n\\nCheck out [Urbit here](https://urbit.org/).\\n\\nCheck your AKT delegations\\n--------------------------\\n\\nDouble-check your AKT delegations to make sure the validator is active. You will not earn staking rewards if you have AKT delegated to a jailed/unbonded validator. See the tweet below for more information:\\n\\n[Redelegation tweet from Smart Stake](https://twitter.com/SmartStake/status/1585845903499399168?s=20&amp;t=EiUB_Md7NK0t5TXoCXhsUA)\\n\\nVote for new holiday Akash merch\\n--------------------------------\\n\\n[Cast your vote for this season\u2019s holiday merch](https://akt.fyi/tvote). Voting ends on Monday, so make sure to choose before then. The winner will be featured in the Akash merch store.\\n\\nGenerative AI &amp; Akash\u2019s upcoming GPU marketplace\\n------------------------------------------------\\n\\nAkash Network's vision includes an open marketplace for GPU compute. The current distribution of GPU computing is inefficient, and we believe Akash\u2019s upcoming GPU marketplace will address the exponentially increasing demand.\\n\\nAkash is working to position itself as the best-in-class marketplace for GPU compute.\\n\\n_Read more: Open AI,_ [_\u201cAI and Compute\u201d_](https://openai.com/blog/ai-and-compute/)\\n\\n* * *\\n\\nGo Deeper\\n---------\\n\\nSubscribe to [Akash Network\u2019s Substack](https://akashnetwork.substack.com) for the complete recap of each week, delivered straight to your inbox.\\n\\n[Check out the recording of the most recent Akash Weekly on YouTube.](https://youtu.be/XQVGt-fdKPY)&quot;],&quot;collection&quot;:[0,&quot;Blog&quot;],&quot;data&quot;:[0,{&quot;title&quot;:[0,&quot;Week in Review With Greg Osuri: Oct 31st - Nov 4th, 2022&quot;],&quot;description&quot;:[0,&quot;Welcome to our new blog update series. This brief weekly rundown will cover the ecosystem updates you\u2019re used to hearing in our Akash Weekly Twitter Spaces in around 500 words.&quot;],&quot;pubDate&quot;:[3,&quot;2022-11-04T00:00:00.000Z&quot;],&quot;draft&quot;:[0,false],&quot;categories&quot;:[1,[[0,&quot;News&quot;]]],&quot;tags&quot;:[1,[[0,&quot;News&quot;]]],&quot;contributors&quot;:[1,[[0,&quot;Zach Horn&quot;]]],&quot;bannerImage&quot;:[0,{&quot;src&quot;:[0,&quot;/_astro/banner-image.CHrS1Cqv.png&quot;],&quot;width&quot;:[0,1920],&quot;height&quot;:[0,1080],&quot;format&quot;:[0,&quot;png&quot;],&quot;fsPath&quot;:[0,&quot;/home/runner/work/website/website/src/content/Blog/week-in-review-with-greg-osuri-oct-31st-nov-4-2022/banner-image.png&quot;]}]}],&quot;render&quot;:[0,null]}],[0,{&quot;id&quot;:[0,&quot;building-the-open-cloud-part-3-the-growing-akash-ecosystem/index.md&quot;],&quot;slug&quot;:[0,&quot;building-the-open-cloud-part-3-the-growing-akash-ecosystem&quot;],&quot;body&quot;:[0,&quot;\\n_By_ [**_Anil Murty_**](https://www.linkedin.com/in/anilmurty/)_, Head of Product at Overclock Labs, and_ [**_Alani Kuye_**](https://www.linkedin.com/in/alanikuye/)_, Technical Program Manager at Overclock Labs_\\n\\n---\\n\\nThis is a continuation of the four-part blog post series we started in October. In the [first post](https://akash.network/blog/building-the-open-cloud-part-one), we discussed the current state of web3 infrastructure and a few of its challenges. We followed that up with a [second post](https://akash.network/blog/building-the-open-cloud-part-2-re-imagining-the-cloud-with-akash) outlining how Akash\u2019s decentralized open cloud solves these challenges. In the process, Akash is creating a platform for a thriving ecosystem of developer-focused products, tools, and services. This post will highlight Akash Network\u2019s growing and thriving ecosystem.\\n\\n## What is a Software Ecosystem?\\n\\nIf you are unfamiliar with the term \u201cecosystem\u201d in the context of software services, here is a quick primer. It originates from the definition used in biology: a physical geographic area where organisms (plants and animals) as well as the weather and landscape, work together to form a \u201cbubble of life.\u201d Much the same, a software ecosystem is a virtual abstraction of space where various digital players work together to create a world of services for users in a common market.\\n\\nArguably, the best example of a software ecosystem today is the one created by Apple, which includes their software and hardware, as well as products and services built by third parties like iOS app developers and hardware accessory manufacturers. Apple\u2019s ecosystem stands in contrast to the Android ecosystem, which is more open. A third party can develop a phone which runs the Android operating system, even though Google also makes its own phones, like the Pixel. Given the open nature of Akash\u2019s software platform \u2014 Akash Network is comparable to the Android ecosystem.\\n\\n## The Akash Network Ecosystem\\n\\nAkash\u2019s ecosystem evolves organically as people discover the power of the platform and find new use cases that even we (the core team at Overclock Labs) have not thought about. We\u2019ve seen projects fall into two categories:\\n\\n1.  Ecosystem projects that build products, tools, and services that make it easier for others to use Akash Network.\\n2.  Projects that run some part of their product or service (website, nodes, and core infrastructure) on Akash.\\n\\n![](https://www.datocms-assets.com/45776/1667500750-61-1.png)\\n\\nLet\u2019s take a look at a few of these projects in more detail.\\n\\n### Praetor App\\n\\nBesides all the benefits to the user that we outlined in the [previous post](https://akash.network/blog/building-the-open-cloud-part-2-re-imagining-the-cloud-with-akash), Akash Network also enables any data center operator today (or in theory, any person with compute and storage capacity) to become a provider on Akash Network. This is one way for existing data center operators to monetize their unused capacity. When Akash launched, the Overclock Labs team built a [CLI-based process](https://akash.network/docs/providers/build-a-cloud-provider) for setting up an Akash provider on a group of servers. While this was great for those with a technical background, it prevented less technical people from being able to \u201cjoin the open cloud revolution\u201d by becoming a provider. This is where Praetor App saw an opportunity and decided to build a solution.\\n\\nPraetor App is web-based product that significantly reduces the technical complexity of setting up a new provider on Akash. [Praetor is now called Akash provider console](https://provider-console.akash.network/). Akash provider console also includes a [provider profitability calculator](https://akash.network/pricing/provider-calculator/) and [usage pricing calculator](https://akash.network/pricing/usage-calculator/) as well as a provider status dashboard that shows the location, count, capacity, and uptime of the (~50 and growing) providers on Akash Network.\\n\\n![](https://www.datocms-assets.com/45776/1667500819-screen-shot-2022-11-03-at-2-39-58-pm.png)\\n\\n### Cloudmos\\n\\nSimilar to the way that Praetor enables the growth of providers, [Cloudmos](https://cloudmos.io/) enables less technical users to deploy on Akash by providing an easy-to-use graphical user interface (GUI), as an alternative to Overclock\u2019s CLI method.\\n\\nCloudmos includes a downloadable (win/exe and mac/dmg images available [here](https://github.com/maxmaxlabs/cloudmos-deploy/releases)) application, as well as a beta web-based UI for deploying an application. They have also built a very cool pricing comparison tool [https://cloudmos.io/price-compare](https://cloudmos.io/price-compare) that compares the price of compute resources on Akash with those on the three major public cloud providers (AWS, Azure, and GCP).\\n\\n![](https://www.datocms-assets.com/45776/1667500882-screen-shot-2022-11-03-at-2-41-12-pm.png)\\n\\n### Terraform Provider for Akash (by Luna, an Akash Insider)\\n\\n[Terraform](https://www.terraform.io/) is one the most popular infrastructure automation tools used by DevOps teams that operate public cloud infrastructure. The way Terraform automates infrastructure provisioning is through the use of \u201cproviders\u201d. Put simply, a \u201cTerraform Provider\u201d is like a \u201cplugin\u201d that lets you work with public APIs provided by cloud service providers, SaaS providers, and other services used by a development team. Given the popularity of Terraform among developers and operations engineers, we were excited to see someone from the Akash community take it upon themselves to build a Terraform provider for Akash. The provider is located at the official Hashicorp Terraform registry docs [here](https://registry.terraform.io/providers/cloud-j-luna/akash/latest/docs). Detailed instructions on how to use it can be found in the Akash Network docs [here](https://akash.network/docs/other-resources/experimental/akash-deployments-via-terraform).\\n\\n![](https://www.datocms-assets.com/45776/1667504595-screen-shot-2022-11-03-at-3-43-06-pm.png)\\n\\n### Moultrie Audits\\n\\nA key part of Akash Network\u2019s value comes from the diversity of its providers. While this is an advantage, it also creates a challenge because we have to ensure that the providers are who they claim to be and the services they claim to provide (amount of compute resources, reliability, security) are accurately represented. While the Akash core team (Overclock Labs) has a process for auditing providers before they are allowed onto the network, a critical part of scaling Akash Network is to have additional auditors. This is where [Moultrie Audits](https://www.moultrieaudits.com/) fulfills an important role. They perform checks on all Akash providers when they join, as well as on a regular basis, to ensure the providers are accurately representing themselves on the Akash Network marketplace.\\n\\n### Vixello\\n\\nVixello are builders and recently joined as validators within the Akash ecosystem. Vixello is focused on building tools that accelerate the adoption of web3, by bridging the gap for those coming from web2.\\n\\nThe Vixello team is increasingly active within the Akash ecosystem. They are testing tools encapsulating general business functions such as: invoice management, fiat to crypto payments, and decentralized business processes&nbsp;\u2014 in a manner that enables web2 and web3 to coexist.\\n\\n## Join the Akash Ecosystem\\n\\nAkash Network greatly values its [ecosystem](https://akash.network/ecosystem/showcase/latest/) of third-party products and services and is always excited to hear about new ones.\\n\\nIf you are interested in becoming a provider on Akash Network, building services for Akash, or integrating with Akash \u2014 reach out to us via [akash.network](https://akash.network), or any of our ecosystem partners.\\n\\nIf you prefer listening to reading, check out [this talk](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=jGqZzNWQrNs&amp;t=1373s) from Messari Mainnet 2022, or [this video](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=8cicuhuf94s) that discusses the state of the Akash ecosystem as of October 2022.\\n\\nMeanwhile, if you are eager to get started, head over to Akash Network\u2019s [documentation](https://akash.network/docs/).\\n&quot;],&quot;collection&quot;:[0,&quot;Blog&quot;],&quot;data&quot;:[0,{&quot;title&quot;:[0,&quot;Building the Open Cloud, Part 3: The Growing Akash Ecosystem&quot;],&quot;description&quot;:[0,&quot;By Anil Murty, Head of Product at Overclock Labs, and Alani Kuye, Technical Program Manager at Overclock Labs&quot;],&quot;pubDate&quot;:[3,&quot;2022-11-03T00:00:00.000Z&quot;],&quot;draft&quot;:[0,false],&quot;categories&quot;:[1,[[0,&quot;Insights&quot;]]],&quot;tags&quot;:[1,[[0,&quot;Insights&quot;]]],&quot;contributors&quot;:[1,[[0,&quot;Anil Murty&quot;]]],&quot;bannerImage&quot;:[0,{&quot;src&quot;:[0,&quot;/_astro/banner-image.Bha2IXAc.png&quot;],&quot;width&quot;:[0,1500],&quot;height&quot;:[0,844],&quot;format&quot;:[0,&quot;png&quot;],&quot;fsPath&quot;:[0,&quot;/home/runner/work/website/website/src/content/Blog/building-the-open-cloud-part-3-the-growing-akash-ecosystem/banner-image.png&quot;]}]}],&quot;render&quot;:[0,null]}],[0,{&quot;id&quot;:[0,&quot;overclock-labs-october-recap/index.md&quot;],&quot;slug&quot;:[0,&quot;overclock-labs-october-recap&quot;],&quot;body&quot;:[0,&quot;\\nAs we close out the month of October, here is a look back at our accomplishments over the past month.\\n\\n**Summary:**\\n\\n- Akash's Mainnet 4 and Overclock Console made significant progress over the past month and are expected to launch soon.\\n- _Akash Weekly with Greg Osuri_ reached its four-month milestone.\\n- We began publishing our four-part _Building the Open Cloud_ blog series in early October.\\n- Overclock Labs attended Devcon and Schelling Point.\\n\\n## Mainnet 4 is coming soon\\n\\nAkash is aiming to launch the network\u2019s Mainnet 4 upgrade in November. Over the past month, we made significant progress \u2014 working out any remaining bugs and getting closer to finalizing the code. At this point, we are moving into a testing phase to make sure everything runs as expected.\\n\\nMainnet 4 will bring four new features to Akash Network:\\n\\n1.  **IP Leases**&nbsp;\u2014&nbsp;a first-of-its-kind open marketplace for IP addresses.\\n2.  **Provider Services Split** \u2014&nbsp;an efficiency upgrade for Akash development.\\n3.  **IBC3** \u2014 an upgrade that will enable the latest Cosmos features on Akash.\\n4.  **Interchain Accounts** \u2014 another feature of Cosmos that enables cross-chain composability.\\n\\n## Overclock Console is coming soon\\n\\nOverclock Console, our flagship deployment tool built by Overclock Labs, is nearing completion. Once Overclock Console is launched, users on Akash Network will have access to an easy, intuitive solution for creating and managing deployments. This will add yet another deployment option for Akash users, alongside [several other deployment solutions built by the incredible Akash community](https://akash.network/ecosystem/showcase/latest/).\\n\\n## Akash Weekly reached its four-month milestone\\n\\n_Akash Weekly with Greg Osuri_ reached its fourth consecutive month of live Twitter Spaces events. Each week, Greg Osuri goes live on [@akashnet\\\\_](https://twitter.com/akashnet_) , Wednesdays at 8 am PT, to give updates on the ecosystem and the latest developments from Akash and Overclock Labs. Each Akash Weekly update also features guests from around the web3 space and beyond.\\n\\nHere are the summaries of our Akash Weekly events from October:\\n\\n[Akash Weekly: Axelar Network](https://open.substack.com/pub/akashnetwork/p/akash-weekly-axelar-network?r=1ov19w&amp;utm_campaign=post&amp;utm_medium=web) - October 28th\\n\\n[Akash Weekly: Secret Network and Moultrie Audits](https://open.substack.com/pub/akashnetwork/p/akash-weekly-secret-network-and-moultrie?r=1ov19w&amp;utm_campaign=post&amp;utm_medium=web) - October 21st\\n\\n[Akash Weekly: The Web3 Regulatory Landscape](https://open.substack.com/pub/akashnetwork/p/akash-weekly-the-web3-regulatory?r=1ov19w&amp;utm_campaign=post&amp;utm_medium=web) - October 14th\\n\\n[Akash Weekly: Alani Kuye](https://open.substack.com/pub/akashnetwork/p/akash-weekly-alani-kuye-overclock?r=1ov19w&amp;utm_campaign=post&amp;utm_medium=web) - October 7th\\n\\n## Blog series: Building the Open Cloud\\n\\nIn early October, we began publishing a series of blog posts on the current state of the cloud, the obstacles facing web3, and the ways that Akash addresses these obstacles. The series is based on the presentation (by the same name) from Messari Mainnet by Overclock Labs\u2019 Head of Product, [Anil Murty](https://twitter.com/_Anil_Murty_).\\n\\nParts 1 &amp; 2 have already been published, and we will continue the series into November, leading up to the launch of Overclock Console. Part 3 will be published later this week. This series will have four parts, with a potential fifth installment in the works.\\n\\nStay tuned for the public launch announcement of Overclock Console by heading over to [akash.network/connect](https://akash.network/connect) to follow us across our social channels.\\n\\n[Building the Open Cloud, Part 1: The State of Web3 Infrastructure](https://akash.network/blog/building-the-open-cloud-part-one)\\n\\n[Building the Open Cloud, Part 2: Re-Imagining the Cloud With Akash](https://akash.network/blog/building-the-open-cloud-part-2-re-imagining-the-cloud-with-akash)\\n\\n## Overclock Labs attended Devcon and Schelling Point\\n\\nThis past month, [Adam Wozney](https://twitter.com/AdamDeanWozney), Head of Community at Overclock Labs, attended Devcon \u201822 and Schelling Point in Bogot\u00e1, Columbia. We always look forward to opportunities to engage with the broader web3 community, and connect with other projects and companies, to hear how we can support the growth and adoption of web3.\\n\\n**_Devcon:_**\\n\\n![](https://www.datocms-assets.com/45776/1667333186-screen-shot-2022-11-01-at-4-06-12-pm.png)\\n\\n**_Schelling Point:_**\\n\\n![](https://www.datocms-assets.com/45776/1667332995-pxl_20221010_155131730-1.jpg)\\n\\n### Stay up to date with Overclock Labs and Akash Network\\n\\nFor real-time updates and ecosystem news, follow [@akashnet\\\\_](https://twitter.com/akashnet_) and [@gregosuri](https://twitter.com/gregosuri). Explore all the ways to [connect with the Akash Community here](https://akash.network/connect).\\n\\nTo get started on Akash, [head over to the docs for more information on the network](https://akash.network/docs/).\\n&quot;],&quot;collection&quot;:[0,&quot;Blog&quot;],&quot;data&quot;:[0,{&quot;title&quot;:[0,&quot;Overclock Labs: October 2022 Recap&quot;],&quot;description&quot;:[0,&quot;As we close out the month of October, here is a look back at our accomplishments over the past month.&quot;],&quot;pubDate&quot;:[3,&quot;2022-11-01T00:00:00.000Z&quot;],&quot;draft&quot;:[0,false],&quot;categories&quot;:[1,[[0,&quot;News&quot;]]],&quot;tags&quot;:[1,[[0,&quot;News&quot;]]],&quot;contributors&quot;:[1,[[0,&quot;Zach Horn&quot;]]],&quot;bannerImage&quot;:[0,{&quot;src&quot;:[0,&quot;/_astro/banner-image.DryOrhW7.png&quot;],&quot;width&quot;:[0,1500],&quot;height&quot;:[0,844],&quot;format&quot;:[0,&quot;png&quot;],&quot;fsPath&quot;:[0,&quot;/home/runner/work/website/website/src/content/Blog/overclock-labs-october-recap/banner-image.png&quot;]}]}],&quot;render&quot;:[0,null]}],[0,{&quot;id&quot;:[0,&quot;akash-weekly-secret-network-and-moultrie-audits/index.md&quot;],&quot;slug&quot;:[0,&quot;akash-weekly-secret-network-and-moultrie-audits&quot;],&quot;body&quot;:[0,&quot;Welcome to another Akash Weekly from the team at Overclock Labs.\\n\\nOur guests this week:\\n- Tor Bair, Founder, Secret Foundation\\n- Anthony Rosa, Project Lead at Moultrie Audits\\n\\n## Mainnet 4 update\\nWe are three weeks away from the launch of Mainnet 4. As of this week, the code is frozen, and we are working on simulating the upgrade so that we are up and running smoothly on launch.\\n\\nStay tuned to Akash\u2019s social media channels and this newsletter for more updates on Mainnet 4 as we get closer to the final upgrade date.\\n\\nOnce Akash upgrades to Mainnet 4, we will have created the first open marketplace for IP addresses. This will bring even more flexibility and utility to tenants on Akash network, and providers will have yet another way to monetize their unutilized resources.\\n\\nBeyond the Mainnet 4 upgrade, we have our eyes set on bringing an open marketplace for GPUs to Akash. Stay tuned for more.\\n\\n## Greg Osuri will be speaking at DCENTRAL Miami\\nDCENTRAL Miami is coming up next month, from November 28-29th. Greg Osuri will be speaking, and we\u2019ll give an update on the exact date and time when it\u2019s available. If you haven\u2019t gotten your tickets yet \u2014 use code FREN30 at decentralcon.com for 30% off.\\n\\n## Moultrie Audits places first at the DoD\u2019s BRAVO Hackathon\\nOur first guest this week was Anthony Rosa, Project Lead at Moultrie Audits \u2014 which is the auditing arm of Moultrie Cryptography. Moultrie Audits focuses on Akash Network, auditing providers to give users more information and help open the network to organizations and industries with stringent security requirements.\\n\\nMoultrie Audits build smart contracts for funds, crypto companies, grants, and for the government. They currently have active projects in all of these categories.\\n\\n### The history of the BRAVO Hackathon\\nThe BRAVO Hackathon, created by Stuart Wagner (chief digital transformation officer for the Department of the Air Force), takes its name from Project B \u2014 a \u201c1921 series of joint Army-Navy target exercises conducted on surplus ships in response to Army Brig. Gen. Billy Mitchell\u2019s claim that bombers sink battleships.\u201d\\n\\n> \u201cStyled off Project B, BRAVO hackathons are sponsored by senior DoD leaders to provide technical and cultural innovation environments that enable government and industry to test and validate bold ideas on real DoD data. These events align under Air Force Chief of Staff Gen. CQ. Brown, Jr.\u2019s Sept. 17, 2021, memo requiring senior leaders to enable Airmen to experiment and innovate.\u201d\\n- \\&quot;Introducing BRAVO: A hackathon series for Air Force, industry\\&quot;\\n\\n### BRAVO 1\\nAccording to Wagner, the BRAVO 1 hackathon was likely the largest and most complex data and software innovation event in the U.S. Department of Defense\u2019s history.\\n\\nThere were a total of 16 judges, including dozens of guests from the DoD, and the final presentation was made to a three-star general.\\n\\n### Why Moultrie chose Secret Network and Akash Network for their project\\nAlthough many of the specifics of the application are unable to be disclosed for security reasons, Rosa was able to give a high-level overview of the intent of the application.\\n\\nMoultrie sought to build an application that allowed for the secure transfer of information within the government, preventing the accumulation of troves of inaccessible data \u2014 which has to be analyzed at some point in the future.\\n\\nBoth networks were chosen for being best-in-class for their respective solutions. Secret Network was selected as the best solution for keeping data private on-chain.\\n\\nAkash Network was chosen as the best solution for allowing the government to access information within its system without requiring more information than a wallet address.\\n\\n### Placing First in BRAVO 1\\nMoultrie\u2019s application won first place in the category \u201cMost Tactically Relevant for Maintenance Data.\u201d\\n\\nIt placed second for \u201cMost Tactically Relevant for Cyber Operations.\u201d\\n\\nThere is full intent to move this project to the NSA to continue development and make it operational. Moultrie is currently in negotiations around the process of transferring the application for further development.\\n\\n### Decentralization needs privacy. Privacy needs decentralization.\\nTor Bair is the Founder of Secret Foundation. Secret Network is the only layer-1 blockchain with privacy-preserving smart contracts live on mainnet, which expands on the idea of transactional privacy.\\n\\nSecret Network exists to support both privacy and decentralization, as both are core to the mission of the network. Bair notes that one is not possible without the other.\\n\\n> \u201cAs much of the stack needs to be as decentralized as possible.\u201d\\n\u2014 Tor Bair\\n\\n### Building at every level of the stack\\nSecret Network\u2019s expertise is around building privacy solutions. Learn more about Secret\u2019s roadmap here.\\n\\nOnce combined with solutions like Akash Network, we will start to see the full decentralized stack needed to build a fully private, decentralized web3.\\n\\n> \u201cWe\u2019re proud to be a part of the small coalition of blockchain builders that are building things that are truly globally useful and not just built for speculation.\u201d\\n\u2014 Tor Bair\\n\\n## Q&amp;A\\nQ: Are there plans for the U.S. government to run providers on Akash?\\nA: Rosa notes that although he can only speak for very specific parts of the DoD, he does believe that it is the intent of specific departments within the DoD to run providers at some point in the future.\\n\\nQ: What are the biggest challenges in building web3 solutions for governments?\\nA: (Rosa) The best thing that companies in the web3 space can do is have someone within the company familiar with the government processes needed to get approval. It also helps to have people within the government familiar with the project or company.\\n\\nQ: (For Greg Osuri) What are your thoughts on Aptos?\\nA: Greg notes that there is a lot of hype around the network and that there may be overlap in the future around running Aptos nodes on Akash. We\u2019ll keep an eye on Aptos going forward.\\n\\n[Listen to the full recording of this week\u2019s Akash Weekly Twitter Spaces](https://youtu.be/dJKFr9wAYwA_).\\n\\n&quot;],&quot;collection&quot;:[0,&quot;Blog&quot;],&quot;data&quot;:[0,{&quot;title&quot;:[0,&quot;Akash Weekly: Secret Network and Moultrie Audits&quot;],&quot;description&quot;:[0,&quot;Welcome to another Akash Weekly from the team at Overclock Labs.&quot;],&quot;pubDate&quot;:[3,&quot;2022-10-21T00:00:00.000Z&quot;],&quot;draft&quot;:[0,false],&quot;categories&quot;:[1,[[0,&quot;Updates&quot;]]],&quot;tags&quot;:[1,[[0,&quot;Updates&quot;]]],&quot;contributors&quot;:[1,[[0,&quot;Zach Horn&quot;]]],&quot;bannerImage&quot;:[0,{&quot;src&quot;:[0,&quot;/_astro/banner-image.CWMgf8Ck.jpeg&quot;],&quot;width&quot;:[0,1920],&quot;height&quot;:[0,1080],&quot;format&quot;:[0,&quot;jpg&quot;],&quot;orientation&quot;:[0,1],&quot;fsPath&quot;:[0,&quot;/home/runner/work/website/website/src/content/Blog/akash-weekly-secret-network-and-moultrie-audits/banner-image.jpeg&quot;]}]}],&quot;render&quot;:[0,null]}],[0,{&quot;id&quot;:[0,&quot;building-the-open-cloud-part-2-re-imagining-the-cloud-with-akash/index.md&quot;],&quot;slug&quot;:[0,&quot;building-the-open-cloud-part-2-re-imagining-the-cloud-with-akash&quot;],&quot;body&quot;:[0,&quot;\\nThis is the second entry in our&nbsp;[four-part blog series](https://akash.network/blog/building-the-open-cloud-part-one). In this post, we build on our summary from Part 1, which focused on the key challenges in web3 infrastructure today. If you prefer to watch a presentation of this, you can find the recording [here](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=jGqZzNWQrNs).\\n\\n![](https://www.datocms-assets.com/45776/1665775012-screen-shot-2022-10-14-at-3-16-49-pm.png)\\n\\nBefore we dig in and talk about how Akash Network addresses these challenges, let's start with a refresher on how public clouds work today.\\n\\n## The Status Quo for Public Cloud Infrastructure\\n\\nAny public cloud today \u2014 AWS, Azure, Google Cloud, Alibaba, Tencent, Oracle, Digital Ocean, or any of the smaller players in the space \u2014 is structured around the idea of a single large entity (like Amazon, in the case of AWS or Microsoft in case of Azure) owning all the infrastructure. All users (thousands, if not millions) connect to that infrastructure through the interfaces that the cloud provider exposes.\\n\\n![](https://www.datocms-assets.com/45776/1665775180-screen-shot-2022-10-14-at-3-19-38-pm.png)\\n\\nThe model above revolutionized the software industry. It enabled people to get started without the need to spin up and manage their own infrastructure. It lowered significant capital expenditure (CapEx) for small startups. The programmability of clouds also enabled things like elastic autoscaling and supported DevOps principles. The programmability of cloud infrastructure allows development teams to move faster by managing the infrastructure their applications run on without being dependent on operations teams. Their autoscaling nature also allows companies to keep costs low by fluidly scaling in response to demand.\\n\\nWhile the things above have contributed immensely to the pace of innovation across many industries, they have some drawbacks.\\n\\n- The cloud provider sets the price and you take it or leave it.\\n- The cloud provider decides where their infrastructure will be located. So, if they choose not to have a presence in your country or region, users of your application are forced to connect to a less-than-optimal location from a latency perspective.\\n- If one cloud service provider offers a better service for one thing (say, compute) and another offers a better service for something else (say, storage), it is hard if not impossible to use \u201cthe best of breed\u201d for your application.\\n- The current model does nothing to address the underutilized infrastructure in the 7M+ datacenters around the world.\\n- The user experience for deploying on a given cloud provider is, for the most part, decided by that cloud provider.\\n\\n## A Decentralized Vision\\n\\nImagine a decentralized version of a public cloud that addresses these concerns. It would look something like this:\\n\\n![](https://www.datocms-assets.com/45776/1665775229-screen-shot-2022-10-14-at-3-20-16-pm.png)\\n\\nInstead of a single, large entity owning and controlling all the infrastructure, you would have several smaller entities owning portions of the infrastructure. Users could choose which provider they want to run on \u2014 and if they choose, they could run on more than one provider.\\n\\nWhile this solves some of the problems we outlined earlier, it introduces new ones. The users in this scenario are now faced with the daunting task of figuring out contractual agreements with multiple providers, each of which could be for different lengths of time. Assuming they figure that out, they would then have to figure out how to deploy to each of these providers, which may have different interfaces and feature sets. All this would take an army of legal, operations, and engineering talent \u2014 making the task unrealistic for a small company.\\n\\nThis is where Overclock Labs saw an opportunity and decided to build a solution.\\n\\n## The Akash Network Approach\\n\\nOverclock Labs pioneered a two-sided marketplace for cloud compute where \u201cTenants\u201d lease compute resources from \u201cProviders\u201d to deploy their applications and services. Akash Network\u2019s marketplace for cloud compute is a software abstraction layer that provides a consistent experience for users regardless of which provider they choose for their deployment.\\n\\n![](https://www.datocms-assets.com/45776/1665775298-screen-shot-2022-10-14-at-3-21-36-pm.png)\\n\\nThere are clear benefits to this approach:\\n\\n1.  Each provider sets its own price.\\n2.  The tenant has greater freedom of choice for their deployment. If they are willing to sacrifice reliability for lower costs, the decision to make that tradeoff is left to the user.\\n3.  If a provider chooses to drop a tenant\u2019s application or service for arbitrary reasons, the tenant has greater optionality to avoid serious downtime.\\n4.  This model allows the underutilized capacity in the 7M+ datacenters to be brought to market, making it more environmentally sustainable.\\n5.  As the network grows, the user\u2019s options for geographic locations scale non-linearly, so their application achieves lower (read: better) latency and response times.\\n\\nIn addition, Akash is an open-source, community-driven network that is powered by a blockchain. This means that it adheres to a governance model that has been proven by many other open source projects and other blockchains.\\n\\n![](https://www.datocms-assets.com/45776/1665775331-screen-shot-2022-10-14-at-3-22-09-pm.png)\\n\\n## Akash Network \u201cUnder the Hood\u201d\\n\\nIf the above has you excited to learn more, here is a quick overview of how Akash Network works.\\n\\nAkash is built on Open Source Software (OSS). The two major technologies that Akash uses are [Docker](https://www.docker.com/) and [Kubernetes](https://kubernetes.io/). Docker is the world's most widely used container technology and Kubernetes is the world\u2019s most popular container orchestrator.\\n\\n![](https://www.datocms-assets.com/45776/1665775391-screen-shot-2022-10-14-at-3-23-08-pm.png)\\n\\nProviders on Akash Network run [Kubernetes clusters](https://kubernetes.io/docs/concepts/architecture/) and Tenants (users of Akash Network) deploy their applications as Docker containers onto these Kubernetes clusters.\\n\\nA typical deployment workflow on Akash looks like the block diagram below:\\n\\n![](https://www.datocms-assets.com/45776/1665775430-screen-shot-2022-10-14-at-3-23-44-pm.png)\\n\\nTenants begin by containerizing their application into a docker image so it is portable (can be easily moved between providers). Then, they include a reference to that image in an SDL file. SDL stands for \u201cStack Definition Language\u201d and, as the name suggests, is a way for users to specify which infrastructure stack they would like for their application. The SDL file includes compute needs, locations, and pricing.\\n\\nOnce as SDL file is prepared, it is submitted to the Akash marketplace as a _\u201crequest for bids\u201d_. Akash software takes the information contained in the SDL file and broadcasts it to all the providers on the Akash marketplace (more than 50 at the time of writing). The providers inspect the request and decide if it is something that they can satisfy. If a provider decides that it can satisfy the request \u2014 it responds with a bid.\\n\\nThe tenant ends up with a set of bids from the providers that respond. The number of bids can range from a few to a few dozen, depending on the request. Then, the tenant decides which bid suits their needs. They may decide to choose a lower-cost provider, even if that provider lacks features. Once the user selects a provider and instructs Akash to deploy, the application container is scheduled to run on the provider and, within a few minutes, the application is deployed and running.\\n\\nTo summarize, it is a simple, four-step process:\\n\\n1.  Create SDL File \ud83d\udcc1\\n2.  Request a bid \ud83d\udcb2\\n3.  Choose a provider \ud83e\udd1d\\n4.  Deploy! \ud83d\ude80\\n\\nIn case you are wondering what an SDL file looks like, here is an example of one that is used to spin up a Tetris game on the web. Let\u2019s break it down and understand the various parts.\\n\\n![](https://www.datocms-assets.com/45776/1665775495-screen-shot-2022-10-14-at-3-24-52-pm.png)\\n\\nThe SDL file answers five questions to help Akash decide which provider to choose and how to deploy the app:\\n\\n1.  **Which app(s) or service(s) would you like to run?** In this case, it is a version of the game, Tetris, as indicated by the \\\\`image:bsodr/tetris\\\\` reference \u2014 which points to a publicly available docker image located [here](https://hub.docker.com/r/bsord/tetris/tags).\\n2.  **What infrastructure resources do you need to run the deployment?** This is where you indicate the required amount of CPU, memory, and storage.\\n3.  **Where (location or provider specifics) would you like to run it?** This tells Akash if you have a preference for certain audited attributes (more on auditors in our forthcoming ecosystem post) or locations for the provider.\\n4.  **How much are you willing to pay the provider to host the deployment?** This is where you specify the maximum amount you\u2019re willing to spend, which will then be used in a \u201creverse auction\u201d on the marketplace.\\n5.  **How many replicas do you want to run?** This is pretty self-explanatory.\\n\\nAnd, that\u2019s it! Isn\u2019t that way easier than you thought it would be? There are many people hard at work at Overclock Labs as well as in small teams of independent developers within the Akash community who are building deployment and provider set-up solutions. This will make the process of interacting with Akash Network much easier. Eventually, someone with little to no technical expertise can operate on Akash. Stay tuned for subsequent posts that will dig into some of these products.\\n\\nMeanwhile, if you are eager to get started, head over to Akash Network\u2019s [documentation](https://akash.network/docs/).\\n&quot;],&quot;collection&quot;:[0,&quot;Blog&quot;],&quot;data&quot;:[0,{&quot;title&quot;:[0,&quot;Building the Open Cloud, Part 2: Re-Imagining the Cloud With Akash&quot;],&quot;description&quot;:[0,&quot;This is the second entry in our&nbsp;four-part blog series. In this post, we build on our summary from Part 1, which focused on the key challenges in web3 infrastructure today.&quot;],&quot;pubDate&quot;:[3,&quot;2022-10-14T00:00:00.000Z&quot;],&quot;draft&quot;:[0,false],&quot;categories&quot;:[1,[[0,&quot;Insights&quot;]]],&quot;tags&quot;:[1,[[0,&quot;Insights&quot;],[0,&quot;Product&quot;],[0,&quot;Developers&quot;]]],&quot;contributors&quot;:[1,[[0,&quot;Anil Murty&quot;]]],&quot;bannerImage&quot;:[0,{&quot;src&quot;:[0,&quot;/_astro/banner-image.DqWl3A4K.png&quot;],&quot;width&quot;:[0,1500],&quot;height&quot;:[0,844],&quot;format&quot;:[0,&quot;png&quot;],&quot;fsPath&quot;:[0,&quot;/home/runner/work/website/website/src/content/Blog/building-the-open-cloud-part-2-re-imagining-the-cloud-with-akash/banner-image.png&quot;]}]}],&quot;render&quot;:[0,null]}],[0,{&quot;id&quot;:[0,&quot;akash-weekly-alani-kuye-overclock-labs/index.md&quot;],&quot;slug&quot;:[0,&quot;akash-weekly-alani-kuye-overclock-labs&quot;],&quot;body&quot;:[0,&quot;Akash Weekly With Greg Osuri \u2014 a live Twitter Spaces event held every Wednesday at 8am PT. Featuring Overclock Labs\u2019 CEO &amp; Co-Founder, Greg Osuri, and special guests from around the web3 space.\\n\\nOur guests on this week\u2019s Akash Weekly With Greg Osuri:\\n- Greg Osuri, CEO &amp; Co-Founder of Overclock Labs (creators of Akash Network)\\n- Alani Kuye, Technical Program Manager at Overclock Labs\\n\\nEcosystem Updates\\n- Mainnnet 4 Is Coming Soon\\n- We plan to launch this network upgrade in the first week of November.\\n\\nThe features below are the four main upgrades of Mainnet 4.\\n**IP Leases**\\nIP Leases will allow tenants on Akash to request a publicly routable IP address for the services they deploy. Today, you get an HTTP endpoint connected to your service, and Kubernetes assigns the actual port. With IP Leases, a tenant on Akash can request a dedicated IPV4 address, allowing users to assign a specific port instead of a randomly assigned port. IP Leases will unlock the functionality to host Solana nodes on Akash Network.\\n\\n**Provider Services Split**\\nThis upgrade will separate parts of the behind-the-scenes development process for Overclock Labs and make it easier for us to iterate quickly as we build and grow Akash.\\n\\n**Cosmos IBC3**\\nIBC3 allows one chain to send transactions to another chain. This provides users with access to the most recent features of the Cosmos ecosystem.\\n\\n**Interchain Accounts**\\nBy enabling Interchain Accounts on Akash, we will provide access to interchain composability and significantly improve the user experience on Akash Network.\\n\\nAfter Mainnet 4 has launched, we will shift our focus to enabling GPU support on Akash. We have received significant interest in GPU support from large machine-learning companies. We look forward to enabling this feature to allow the machine-learning space to access the decentralized cloud.\\n\\n## Our special guest this week: Alani Kuye, Overclock Labs\\n**Alani Kuye is the Technical Program Manager at Overclock Labs.** Alani has spent the last 21 years in enterprise technology across the U.S. and Europe, with a focus on scalability and rapid deployment. He advocates through technology to drive the evolution of the internet. His personal and professional life span across the U.S., Amsterdam, London, Berlin, and other parts of the world.\\n\\n\u201cMany of our ecosystem partners ship products every one to two weeks, which is a testament to the strength of our community. Our ecosystem is based on innovation\u2014and brand loyalty to Akash Network.\u201d\\n\\nWhat is PTRI?\\nAkash Network\u2019s new program, the Provider and Tenant Retention Initiative (PTRI), incentivizes providers and tenants to participate in Akash Network. It seeks to lower the barrier to entry that sidelines many who want to interact with Akash\u2014on either side of the marketplace.\\n\\nAnyone can set up a Keplr wallet, generate a referral code, and share it with friends, family, or anyone else they choose. If someone uses that referral code to become a provider or a tenant on Akash (and remains active for a set period), the person who generated the code is rewarded.\\n\\nThis makes it easy for anyone, at any technical skill level, to get involved and spread the word about Akash Network.\\n\\n## Q&amp;A\\nQ: Is there a stable economic model that supports AKT?\\nA: Given the financial nature of this topic, please listen to Greg Osuri address this question.\\n\\nQ: Is there an airdrop coming for AKT stakers from the Passage?\\nA: We believe there will be an airdrop for AKT stakers, but please check Passage\u2019s Twitter for the official announcement of any potential airdrops.\\n\\nQ: How long do you think the adoption of Web3 will take?\\nA: Mainstream adoption of Web3 is already underway. As more people experience the benefits that Web3 technologies uniquely offer, they will begin to promote the use of these technologies, leading to exponential adoption over time.\\n\\nOfficial estimates project 2030 for mainstream adoption of Web3 cloud technologies. Greg Osuri believes we will reach mainstream adoption on a faster timeline\u2014with full mainstream adoption closer to 2027.\\n\\nQ: How will Interchain Accounts (ICA) be used on Akash Network?\\nA: Today, DAOs have to rely on centralized infrastructure, which is censorable. There is no way, currently, for a DAO to directly control deployments on a decentralized network. Interchain Accounts will allow a DAO on Juno Network (for example) to deploy directly on Akash Network.\\n\\nWith ICA, a smart contract can directly control a deployment without a person needing to manage that deployment.&quot;],&quot;collection&quot;:[0,&quot;Blog&quot;],&quot;data&quot;:[0,{&quot;title&quot;:[0,&quot;Akash Weekly: Alani Kuye, Overclock Labs&quot;],&quot;description&quot;:[0,&quot;Akash Weekly With Greg Osuri \u2014 a live Twitter Spaces event held every Wednesday at 8am PT. Featuring Overclock Labs\u2019 CEO &amp; Co-Founder, Greg Osuri, and special guests from around the web3 space.&quot;],&quot;pubDate&quot;:[3,&quot;2022-10-07T00:00:00.000Z&quot;],&quot;draft&quot;:[0,false],&quot;categories&quot;:[1,[[0,&quot;Updates&quot;]]],&quot;tags&quot;:[1,[[0,&quot;Updates&quot;]]],&quot;contributors&quot;:[1,[[0,&quot;Zach Horn&quot;]]],&quot;bannerImage&quot;:[0,{&quot;src&quot;:[0,&quot;/_astro/banner-image.CWMgf8Ck.jpeg&quot;],&quot;width&quot;:[0,1920],&quot;height&quot;:[0,1080],&quot;format&quot;:[0,&quot;jpg&quot;],&quot;orientation&quot;:[0,1],&quot;fsPath&quot;:[0,&quot;/home/runner/work/website/website/src/content/Blog/akash-weekly-alani-kuye-overclock-labs/banner-image.jpeg&quot;]}]}],&quot;render&quot;:[0,null]}],[0,{&quot;id&quot;:[0,&quot;building-the-open-cloud-part-one/index.md&quot;],&quot;slug&quot;:[0,&quot;building-the-open-cloud-part-one&quot;],&quot;body&quot;:[0,&quot;\\n_By Anil Murty, Head of Product at Overclock Labs_\\n\\nI joined Overclock Labs, the creators of Akash Network, nearly four months ago to lead our product efforts. In that time, I\u2019ve seen exciting developments in our products and those built by a growing number of independent teams that are part of the Akash Network ecosystem. Several developments in the web3, crypto, and cloud computing markets have reinforced our vision and company mission.\\n\\nThis series of four articles will summarize how I see those developments, starting with this article\u2014which explores the current state of web3 infrastructure and the challenges that remain to be solved. The second article will delve into Akash Network\u2019s approach to solving those challenges. The third article will describe some of our latest product efforts in making it easier to deploy on Akash. The fourth article will highlight several projects from Akash\u2019s ecosystem that are contributing their efforts to our vision.\\n\\nIf you prefer listening over reading, [my talk at Messari Mainnet covers much of this content](https://youtu.be/jGqZzNWQrNs?t=10).\\n\\n## The State of Web3 Infrastructure\\n\\nWhile there is plenty that can be said when it comes to Web3 infrastructure across the different layers (L1-L3), for this discussion, I want to focus on three areas:\\n\\n- The current state of Layer 1 blockchain infrastructure.\\n- How infrastructure cost impacts the decentralization of chains.\\n- How better infrastructure and tooling can increase developer traction in Web3.\\n\\n## The Infrastructure Powering Top DApps Is Centralized\\n\\nEthereum and Solana are arguably two of the most popular chains among developers who build Decentralized Apps (DApps). Based on [stats published by State of the DApps](https://www.stateofthedapps.com/stats/platform/ethereum#new), Ethereum runs nearly 3,000 DApps.\\n\\n![](https://www.datocms-assets.com/45776/1664975700-screen-shot-2022-10-05-at-9-14-49-am.png)\\n\\nThese DApps are powered by Ethereum\u2019s network of ~450K validators (source: [https://beaconscan.com/stat/validator](https://beaconscan.com/stat/validator)), which is impressive.\\n\\n![](https://www.datocms-assets.com/45776/1664985200-screen-shot-2022-10-05-at-11-53-07-am.png)\\n\\nIf you dig deeper, you\u2019ll see that five validator platforms own 75% of the staking pool, with the largest of them, Lido Finance, making up nearly 30%. (Source: [https://beaconcha.in/charts/pools_distribution](https://beaconcha.in/charts/pools_distribution))\\n\\n![](https://www.datocms-assets.com/45776/1664985365-screen-shot-2022-10-05-at-11-55-41-am.png)\\n\\nIf we dig yet another layer deeper, things look even more centralized at the \u201cbare metal\u201d infrastructure layer. 75% of Ethereum\u2019s mainnet nodes run on three service providers: Amazon, Google, and Hetzner. (Source: [https://ethernodes.org/networkType/Hosting](https://ethernodes.org/networkType/Hosting))\\n\\n![](https://www.datocms-assets.com/45776/1664985516-screen-shot-2022-10-05-at-11-58-31-am.png)\\n\\nThe chart above looked different only a few weeks ago. Hetzner and Google swapped places over the course of a few weeks (we\u2019ll cover how that happened shortly). The chart below shows how things looked in early September 2022:\\n\\n![](https://www.datocms-assets.com/45776/1664985457-ethernodes-org.png)\\n\\nAlthough a similar chart doesn\u2019t seem to exist for Solana, I did find several articles talking about how more than a third of Solana\u2019s node infrastructure is also dependent on Amazon (AWS). See this article from [CoinRivet](https://coinrivet.com/it/amazon-hosts-37-of-actively-staked-sol-could-this-be-a-solana-kill-switch/):\\n\\n![](https://www.datocms-assets.com/45776/1664985571-solana.png)\\n\\nThe obvious takeaway from these stats is that the core (Layer 1) infrastructure that powers many popular chains and, therefore, most DApps are fairly centralized. This presents a huge risk to the Web3 ecosystem as a whole. For instance, if Amazon decided tomorrow that it wants nothing to do with crypto or chooses to build its own chain to compete with Ethereum\u2014it would cause significant disruption to the entire Web3 space.\\n\\nIf you think my concern is overblown, think again. One month ago, this is what Hetzner [decided to do](https://cointelegraph.com/news/hetzner-anti-crypto-policies-a-wake-up-call-for-ethereum-s-future):\\n\\n![](https://www.datocms-assets.com/45776/1664985640-hetzner-1.png)\\n\\n![](https://www.datocms-assets.com/45776/1664985671-hetzner-2.png)\\n\\nThis news is the likely reason for the increase in nodes deployed to Google Cloud over the last few weeks.\\n\\nNow, you may be thinking that in the worst-case scenario, where all the major public clouds decide to become \u201cclosed\u201d or anti-crypto, there are always independent data centers around the world where node operators could lease compute capacity.\\n\\nIn theory, that is true. In practice, the story is a little different. Leasing space in an independent data center is a manual, high-touch process relative to self-serve clouds like AWS. Independent data centers can involve significant capital expenditure (CapEx) if you intend to [co-locate](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Colocation_centre) your infrastructure. There is reason to believe that the ease of use of self-serve public clouds has decreased the total number of data centers worldwide\u2014from about 8.5 million in 2015 to about 7.2 million in 2021.\\n\\n(Source: [https://www.statista.com/statistics/500458/worldwide-datacenter-and-it-sites/](https://www.statista.com/statistics/500458/worldwide-datacenter-and-it-sites/))\\n\\n![](https://www.datocms-assets.com/45776/1664987339-screen-shot-2022-10-05-at-12-28-46-pm.png)\\n\\nWhile the number of data centers worldwide has declined in the last six to seven years, there are still an estimated 7.2 million data centers across the globe.\\n\\nOn average, only 15-20% of the compute capacity within these data centers is fully utilized.\\n\\nAnything we can do to more efficiently utilize excess compute capacity in these data centers would not only benefit the people running these businesses but would also benefit the planet from the standpoint of environmental sustainability.\\n\\n## Low-Cost Infrastructure Is the Key to Decentralization\\n\\nLet\u2019s assume we will keep running our Web3 node infrastructure in public clouds for the foreseeable future. What implications does this have on decentralization from a pure cost perspective?\\n\\nOne of the greatest misconceptions that people have about running workloads in public clouds is that it is _always_ cheaper than running those workloads in a data center. While this is often true for small teams and projects with small resource requirements, as those teams and projects scale, this becomes less and less true.\\n\\nBut don\u2019t just take my word for it. Andreesen Horowitz (a16z), arguably the biggest name in Web3 venture capital, called the cost of the public cloud a \u201cTrillion Dollar Paradox\u201d in a [blog post published in 2021](https://a16z.com/2021/05/27/cost-of-cloud-paradox-market-cap-cloud-lifecycle-scale-growth-repatriation-optimization/).\\n\\n![](https://www.datocms-assets.com/45776/1664986059-a16z-1.png)\\n\\na16z arrived at this thesis after studying the cost structure of several well-known public companies, including Palantir, Slack, Snowflake, Datadog, and Asana. They found that, on average, these large enterprise SaaS companies spend about 50% of their revenue on public cloud hosting.\\n\\n![](https://www.datocms-assets.com/45776/1664986150-screen-shot-2022-10-05-at-12-09-05-pm.png)\\n\\nAssuming the cost structure looks similar for the consumer apps we all use (Doordash, Grubhub, Lyft, Uber, Spotify, and others), this means that for every dollar you spend on these apps, nearly $0.50 is paid to a public cloud provider. a16z\u2019s mission is to find the next multi-billion dollar opportunity. Right now, they consider this to be the biggest opportunity in infrastructure.\\n\\nFrom _The Cost of Cloud, A Trillion Dollar Paradox_:\\n\\n![](https://www.datocms-assets.com/45776/1664986255-screen-shot-2022-10-05-at-12-10-39-pm.png)\\n\\nCloudflare, whose CDN and reverse-proxy infrastructure [powers nearly 80% of all websites](https://kinsta.com/cloudflare-market-share/), provides another data point related to cloud costs. In a blog post from July 2021, Cloudflare calls egress cost on AWS \u201c...egregious.\u201d\\n\\n![](https://www.datocms-assets.com/45776/1664986312-cloudflare-1.png)\\n\\nEgress cost is what AWS\u2019 customers pay to pull data (their own data!) out of AWS. While AWS charges nothing to bring data into AWS (the \u201dingress cost\u201d), it charges an arm-and-a-leg to pull data out of AWS. Rather than charging based on the size of the pipe a customer connects to AWS with, Amazon charges based on the amount of data you pull through that pipe. This starkly contrasts how a person is charged for their home broadband connection, where they pay the same cost (based on upload and download speeds) regardless of whether that person watches Netflix for three hours every day or simply uses their email and browses the web.\\n\\nWhile AWS charges its customers for the amount of data they pull through (and not the rate at which it flows), it pays the service provider based on the rate at which the data flows (and not the amount of data). In other words, this is the way that AWS makes it expensive to switch to another provider\u2014while earning a pretty penny every time their customers pull out data. The most important thing to keep in mind is that while AWS hasn\u2019t changed its stance despite Cloudflare and others calling it out, most data centers in the world today provide \u201cunmetered bandwidth\u201d where you pay a fixed cost based on the size of the connection rather than the amount of data you pull. This is yet another reason to consider deploying on one of those 7.2M data centers.\\n\\nWhat does all this have to do with decentralization? It\u2019s simple: As the Web3 space increasingly transitions to Proof-of-Stake (PoS) consensus mechanisms, the role of validators becomes more and more critical to ensure chain security. As such, the more validators the chains have, the greater the security of the chains and, in turn, the DApps running on those chains. For there to be more validators, the cost of spinning one up must be low enough that nearly anyone can run a validator node.
