The process of creating and hosting a web app on Akash inspired the Akashlytics team to create a fully dependency-free desktop app that can be installed in a few clicks on Windows, Mac, and Linux and be able to do all the steps required to deploy on Akash in the same app. Click [here](https://www.akashlytics.com/deploy) to check out the platform.\\n\\n- _**Akash Deploy by SpacePotato**_: A web-based tool for deploying and managing containers on the Akash Network. The deploy website leverages a new AkashJS library that replaces the command line functionality with JavaScript. Click [here](https://2g0cl9g6u0mn6vrbiajv5p9h508vbfq07j6fm060dl8lci85k436jh0.siasky.net/) to see the platform.\\n- _**Minecraft deployment on Akash by SlowRiot**_: Launch a Minecraft server on the Akash blockchain. It can be easily configured with only changes to deploy.yaml, and supports any Minecraft version, including multiple modded server types. See the full project, [here](https://github.com/ovrclk/awesome-akash/tree/master/minecraft).\\n- _**Akashian Public Library by Rodrigo Rochin**_: The Akashian Public Library is a platform that allows anyone to find interesting copyright. This includes free books, comics, documents, media and information, and accessing the library is completely free. See the full project, [here](https://forum.akash.network/t/akash-nextcloud-filebase/2343/3).\\n- _**Radical.xyz by SlowRiot**_: Host a gitpage-like website anonymously, using decentralized Akash resources, directly from a Radicle or git repository. See the full project, [here](https://github.com/slowriot/anubis).\\n\\n### **Community &amp; Events**&nbsp;\\n\\n#### **Community Growth**\\n\\nOur community has grown by leaps and bounds over the past year. At the beginning of 2020, our community totaled 22,843 members. As of the time of this blog post, we have _85,266 total community members around the world_. A 273% increase!\\n\\nOur main community hubs are in the United States, China, Russia, and Korea. However, we\u2019re not stopping there. With the help of our Insider community (we\u2019ll cover that next) we have plans to grow our local hubs in South America, Turkey, India, Portugal, and beyond.\\n\\nWe are so humbled by the growth and efforts of our community and wouldn\u2019t be in the place we are today if it were not for the dedication and passion of our global community.\\n\\n#### **Akash Insiders**\\n\\nThe Akash Insiders are community moderators, event organizers, and content contributors. They are leaders within our community and spearhead the growth of not just Akash, but the entire crypto ecosystem in cities and towns, globally.\\n\\nLast summer, when we launched the Insiders program, we didn\u2019t know if anyone inside the Akash community would be interested in joining. After all, the program is volunteer-based and many members of our community have jobs and live outside of crypto. We were blown away by the interest and response. Since its launch, we\u2019ve had over 268 applications to participate and we\u2019ve onboarded 28 Akash Insiders. Insiders are the tip of the spear and we have big plans for the program in 2022 and look forward to onboarding many more Insiders over the coming days and months. If you\u2019d like to get involved as an Akash Insider, click [here](https://akash.network/community?form=true#insiders).\\n\\n#### **Community Events**\\n\\nThe pandemic has affected everyone and Akash has not been immune to the effects of this global pandemic. However, with restrictions calming and precautions in place, we\u2019ve been able to increase our reach through local in-person gatherings and online activities.\\n\\nOver the past year, we\u2019ve held 82 online events. From Youtube Livestreams to Telegram AMA\u2019s to Twitter Spaces events. We\u2019ve been able to connect with our community. In addition to online events, We hosted our first-ever in-person Akash meetups in New York, during Messari Mainnet.\\n\\n![](https://www.datocms-assets.com/45776/1640653069-pxl20210921223914533-mp.jpg)\\n\\nWe also hosted a series of events in Lisbon during Solana Breakpoint. We could have never done any of these events without the help of numerous partners such as Ledger, Infura, Polygon, Filebase, Agoric, Osmosis, and of course, Cosmos.\\n\\n![](https://www.datocms-assets.com/45776/1640653114-pxl20211109183443371-night.jpg)\\n\\n### **2022**&nbsp;\\n\\nAs the world becomes more digitalized, we see GPUs everywhere. Not just in computers but cell phones, gaming consoles, and yes, even Teslas. And, as Ethereum moves towards a PoS model, it\u2019s inevitable that more will hit the market at that time.\\n\\nOnce unlocked, GPU support on Akash will not only open the door for the next generation of Web3 games but will unlock unprecedented Artificial Intelligence (AI) and Machine Learning (ML) capabilities. Meaning, everyone will be able to run _even more_ complex workloads without fear of de-platforming or censorship.\\n\\n> \u201cThis has been a monumental year with the launch of Akash Network, a product for developers by developers that Adam Bozanich, my Cofounder, and I created as a result of dealing with the barriers that centralized cloud providers presented. We saw a need and wanted a better alternative for the builders of tomorrow. We\u2019re that much closer towards a flourishing Web 3.0 and with GPU support on the docket, we\u2019re excited to crack open a whole new array of use cases.\u201d\\n>\\n> Greg Osuri, CEO of Akash Network\\n\\nWe\u2019re in the home stretch and just have one more step along the way in the form of a Testnet. Coming early 2022, we\u2019ll share more details on what the challenges look like and how you can participate in unlocking the future of Web 3.0.\\n&quot;],&quot;collection&quot;:[0,&quot;Blog&quot;],&quot;data&quot;:[0,{&quot;title&quot;:[0,&quot;2021 Recap: The Road to GPU Support&quot;],&quot;description&quot;:[0,&quot;As the year comes to a close, personally and professionally, we tend to get introspective; analyzing our year, celebrating our milestones, and looking ahead to new goals for the New Year.&quot;],&quot;pubDate&quot;:[3,&quot;2021-12-27T00:00:00.000Z&quot;],&quot;draft&quot;:[0,false],&quot;categories&quot;:[1,[[0,&quot;Updates&quot;]]],&quot;tags&quot;:[1,[[0,&quot;Updates&quot;],[0,&quot;Developers&quot;],[0,&quot;Partners&quot;],[0,&quot;Product&quot;]]],&quot;contributors&quot;:[1,[[0,&quot;Kelsey Ruiz&quot;]]],&quot;bannerImage&quot;:[0,{&quot;src&quot;:[0,&quot;/_astro/banner-image.Dauecxe4.jpg&quot;],&quot;width&quot;:[0,1124],&quot;height&quot;:[0,424],&quot;format&quot;:[0,&quot;jpg&quot;],&quot;orientation&quot;:[0,1],&quot;fsPath&quot;:[0,&quot;/home/runner/work/website/website/src/content/Blog/2021-recap-the-road-to-gpu-support/banner-image.jpg&quot;]}]}],&quot;render&quot;:[0,null]}],[0,{&quot;id&quot;:[0,&quot;q2-2022-update-for-akash-roadmap/index.md&quot;],&quot;slug&quot;:[0,&quot;q2-2022-update-for-akash-roadmap&quot;],&quot;body&quot;:[0,&quot;\\nAt the beginning of this quarter, the Akash core team published an ambitious roadmap, the [Akash Roadmap 2022](https://akash.network/blog/product-roadmap-2022). Now we are at the end of our first quarter, here's is an update on how we are progressing through the roadmap.\\n\\nIn summary, WAGMI.\\n\\n### **Persistent Storage**\\n\\nAkash now supports persistence storage (the most requested feature) in the Testnet. This feature requires a chain upgrade for Mainnet, which is currently planned for Q1 2022.\\n\\nPersistence storage allows workloads to persist data between restarts, ideal for data-intensive workloads such as blockchain nodes, Solana and Ethereum.\\n\\n**Status:** Testnet\\n\\n**Since:** [0.15.0 (rc4)](https://github.com/ovrclk/akash/releases/tag/v0.15.0-rc4)\\n\\n**Related Pull Request(s):**\\n\\n- [feat: persistent storage #1348](https://github.com/ovrclk/akash/pull/1348)\\n- [docs(storage): setup and usage of persistent storage #1471](https://github.com/ovrclk/akash/pull/1348)\\n\\n### **Network Usage Dashboard**\\n\\nThe first version of the Network usage dashboard is complete and deployed in production, naturally running on Akash, and available at [stats.akash.network](https://stats.akash.network).\\n\\nThis version is inspired by [Akashlytics](https://www.akashlytics.com/); the future version will include several provider-related metrics.\\n\\nThe source code is now being cleaned up and open-sourced momentarily with an announcement planned for early next year.\\n\\n**Status:** Live ([stats.akash.network](https://stats.akash.network))\\n\\n### **Hostname Migration**\\n\\nAkash now supports Hostname Migration in the upcoming Testnet. Usage documentation is available [here](https://akash.network/docs/release-notes/v0.14.0#hostname-migration). This feature requires a chain upgrade for Mainnet, which is currently planned for Q1 2022.\\n\\nDeployment of an updated workload encounters a challenge when the DNS hostname remains active on the existing deployment.&nbsp; An example scenario is presented to ensure understanding of the challenge - followed by a review of the mechanism introduced in this release to migrate a hostname to the new deployment.\\n\\n**Status:** Testnet\\n\\n**Since:** [0.14.0](https://akash.network/docs/release-notes/v0.14.0)\\n\\n**Related Pull Request(s):**\\n\\n- [feat(provider): rework hostname management to use a kube operator #1365](https://github.com/ovrclk/akash/pull/1365)\\n\\n### **TTY (Shell) Access**&nbsp;\\n\\nTTY Access is implemented in the Testnet. This feature requires a chain upgrade for Mainnet, which is currently planned for Q1 2022.\\n\\nTTY Access allows developers to access the shell of the container that the application is running in. This provides the ability to easily debug. Currently, debugging and running applications on Akash is difficult, as users can not run arbitrary commands on a running container. TTY access unblocks this and allows users to run any command.\\n\\n**Status:** Testnet\\n\\n**Since:** [0.14.0](https://akash.network/docs/release-notes/v0.14.0)\\n\\n**Related Pull Request(s):**\\n\\n- [Add provider lease-shell command #1293](https://github.com/ovrclk/akash/pull/1293)\\n\\n### **Inflation Decay Curve**&nbsp;\\n\\nInflation Decay Curve is implemented in the Testnet. This feature requires a chain upgrade for Mainnet, which is currently planned for Q1 2022.\\n\\nOn-chain [inflation decay curve](https://akash.network/roadmap?feature=inflation-decay-curve) ensures inflation decay occurs every block period without needing governance proposals.\\n\\n**Status:** Testnet\\n\\n**Since:** [0.15.0 (rc4)](https://github.com/ovrclk/akash/releases/tag/v0.15.0-rc4)\\n\\n**Related Pull Request(s):**\\n\\n- [feat(inflation): Implement Akash custom inflation function according to the whitepaper. #1352](https://github.com/ovrclk/akash/issues/1352)\\n\\n### Airdrop Faucet\\n\\nThe first version of the [Faucet](https://akash.network/roadmap?feature=airdrop-faucet) is complete and deployed in production, available at [drip.akash.network.](https://drip.akash.network) This version emits 20 Akash Token (AKT) and has a minor delay (for manual verification)&nbsp; to prevent fraud. The future versions will employ automatic algorithms that will transmit tokens in real-time.\\n\\nThe source code is now being cleaned up and open-sourced momentarily. Announcement planned for January.\\n\\n**Status:** Live ([drip.akash.network](https://drip.akash.network))\\n\\n### **Provider Onboarding Framework**&nbsp;\\n\\nCurrently, there is an enormous and intricate set of steps that a provider needs to execute in order to provide compute on the Akash Network. This leads to confusion and instability of the provider. A new provider onboarding framework will increase adoption, optimize the onboarding process, and eliminate potential issues with the provider in the future.\\n\\nA provider onboarding framework is to ease new providers selling compute on Akash, planned to be released in Q4 of 2021 is now delayed.\\n\\nThe automation for bootstrapping a node is code-complete and tested internally for Testnet and Devnets; the documentation is, however, still pending, so we\u2019re moving this deliverable to next quarter. The helm charts for installing various components are available at [ovrclk/helm-charts](https://github.com/ovrclk/helm-charts).\\n\\n**Status**: Incomplete\\n\\n**Related Repositories:**\\n\\n- [ovrclk/helm-charts](https://github.com/ovrclk/helm-charts)\\n\\n### **Developer Hub**&nbsp;\\n\\nThe developer hub will be a one-stop shop for all developer-related content such as guides, tutorials, documentation, architecture, and discussions.\\n\\n**Status:** Not Started\\n\\n**Estimate (Updated):** Q1 2022\\n\\n### **ASN (IP Addresses) Market**&nbsp;\\n\\nThis Feature Dedicated IP addresses (and ports) for workloads and the marketplace to source them.\\n\\nWorkloads hosted on Akash share IP addresses because there is no facility to assign individual IP addresses to applications. This presents limitations with routing. Hostname name-based routing has to rely on HTTP or SSL. To accommodate for TCP / UDP, Akash assigns random ports and there is no way to multiplex TCP services over a single port. This also slows down fault recovery as DNS services require record updates which are slow to propagate. An ability to assign a dedicated IP address will solve this issue.\\n\\n**Status:** Incomplete\\n\\n**Estimate (Updated):** Q1 2022\\n\\n### **Log Retention**&nbsp;\\n\\nThe Log Retention feature provides the ability to retain logs between restarts\\n\\n**Status:** Incomplete\\n\\n**Estimate (Updated):** Q1 2022\\n\\n**Related Pull Request(s):**\\n\\n- [Provider JWT Service #1417](https://github.com/ovrclk/akash/pull/1417)\\n\\n### **\u200b\u200bEthereum Bridge**\\n\\nThe Ethereum Bridge enables AKT users to acquire AKT using various ERC-20 tokens (USDT). By enabling users with more options to buy and sell AKT, we can increase liquidity, eliminate friction points found in the new developer onboarding process, and attract additional AKT buyers and traders from the crypto retail market. Additionally, this will increase our likelihood of working with Tier 1 exchanges and DEXs like Uniswap.\\n\\nThe [Gravity Bridge](https://www.gravitybridge.net) went live on [December 14](https://twitter.com/gravity_bridge/status/1470896532257861635). We\u2019re currently testing the bridge and the AKT ERC-20 contract is currently under development and audit.\\n\\n**Status:** Mainnet\\n\\n**Related Repositories:**\\n\\n- [Gravity Bridge](https://github.com/Gravity-Bridge/Gravity-Bridge)\\n\\n### **Akash Javascript SDK**&nbsp;\\n\\nJavascript SDK simplifies extending Akash in Javascript applications by providing libraries to improve access to the Akash API. The SDK also abstracts standard functions like credential management, retries, data marshaling, serialization, and deserialization.\\n\\nThe first version is complete and currently being tested on a new notification service to be announced next quarter.\\n\\n**Status:** Incomplete\\n\\n**Updated Estimate:**&nbsp; Q1 2022\\n\\n### **AKCMD Deploy Tool**&nbsp;\\n\\nAKCMD is a command-line utility that simplifies workload management on the Akash network. AKCMD is a complementary tool to core Akash CLI that focuses on improving tenant workflow by taking an opinionated approach to deployment on Akash Network.\\n\\nMuch progress has been made and the first version will be ready by mid-January.\\n\\n**Status:** Incomplete\\n\\n**Updated Estimate:** Q1 2022\\n\\n### **Lease Renegotiation**&nbsp;\\n\\nThis feature provides the ability for users to renegotiate the AKT price without breaking the lease. The volatility of AKT leads to unstable value exchanges, as the AKT denominated price is set during lease creation and doesn\u2019t change until the lease terminates. When the dollar AKT is higher than it was during lease creation, it may benefit the provider at the cost of the tenant and vice versa. An ability to renegotiate the lease during its life cycle solves this issue.\\n\\nWe\u2019re exploring a new stable payment mechanism for Akash as part of Akashian Economics 2.0. This feature may be obsolete.\\n\\n**Status:** Not Started\\n\\n**Updated Estimate:** Not Planned\\n&quot;],&quot;collection&quot;:[0,&quot;Blog&quot;],&quot;data&quot;:[0,{&quot;title&quot;:[0,&quot;Q4 Update on Akash Roadmap 2022&quot;],&quot;description&quot;:[0,&quot;At the beginning of this quarter, the Akash core team published an ambitious roadmap, the Akash Roadmap 2022. Now we are at the end of our first quarter, here's is an update on how we are progressing through the roadmap.&quot;],&quot;pubDate&quot;:[3,&quot;2021-12-20T00:00:00.000Z&quot;],&quot;draft&quot;:[0,false],&quot;categories&quot;:[1,[[0,&quot;Updates&quot;]]],&quot;tags&quot;:[1,[[0,&quot;Updates&quot;],[0,&quot;News&quot;]]],&quot;contributors&quot;:[1,[[0,&quot;Greg Osuri&quot;]]],&quot;bannerImage&quot;:[0,{&quot;src&quot;:[0,&quot;/_astro/banner-image.BRYJL8Rc.jpg&quot;],&quot;width&quot;:[0,3472],&quot;height&quot;:[0,1953],&quot;format&quot;:[0,&quot;jpg&quot;],&quot;orientation&quot;:[0,1],&quot;fsPath&quot;:[0,&quot;/home/runner/work/website/website/src/content/Blog/q2-2022-update-for-akash-roadmap/banner-image.jpg&quot;]}]}],&quot;render&quot;:[0,null]}],[0,{&quot;id&quot;:[0,&quot;ibc-what-you-need-to-know/index.md&quot;],&quot;slug&quot;:[0,&quot;ibc-what-you-need-to-know&quot;],&quot;body&quot;:[0,&quot;\\nWelcome to [IBC](https://ibcprotocol.org/) 101. In this blog, together we\u2019ll explore what IBC is, how it works and why it\u2019s important, but first, why should you care?&nbsp; IBC is a core component enabling the Cosmos vision and feeding the narrative that the [Cosmos](https://v1.cosmos.network/intro) network is the \u201cInternet of blockchains.\u201d Like gravity, IBC will help pull economic value into the growing blockchain that is the Cosmos Hub.&nbsp; So without further ado, let\u2019s delve into IBC\u2019s unique properties, features and what\u2019s in store next.&nbsp; Let\u2019s get to it.\\n\\n### What is IBC?\\n\\nIBC is short for Inter-Blockchain Communication.&nbsp; It has been developed as part of the greater Cosmos network ecosystem by IBC contributors such as Tendermint, Interchain Foundation and Agoric Systems.&nbsp; In its simplest form, IBC is connecting different blockchains together.&nbsp; Up until now, blockchains like Bitcoin, Ethereum and many others operate in their own silo or as if each blockchain was its own deserted island, disconnected from the rest of the world or other blockchains and unable to communicate.&nbsp; It gets rather lonely.\\n\\nThe IBC protocol is a vehicle for blockchains to socially network (communicate, swap tokens and information).&nbsp; IBC is kind of what the TCP protocol is to the internet.&nbsp; Prior to TCP, the internet was a collection of desperate computer networks that didn\u2019t communicate well between each other.&nbsp; Together, with IP, TCP/IP standardized how data was sent and routed over computer networks.&nbsp; Today, TCP/IP seamlessly underpins how we consume and enjoy the internet every day.&nbsp; Similarly, IBC standardizes how blockchains communicate. Hence, Cosmos is often referred to as the \u201cInternet of blockchains\u201d.\\n\\n# How does IBC work?\\n\\nEach blockchain that wants to communicate with one another sends and receives header files to keep track of validator sets. Put simply, they run a light client of each other to keep track of one another's blockchain/ledger.&nbsp; When sending tokens from one blockchain to the other, tokens must first be:\\n\\n1.  Bonded (held in trust) in preparation for the transaction (i.e. 100 ATOM)\\n2.  A proof must be sent to the receiving blockchain that the tokens have been bonded\\n3.  The receiving chain must verify the proof of the 100 bonded ATOM tokens\\n4.  If the proof is verified, 100 ATOM tokens are frozen/bonded on the originating chain, while a representation of the 100 ATOM are created on the new chain\\n\\nTo be compatible with IBC, a blockchain must have fast finality.&nbsp; Bitcoin and Ethereum, which are both proof of work systems, do not have this capability.&nbsp; Each blockchain must maintain its own validator set.&nbsp; In doing so, blockchains maintain better interoperability with applications.\\n\\nScaling this solution becomes challenging if multiple blockchains want to communicate with one another.&nbsp; Connections can get out of hand quickly.&nbsp; This is where the Cosmos Hub comes into play. Hubs act as the aggregators, enabling a singular blockchain to communicate with many blockchains.&nbsp; The hub enables a network of blockchains or the \u2018internet of blockchains\u201d.\\n\\n### Why is IBC important?\\n\\nIBC is a critical element to the Cosmos framework connecting sovereign blockchains.&nbsp; This creates tremendous value to the network, beyond the obvious ability to swap tokens and information. Paired with the Tendermint BFT engine, Cosmos SDK, and other tools, developers can scale blockchains with speed, security and interoperability within or outside of the Cosmos network.&nbsp; This kind of versatility can be a powerful incentive for new or existing blockchains to build with or connect to Cosmos via the IBC protocol thereby growing the value of the Cosmos network, in addition to its capability and utility.\\n\\n### Blockchain Integrations\\n\\nIn addition to token transfers, IBC also facilitates interaction with the IBC data oracle.&nbsp; IBC compatible blockchains use this protocol to access [BandChain](https://docs.bandchain.org/whitepaper/cosmos-IBC.html)_**.**_\\n\\nBandChain indexes blockchain data from IBC connected sources.&nbsp; BandChain receives requests for information and processes the transactions accordingly. In plain English, IBC connects several blockchains together, making cross-chain queries, data and analytics possible.&nbsp; To simplify and scale access to BandChain, [StarPort](https://starport.com/) was born.&nbsp; StarPort accelerates the adoption curve of using BandChain***,*** as well as many other aspects of blockchain development.\\n\\n### Customizations\\n\\nTo be IBC compatible, a blockchain consensus layer must offer fast finality.&nbsp; Proof of Work (PoW) systems such as Bitcoin and Ethereum do not offer fast finality.&nbsp; To address this problem, IBC offers \u201cpegs\u201d as an intermediary between the blockchain and the Cosmos Hub.&nbsp; The peg will translate the PoW system into one that has fast finality and is compatible with IBC.&nbsp; Ethereum in particular has its own peg or bridge that we\u2019ll talk about later.\\n\\nIBC and the broader Cosmos network support and enable the building and networking of sovereign blockchains.&nbsp; While Ethereum supports a wide range of L2 applications/DAPP\u2019s and DeFi, its services are constrained to the limitation of EVM\u2019s (Ethereum Virtual Machine) and the Ethereum protocol.&nbsp; With Cosmos and IBC DAPP\u2019s and services are sovereign to make decisions and integrate at an L1 layer to maximize efficiencies, security or scalability to the specific needs of a project.\\n\\n### Governance\\n\\nThe Cosmos network builds and maintains the IBC protocol.&nbsp; ATOM, being the native token of the Cosmos network, enables [Validators](https://hub.cosmos.network/main/validators/validator-faq.html#what-is-a-validator) and [Delegators](https://hub.cosmos.network/main/validators/validator-faq.html#what-is-a-delegator) the ability to stake ATOM to secure the network and in return receive voting eligibility for new proposals.&nbsp; Changes to the IBC protocol and other aspects of the Cosmos network must be approved by the community prior to implementation.&nbsp; This gives anyone the ability who\u2019s staking and/or validating the opportunity to influence the direction of the project.&nbsp; While running a Validator node does take technical skills, Delegators can easily participate and are also highly encouraged to contribute to the governance process.\\n\\n### Business Enablement\\n\\n[_**Osmosis**_](https://app.osmosis.zone/) is the first Cosmos native interchain Decentralized Exchange or DEX and Automated Money Maker or AMM for short.&nbsp; Osmosis facilitates the trade of Cosmos IBC enabled tokens such as ATOM, OSMO, AKT, LUNA, UST, etc. &nbsp; More than that, it enables AirDrops, Staking, Voting, Liquidity Pooling and Analytics.\\n\\n[**Sifchain**](https://sifchain.finance/) is an OMNI Chain Decentralized Exchange or DEX and Automated Money Maker or AMM.&nbsp; The native token to Sifchain is ROWAN.&nbsp; What makes Sifchain special is it enables token transfers among the top 20 blockchains and is IBC connected, BinanceChain, Bitcoin, EOS, Polkadot etc.&nbsp; Becoming a Liquidity Provider on Sifchain can bring juicy APY\u2019s (Annual Percentage Yield) depending on the pair!\\n\\n[**Emeris**](https://emeris.com/) is a new OMNI Chain Decentralized Exchange or DEX and Automated Money Maker or AMM, developed by the Tendermint foundation.&nbsp; Aims include multi-wallet support, access to diverse DeFi platforms, multi-chain staking, and a mobile application.&nbsp; Emeris features the all-new [Gravity Bridge](https://github.com/cosmos/gravity-bridge#:~:text=Gravity%20bridge%20is%20Cosmos,chain%20and%20back%20to%20Ethereum.), which is a great segway to our next topic, the Ethereum network.\\n\\n### Gravity Bridge and Cross Ecosystem Transfer of Value\\n\\nThe [Gravity Bridge](https://github.com/cosmos/gravity-bridge#:~:text=Gravity%20bridge%20is%20Cosmos,chain%20and%20back%20to%20Ethereum.) is a bi-directional bridge to the Ethereum network designed to run on the Cosmos network for maximum speed, efficiency and security.&nbsp; With Gravity Bridge, ERC20 based tokens can be transferred to Cosmos chains and back to Ethereum.&nbsp; The ability to transfer a Cosmos asset to the Ethereum network is in development and should be made available soon.\\n\\nCosmos secures over 140 billion USD in capital across 40+ applications and services and is growing all the time.&nbsp; Just like a port city or Country may be measured by its value and velocity of trade or Gross Domestic Product (GDP), Cosmos will be valued by the amount of trade and liquidity that flows through it.&nbsp; IBC will facilitate all of this by making it the standard protocol by which sovereign blockchains connect.&nbsp; Cosmos and IBC interoperability will facilitate the internet of blockchains, which ensures transfer of value will continue to grow for a long time to come.\\n\\n### Closing\\n\\nCosmos has a grand vision, building and connecting decentralized blockchain applications and services. Like a night sky filled with stars, we map the Cosmos with constellations such as Leo, Taurus and Orion.&nbsp; IBC is what connects blockchains, like stars connected in a constellation.&nbsp; IBC is the glue that\u2019s building and connecting the Cosmos network to sovereign blockchains.&nbsp; It\u2019s the protocol that\u2019s enabling the internet of Blockchains.&nbsp; Imagine that for a second.&nbsp; What value does or will the internet of blockchains have?\\n&quot;],&quot;collection&quot;:[0,&quot;Blog&quot;],&quot;data&quot;:[0,{&quot;title&quot;:[0,&quot;IBC: What You Need to Know&quot;],&quot;description&quot;:[0,&quot;Welcome to IBC 101. In this blog, together we\u2019ll explore what IBC is, how it works and why it\u2019s important, but first, why should you care?&quot;],&quot;pubDate&quot;:[3,&quot;2021-12-01T00:00:00.000Z&quot;],&quot;draft&quot;:[0,false],&quot;categories&quot;:[1,[[0,&quot;Insights&quot;]]],&quot;tags&quot;:[1,[[0,&quot;Insights&quot;]]],&quot;contributors&quot;:[1,[[0,&quot;Greg Richardson&quot;]]],&quot;bannerImage&quot;:[0,{&quot;src&quot;:[0,&quot;/_astro/banner-image.C29G8Ww6.gif&quot;],&quot;width&quot;:[0,320],&quot;height&quot;:[0,122],&quot;format&quot;:[0,&quot;gif&quot;],&quot;fsPath&quot;:[0,&quot;/home/runner/work/website/website/src/content/Blog/ibc-what-you-need-to-know/banner-image.gif&quot;]}]}],&quot;render&quot;:[0,null]}],[0,{&quot;id&quot;:[0,&quot;akash-and-polygon-offer-decentralized-infrastructure-to-dapp-developers/index.md&quot;],&quot;slug&quot;:[0,&quot;akash-and-polygon-offer-decentralized-infrastructure-to-dapp-developers&quot;],&quot;body&quot;:[0,&quot;\\nAkash Network and Polygon join forces with a bounty matching program that offers the Polygon Ecosystem a path from traditional cloud to cloud providers on Akash Network. Akash\u2019s peer-to-peer marketplace offers Polygon developers a cost-effective option to deploy and scale their applications and services while Polygon provides [a starter kit](https://polygontechnology.notion.site/Polygon-Starter-Kit-a289a505a0bb4e8b8189c1fc3b2223d0) to developers including instructions for hosting on Akash Network.\\n\\n[Polygon](https://polygon.technology/), is a full-stack scaling solution built to improve Ethereum by processing transactions in a more efficient fashion and connecting different blockchains. This provides a way for developers to let their decentralized applications, or dApps, work across different blockchains.\\n\\n### **Making dApps More Decentralized**\\n\\nThe benefit of moving to Akash is that decentralized application (dApp) developers can deploy their existing software faster and at scale while eliminating their reliance on a single cloud provider.\\n\\nBy running their dApps across multiple cloud providers, developers break free of the vendor lock-in and constantly changing terms of service associated with the traditional cloud companies. The lower costs on Akash Network bring welcomed cost-savings, making it an easy decision for developers who are tied to the centralized internet giants, Amazon Web Services (AWS), Google Cloud, and Microsoft Azure.\\n\\nMost cloud-native applications running on the cloud today can run on Akash Network.\\n\\nFor end-users, this promises to result in more dApps that are \u201cfully decentralized\u201d and more robust. Should a provider shut down, dApps can quickly spin up a new container deployment on a different provider. Thanks to Akash Network, the steps to switch cloud providers are closing a deployment and then creating a new lease. The deposit is returned immediately, and the only fees incurred are signing the blockchain transactions. Akash lets you set the price, length of lease, and terms of your deployment.\\n\\n### **Web3 and DeFi Working Together**\\n\\nMore than 70% of Polygon\u2019s 700 dApps are related to decentralized finance (DeFi) and provide investing, lending, and other financial services. Developers are also building dApps for gaming, collecting (NFTs), social platforms, blogs, and more.\\n\\nDeFi companies and decentralized autonomous organizations (DAOs) are a natural fit for the Akash Network. Like DeFi and DAOs, Akash is founded on the principle of permissionless, open access and does not decide who can use the marketplace. Akash is a community-driven open-source project that allows anyone to contribute.\\n\\n### **The Akash Polygon-athon**\\n\\nDubbed the Akash Polygon-athon, Akash has launched a new program specifically for dApps running on Polygon\u2019s network. All developers in the Polygon ecosystem are now incentivized to migrate away from the traditional cloud providers and move their back-end and front-end services to the Akash Network.\\n\\n- Akash is offering 20 $AKT to any Polygon ecosystem project to cover the cost of hosting on Akash. If you are a developer, check out the [Polygon Starter Kit](https://akashnet.notion.site/Polygon-Akash-Starter-Kit-d4e817023556417ea8c9b679336d0d76) to get started.\\n\\n- To put things in perspective, this covers roughly 2-3 months of hosting costs for an application with 4 cores, 16 GB RAM, and 1 GB of storage - OR - up to 20 microservices.\\n\\n- Akash will _**match**_ bounties posted by Polygon projects - up to 100 $AKT. If a project offers a bounty of 100 $AKT or more, Akash will match the bounty with an additional 100 $AKT, and the person hired to the bounty will be awarded 200 $AKT.\\n\\n- Polygon apps can immediately post a bounty on the Akash Bounty Board ([click here](https://forum.akash.network/c/bounties/)) to hire engineers to help them with the DevOps effort of migration and hosting on Akash.\\n\\n- Bounties by projects can be paid in any currency. Matching awards by Akash will be paid in $AKT.\\n\\nFurther, developers are encouraged to apply for up to $100,000 from the Akash Developer Grant Program, which will be welcoming projects running on Polygon. Support for Polygon dApps will be funded through a bounty hosted by Akash and Gitcoin. Visit the [Akash Community Forum](https://forum.akash.network/c/hackathons/polygon/56) to learn how to apply for the program.\\n\\nIf you're an Ethereum Developer, you're already a Polygon developer. Leverage Polygon\u2019s fast and secure txns for your dApp, get started [here](https://docs.polygon.technology/docs/develop/getting-started).\\n&quot;],&quot;collection&quot;:[0,&quot;Blog&quot;],&quot;data&quot;:[0,{&quot;title&quot;:[0,&quot;Akash and Polygon Offer Decentralized Infrastructure to dApp Developers&quot;],&quot;description&quot;:[0,&quot;Akash Network and Polygon join forces with a bounty matching program that offers the Polygon Ecosystem a path from traditional cloud to cloud providers on Akash Network. Akash\u2019s peer-to-peer marketplace offers Polygon developers a cost-effective option to deploy and scale their applications and services while Polygon provides a starter kit to developers including instructions for hosting on Akash Network.&quot;],&quot;pubDate&quot;:[3,&quot;2021-11-22T00:00:00.000Z&quot;],&quot;draft&quot;:[0,false],&quot;categories&quot;:[1,[[0,&quot;Partners&quot;]]],&quot;tags&quot;:[1,[[0,&quot;Developers&quot;],[0,&quot;Partners&quot;],[0,&quot;News&quot;],[0,&quot;Partners&quot;]]],&quot;contributors&quot;:[1,[[0,&quot;Colin Pollen&quot;]]],&quot;bannerImage&quot;:[0,{&quot;src&quot;:[0,&quot;/_astro/banner-image.CC2X0kwg.jpeg&quot;],&quot;width&quot;:[0,1024],&quot;height&quot;:[0,532],&quot;format&quot;:[0,&quot;jpg&quot;],&quot;fsPath&quot;:[0,&quot;/home/runner/work/website/website/src/content/Blog/akash-and-polygon-offer-decentralized-infrastructure-to-dapp-developers/banner-image.jpeg&quot;]}]}],&quot;render&quot;:[0,null]}],[0,{&quot;id&quot;:[0,&quot;architecture-series-part-i-the-cloud/index.md&quot;],&quot;slug&quot;:[0,&quot;architecture-series-part-i-the-cloud&quot;],&quot;body&quot;:[0,&quot;Everything we do today on the Internet leverages \u201cthe cloud.\u201d The term has become so ubiquitous it can be hard to understand exactly what the cloud is, how it works, and how we interact with it.\\n\\nIt's a remarkably simple concept, actually, and a powerful one as well, but it's easy to have that simplicity and power obscured by specs and stats and technical terms. Let's start from the foundations and take a look at what the cloud really is and why it's important for everyone online.\\n\\nWhile the term \\&quot;the cloud\\&quot; is fairly new, the concept goes back a long way, to the earliest days of computing, in fact, when computers were room-sized machines that you had to access via specialized terminals elsewhere in the building. However, it wasn't until about 20 years ago that the modern concept of working and communicating online came about.\\n\\n### Who needs servers?\\n\\nAt that time broadband was becoming more common and people were learning just how powerful the web could be (turns out AOL wasn't all that great). But to offer services online, companies needed to invest in _servers_: specialized computers dedicated to handling Internet traffic. This expensive step was easy to get wrong, and a spotty or frustratingly slow web-based business might be worse than none at all.\\n\\nThe solution appeared in the form of _datacenters_, buildings full of servers all being operated by the same company as one giant machine, and instead of buying your own, you'd just rent time and space on theirs. The operators used software to quickly and efficiently delegate computing power to their customers, letting companies use just two servers one day and a hundred on the next if business took off.\\n\\nThis newfound reliability and flexibility led to the creation of some early cloud providers \u2014 though they didn't call themselves that quite yet \u2014 like what would later become the biggest of them all, Amazon Web Services (AWS). These companies made money by hosting and delivering data for their customers \u2014 from small businesses to equally large ones like Netflix.\\n\\nThere's an important distinction here between the cloud services that would soon be offered by AWS, Google, and Microsoft Azure and the other things those companies did. Just because AWS or Azure hosts your data doesn't mean you have to list your product on Amazon's store or run Windows. The cloud services they offer were more like a utility, for the most part detached from their other products and competing with each other on price for processing power, storage, and traffic. This infrastructure is provided as a layer that's transparent for users \u2014 the only time anyone these days knows what cloud provider a website or service runs on is when one of them goes down and takes a quarter of the Internet with it.\\n\\n### From local apps to web apps\\n\\nAt first, these hosted services simply acted as more convenient places to quickly store and access bulky data. But before long it became clear that there was more to the opportunity than not having to run your own servers. In fact, the servers could do much of the work that home computers and phones were doing, with incredible benefits.\\n\\nThe poster child for this revelation, though it is far from alone, is certainly Gmail. For decades emails were something that went between computers, showing up in an application like Outlook that you opened on your computer, which had to be configured with a lot of technical details. Google showed the world that not only could email be done entirely in a browser, but that it was arguably superior to its desktop rivals.\\n\\nWhy? Think about it. Your inbox is now available at any computer you sit down at \u2014 all you do is go to gmail.com. Not only that, Gmail kept adding new features and expanding the already eye-popping gigabyte of storage each user was allowed \u2014 and no matter how big your attachments got, they never filled up _your_ hard drive.\\n\\nWhat do all these features have in common? They only became possible because the entire application lived full-time on Google's servers. Nothing depended on the user whatsoever: desktop or laptop, Mac or Windows, Chrome or Firefox... well, at the time it was probably Netscape or Internet Explorer, but you get the idea.\\n\\nGmail is just one example of the thousands of new markets and business opportunities that were created by the capability of letting someone else's computer do all the hard work, while the user just gets the results. This model was so promising that practically the entire digital economy would soon be built on it.\\n\\n### Digital transformation hits the gas\\n\\nThat's good, because as time went on people started storing a _lot_ more data online. [By one estimate](https://www.forbes.com/sites/gilpress/2013/05/09/a-very-short-history-of-big-data/), the world produced about 1.5 exabytes of data in total in 1999. (Your phone might have 100 gigabytes of space, your laptop perhaps ten times that, a terabyte \u2014 a petabyte is a thousand of those, and an exabyte is a thousand of _those_). By 2006 this had increased by an order of magnitude to 160 exabytes yearly. Over the next decade it would increase even faster, and these days we are producing [hundreds of exabytes](https://blog.iotechnologies.com/data-utilization-research/) _every single day_.\\n\\nAs for the money involved, in 2008 the cloud computing market was worth perhaps $6 billion or so, not pocket change by any means but only a tiny fraction of what was to come: cloud services in 2021 are a market worth well over $300 billion and growing faster than ever, [according to Allied Market Research](https://www.alliedmarketresearch.com/cloud-services-market).\\n\\nWhat happened? The world moved online, and everything online is part of \\&quot;the cloud\\&quot; in some way or another. From business services to social media to TV and movies, everything began to live in datacenters, and because no one wants to think about which server exactly or at what datacenter \u2014 even network engineers may not know for sure where their company's data is physically \u2014 everyone started just calling it \\&quot;the cloud.\\&quot; Something vague yet omnipresent.\\n\\n### The cloud and Big Tech&nbsp;\\n\\nAs the market grew, leaders emerged \u2014 and they're exactly who you'd expect. Microsoft's Azure, Amazon's AWS, and Google Cloud were among the first to invest in the space and offer cloud-native services, and with that first-mover advantage, they have steadily advanced until they completely dominated the cloud landscape.\\n\\nOn one hand, this is a good thing: large, well-known companies are likely to provide a variety of useful and reliable services easily accessible to businesses looking to host their own platforms. If you want to start an on-demand video service, you don't have to spend hundreds of millions on a datacenter, you just call up Amazon and tell them how much bandwidth you need. In fact, that's pretty much what Netflix did! (There's more to it than that, obviously, but that's a story for another time.)\\n\\nBut it also comes with risks. Having the cloud infrastructure owned by a handful of big tech companies means innovation can suffer while the market stagnates and becomes more siloed. Like any industry, if there are only a handful of players, and they're printing money, there's little incentive to truly change the product on offer, and instead, they compete on things like customer retention and upselling. Meanwhile, prices won't decline as fast as they would with more competition: Amazon, as pointed out by Cloudflare recently, seems to be marking up its own bandwidth costs [by almost 8,000 percent](https://blog.cloudflare.com/aws-egregious-egress/) \u2014 at a time when bandwidth is cheaper than ever.\\n\\nIt's a trade-off we often see in growing industries: it's not quite a monopoly, and it's not quite price-fixing, but it's certainly not the robust competition that produces the best results for consumers and businesses. When you spend half of your 8 or 9 figures of revenue on cloud services, you tend to start wondering [whether it's worth it to build that datacenter after all](https://a16z.com/2021/05/27/cost-of-cloud-paradox-market-cap-cloud-lifecycle-scale-growth-repatriation-optimization/).\\n\\n### Cloudy present, cloudy future\\n\\nWhether you're shopping, consuming media like shows or music, or doing a video call with friends (something that of course became far more common during the pandemic), you are using cloud services every step of the way: when you browse, when you stream, when you pay, when you ask for help.\\n\\nPractically every service that needs to happen online has migrated to the cloud in one sense or another. This has produced enormous increases in productivity in some ways, but also creates new risks as personal and financial data flows between those services \u2014 and opportunities to protect that data. And of course, the challenge that started it all \u2014 getting enough servers to do the job right \u2014 is a constant challenge even for the mega-corporations vying with each other for the market.&quot;],&quot;collection&quot;:[0,&quot;Blog&quot;],&quot;data&quot;:[0,{&quot;title&quot;:[0,&quot;Architecture Series Part I: The Cloud&quot;],&quot;description&quot;:[0,&quot;Everything we do today on the Internet leverages \u201cthe cloud.\u201d The term has become so ubiquitous it can be hard to understand exactly what the cloud is, how it works, and how we interact with it.&quot;],&quot;pubDate&quot;:[3,&quot;2021-11-17T00:00:00.000Z&quot;],&quot;draft&quot;:[0,false],&quot;categories&quot;:[1,[[0,&quot;Insights&quot;]]],&quot;tags&quot;:[1,[[0,&quot;Insights&quot;]]],&quot;contributors&quot;:[1,[[0,&quot;Kelsey Ruiz&quot;]]],&quot;bannerImage&quot;:[0,{&quot;src&quot;:[0,&quot;/_astro/banner-image.B4cnl79M.gif&quot;],&quot;width&quot;:[0,500],&quot;height&quot;:[0,276],&quot;format&quot;:[0,&quot;gif&quot;],&quot;fsPath&quot;:[0,&quot;/home/runner/work/website/website/src/content/Blog/architecture-series-part-i-the-cloud/banner-image.gif&quot;]}]}],&quot;render&quot;:[0,null]}],[0,{&quot;id&quot;:[0,&quot;introducing-the-permaweb-hackathon/index.md&quot;],&quot;slug&quot;:[0,&quot;introducing-the-permaweb-hackathon&quot;],&quot;body&quot;:[0,&quot;\\nWhen you buy an NFT how do you know it is going to be around in 20 years? Who is paying to store it? NFTs are non-fungible tokens that grant ownership of unique items like art, music, digital items in a game, or real-world objects. Generative NFTs are especially popular as they transform strings of data stored in the token into colorful digital images of [Apes](https://boredapeyachtclub.com/#/), [Punks](https://www.larvalabs.com/cryptopunks), [Mondrians](https://paulstamatiou.com/how-i-made-50k-in-3-days-with-nfts/), even the [cover of Rolling Stone\u2019s](https://hypebeast.com/2021/11/rolling-stone-bored-ape-yacht-club-digital-cover-nfts-announcement) magazine. While the actual tokens define ownership, they do not store the actual images on the blockchain. More often than not, the artwork is stored somewhere out of your control - or on a server that could shut down or suffer from data corruption.\\n\\nThe Akash Network is ideal for producing generative art, but a more permanent solution is needed to store your NFTs. Akash Network is a cloud platform that offers containers with _**ephemeral**_ storage, and data stored in containers are not meant to be stored long-term. _**Persistent**_ storage is on the [Akash Roadmap](https://akash.network/roadmap) and will add the ability for data to persist between restarts, ideal for data-intensive workloads such as blockchain nodes.\\n\\n> \u201cAs seen with the NFT gaming platform, Strange Clan, powered by Akash, we\u2019ve seen real-world use cases that leverage Akash\u2019s distributed peer-to-peer marketplace for cloud compute. We\u2019re excited to partner with Arweave and ArDrive to enable NFT creators and collectors to create generative art and store the NFTs permanently on Arweave using ArDrive.\u201d\\n>\\n> Greg Osuri, CEO at Akash Network\\n\\nWhen it comes to choosing storage services for your NFT, the most important factors are durability and availability. Availability is a measure of hardware redundancy while durability is a measure of data redundancy. Amazon S3 \u201cboasts\u201d an availability of 99.99% which translates to over 8 hours downtime per year. Durability is the ability for data to be protected from corruption and \u201cbit rot\u201d over the long term. Amazon Elastic Block Store (EBS) volumes have annual failure rates that range between 0.1% - 0.2% every year. For every 1000 Amazon EBS volumes that you provision in a year, you can expect one or two of them to fail.\\n\\n### Meet the Permaweb&nbsp;\\n\\n[Arweave](https://www.arweave.org/) is a decentralized data storage protocol that allows you to store documents and applications in perpetuity on a permanent internet \u2014 the permaweb. The protocol matches people who have hard drive space to spare with those individuals and organizations that need to store data or host content permanently. All data stored is backed by an [endowment](https://arwiki.wiki/#/en/storage-endowment) ensuring it is available in perpetuity. You can read an introduction to Arweave and the _**permaweb**_ [here](https://arwiki.wiki/#/en/the-permaweb). Arweave is a completely community-owned and operated open-source network. The Arweave network is powered by the AR token, which can be found on most major exchanges.\\n\\n> \u201cWe are very excited to see support for Arweave and ArDrive grow in the Akash ecosystem. Persistent state between VM executions is a critical issue in the space -- and we are thrilled to see this being addressed with Arweave.\u201d\\n>\\n> Sam Williams\\n\\n[ArDrive](https://ardrive.io/) is a permanent storage platform whose [applications and core libraries](https://github.com/ardriveapp/) offer hierarchical organization, privacy via complete end-to-end encryption, flexibility, extensibility, and access control over your most valuable data, all made possible by its underlying core technology, the [Arweave File System (ArFS) Protocol](https://ardrive.atlassian.net/wiki/spaces/help/pages/278495281/Arweave+File+System). ArDrive is a fantastic way to [store NFT data durably and permanently](https://ardrive.io/nft/) on Arweave.\\n\\n> \\&quot;ArDrive is the critical layer bridging the existing models that users and data systems rely upon to organize and access their data with the transaction-oriented, decentralized, and cryptographically secure Arweave Permaweb. ArDrive-powered, durable storage for Akash compute systems and bootstrap workflows are a natural fit and an exciting opportunity. The ArDrive Community is ready to support, and eager to celebrate the innovations developed by the Challengers!\\&quot;\\n>\\n> Ariel Melendez, Chief Technology Officer at ArDrive\\n\\n### Durable NFT Challenge\\n\\nAkash Network, Arweave Protocol, and ArDrive are partnering to offer a prize to open source projects to utilize building blocks from the Akash and ArDrive ecosystems to create an amazing NFT-related integration. NFT creators and collectors can create generative art using Akash\u2019s compute marketplace and store the NFTs permanently on Arweave using ArDrive.\\n\\nThe winner of the PermaNFT Challenge will receive 1,000 AKT and 10AR, equivalent to 20GB of perma-storage. The runner-up will receive 100 AKT and 2.5AR, equivalent to 5GB of perma-storage.\\n\\n### Bootstrap Challenge\\n\\nSnapshots and Bootstrap images for Akash deploys, backed by ArDrive. Use the [ArDrive CLI](https://github.com/ardriveapp/ardrive-cli/) (Node.js) to create an app, service, or workflow integration that can take automatic, permanent backups of Akash Databases, Docker Snapshots, and/or Bootstrap Images to public or private drives on ArDrive. Alternatively, or in addition, create an app, service, or workflow integration that can retrieve backups from ArDrive of key Akash entities and/or data and deploy or restore them to Akash.\\n\\nThe winner of the Bootstrap Challenge will receive 1,000 AKT and 10AR, equivalent to 20GB of perma-storage. The runner up will receive 100 AKT and 2.5AR, equivalent to 5GB of perma-storage.\\n\\n### Filesystem Challenge\\n\\nFilesystems are critical for containers. [FUSE (Filesystem in Userspace)](https://github.com/libfuse/libfuse) is an interface for userspace programs to export a filesystem to the Linux kernel. Create a FUSE integration for a Linux-based Akash container that utilizes ArDrive as its FUSE backend. Use the [ArDrive CLI](https://github.com/ardriveapp/ardrive-cli/) (Node.js - Typescript) or [ArDrive Core Library](https://github.com/ardriveapp/ardrive-core-js) (Node.js - Typescript) to build your integration.\\n\\nThe winner of the Filesystem Challenge will receive 1,000 AKT and 10AR, equivalent to 20GB of perma-storage. The runner-up will receive 100 AKT and 2.5AR, equivalent to 5GB of perma-storage.\\n\\n### How to Participate\\n\\nTo compete in the challenge, submit your work to the [Akash-Arweave Challenge](https://forum.akash.network/c/bounties/arweave/) on the Akash Community Forum. Please include the following information:\\n\\n- Project name and a list of team members\\n- A description of what your project does and why you decided to build it\\n- Demo video or presentation slides. Your video should be around 3 minutes long and include a demo of your working project. Videos must be made publicly visible.\\n- Access to your working application or Github code repository. Access must be provided to the working application or code for judging and testing by providing a link to a website, functioning demo, or a Github repository.\\n\\nTo help developers get started here are some of the important links:\\n\\n- Akash Getting Started: [https://akash.network/docs/guides/cli](https://akash.network/docs/guides/cli)\\n- Akash Discord: [http://discord.akash.network/](http://discord.akash.network/)\\n- Akash Community Fund: [http://forum.akash.network/](http://forum.akash.network/)\\n- ArDrive CLI Docs: [https://github.com/ardriveapp/ardrive-cli](https://github.com/ardriveapp/ardrive-cli)\\n- ArDrive Core Library Docs: [https://github.com/ardriveapp/ardrive-core-js](https://github.com/ardriveapp/ardrive-core-js)\\n- ArDrive Discord: [https://discord.gg/ya4hf2H](https://discord.gg/ya4hf2H)\\n- ArDrive Knowledge Base: [http://kb.ardrive.io](http://kb.ardrive.io)\\n- Arweave wiki: [https://arwiki.wiki/#/en/category/resources](https://arwiki.wiki/#/en/category/resources)\\n- Arweave Faucet: &nbsp;[faucet.arweave.net](http://faucet.arweave.net)\\n- Example Pool: [https://ar.virdpool.com/](https://ar.virdpool.com/)\\n- Example Pool: [https://www.hpool.in/statistics/ar](https://www.hpool.in/statistics/ar)\\n\\nTo learn more about the hackathon and how you can participate check out the Akash Community Forum, [here](https://forum.akash.network/c/bounties/arweave/57).\\n&quot;],&quot;collection&quot;:[0,&quot;Blog&quot;],&quot;data&quot;:[0,{&quot;title&quot;:[0,&quot;Introducing the Permaweb Hackathon&quot;],&quot;description&quot;:[0,&quot;When you buy an NFT how do you know it is going to be around in 20 years? Who is paying to store it?&quot;],&quot;pubDate&quot;:[3,&quot;2021-11-08T00:00:00.000Z&quot;],&quot;draft&quot;:[0,false],&quot;categories&quot;:[1,[[0,&quot;Developers&quot;]]],&quot;tags&quot;:[1,[[0,&quot;Developers&quot;],[0,&quot;News&quot;]]],&quot;contributors&quot;:[1,[[0,&quot;Colin Pollen&quot;]]],&quot;bannerImage&quot;:[0,{&quot;src&quot;:[0,&quot;/_astro/banner-image.C4yC9GEK.jpg&quot;],&quot;width&quot;:[0,1200],&quot;height&quot;:[0,675],&quot;format&quot;:[0,&quot;jpg&quot;],&quot;orientation&quot;:[0,1],&quot;fsPath&quot;:[0,&quot;/home/runner/work/website/website/src/content/Blog/introducing-the-permaweb-hackathon/banner-image.jpg&quot;]}]}],&quot;render&quot;:[0,null]}],[0,{&quot;id&quot;:[0,&quot;announcing-our-filebase-akash-hackathon-winners/index.md&quot;],&quot;slug&quot;:[0,&quot;announcing-our-filebase-akash-hackathon-winners&quot;],&quot;body&quot;:[0,&quot;Together with Filebase and Akash, developers and enterprises can quickly migrate from centralized cloud services like Amazon Web Services (AWS), Google Cloud, and Microsoft Azure, onto a decentralized network of cloud providers at a reduced cost.&nbsp;\\n\\nBack in July, we teamed up with Filebase to break down barriers when it comes to building the dWeb. As part of that partnership, we challenged our community to build the best app that integrates Filebase and Akash, offering $10,000 in $AKT and $250 in free object storage.\\n\\nOver the course of the two-month-long hackathon, we received 16 total projects and were amazed with the quality and creativity of each one. Below are the top 3 projects that came out on top.&nbsp;\\n\\n### **3rd - QR-Share by zjor**\\n\\nQR-Share is an app that allows you to instantly share a photo or file from mobile to mobile, or from PC to mobile.\\n\\nFirst, you upload a file to Filebase S3 which gives you a public URL that is then generated into a QR-code. This allows you to share a photo with people in its original quality without adding them to your contacts which can be useful at public events or in large group settings.&nbsp;\\n\\nSimple, elegant, and useful. This thoughtful use of Filebase and Akash displays the power that technologies like Pastebin pioneered. Taking this to the next level with QR codes and file downloading this tool has real-world applications that thoroughly impressed the judges.\\n\\nClick [here](https://forum.akash.network/t/qr-share-on-akash-filebase/2892/7) to see the full submission and [here](https://qrshare.io/) to check out the QR-Share app.&nbsp;\\n\\n### **2nd - Akash Filebase AI/ML DeCloud Platform by SpacePotato**&nbsp;\\n\\n> \u201cMachine learning and AI require lots of storage (for storing data, model checkpoints, production models, etc.) and lots of compute (for experimenting with and training different models, serving the models in production, etc.). Filebase and Akash respectively provide both at a fraction of the cost of their centralized counterparts, but there is no AI/ML platform to take advantage of them right now. Let\u2019s change that.\u201d &nbsp;\\n> \\n> SpacePotato\\n\\nIntroducing The Akash Filebase AI/ML DeCloud Platform.&nbsp;\\n\\nKey features of this project include:&nbsp;\\n\\n*   Users will be able to specify and deploy a custom compute instance that comes with a hosted Jupyter notebook environment at the click of a button.\\n    \\n*   Within their Jupyter environment, users will be able to load datasets from Filebase S3 and train their models. Model checkpoints and final models will also be uploaded to Filebase. Users can close their Jupyter deployment and the models will still be available from Filebase.\\n    \\n*   From the web interface, users will be able to see all their models saved to Filebase. There will be a UI that allows users to pick a model to deploy as an endpoint, so that consuming ML apps can use the endpoint to perform model inference.\\n    \\n\\nNot only did this project impress the Filebase and Akash teams, but community members loved it too.&nbsp;\\n\\n![](https://www.datocms-assets.com/45776/1635481067-screen-shot-2021-10-28-at-5-45-45-pm.png)\\n\\n![](https://www.datocms-assets.com/45776/1635481107-screen-shot-2021-10-28-at-5-45-19-pm.png)\\n\\nCheck out the full project, [here](https://forum.akash.network/t/akash-filebase-ai-ml-decloud-platform/2588/8).&nbsp;\\n\\n### **1st - The Akashian Public Library by Rodrigo Rochin**\\n\\nThe Akashian Public Library is a platform that allows anyone to find interesting copyright. This includes free books, comics, documents, media and information, and accessing the library is completely free.\\n\\n![](https://www.datocms-assets.com/45776/1635481144-screen-shot-2021-10-28-at-5-24-20-pm.png)\\n\\nThere is also a calendar with important events related to Akash, Filebase, blockchain and tech. The team is working on adding more features, which will become available very soon.\\n\\n![](https://www.datocms-assets.com/45776/1635481187-screen-shot-2021-10-28-at-5-25-43-pm.png)\\n\\nThis was by far the most polished and has real-world applications right out of the gate. The care and attention to detail won out and placed the Akashian Public Library as the first place winner of the competition. Click [here](https://forum.akash.network/t/akash-nextcloud-filebase/2343/3) to view the full project.&nbsp;\\n\\n  \\nTo check out some of the hackathons we\u2019re currently running, head to the [Akash Community Forum](https://forum.akash.network/c/hackathons/7) to see how you can get involved.&quot;],&quot;collection&quot;:[0,&quot;Blog&quot;],&quot;data&quot;:[0,{&quot;title&quot;:[0,&quot;Announcing our Filebase + Akash Hackathon Winners&quot;],&quot;description&quot;:[0,&quot;Together with Filebase and Akash, developers and enterprises can quickly migrate from centralized cloud services like Amazon Web Services (AWS), Google Cloud, and Microsoft Azure, onto a decentralized network of cloud providers at a reduced cost.&quot;],&quot;pubDate&quot;:[3,&quot;2021-10-29T00:00:00.000Z&quot;],&quot;draft&quot;:[0,false],&quot;categories&quot;:[1,[[0,&quot;Developers&quot;]]],&quot;tags&quot;:[1,[[0,&quot;Developers&quot;],[0,&quot;News&quot;]]],&quot;contributors&quot;:[1,[[0,&quot;Kelsey Ruiz&quot;]]],&quot;bannerImage&quot;:[0,{&quot;src&quot;:[0,&quot;/_astro/banner-image.Baj9nzkU.gif&quot;],&quot;width&quot;:[0,1200],&quot;height&quot;:[0,675],&quot;format&quot;:[0,&quot;gif&quot;],&quot;fsPath&quot;:[0,&quot;/home/runner/work/website/website/src/content/Blog/announcing-our-filebase-akash-hackathon-winners/banner-image.gif&quot;]}]}],&quot;render&quot;:[0,null]}],[0,{&quot;id&quot;:[0,&quot;crypto-101/index.md&quot;],&quot;slug&quot;:[0,&quot;crypto-101&quot;],&quot;body&quot;:[0,&quot;\\n#### **The Basics: Why Does Crypto Matter?**\\n\\nCryptocurrencies are important because they allow instantaneous, private and secure transactions between individuals located anywhere in the world without relying on large financial institutions. The implications of this technology have far-reaching consequences and represent a revolution that is spreading into new areas and causing significant innovation.\\n\\nWhether or not you are directly impacted by crypto today, there is a high likelihood that you will be in the future. Explaining the full significance of the phenomenon would be impossible in a short blog post.\\n\\n#### **What Can Crypto Do For You?**\\n\\nHere is a list of potential benefits that cryptocurrency can offer you, as a user:\\n\\n- Earn a living buying, swapping, selling cryptocurrencies.\\n- Earn passive income, compounding interest and high yields through a wide variety of \u201cDecentralized Finance\u201d (DeFi) technologies.\\n- Purchase digital property which can accumulate significantly in value via NFTs.\\n- Effortlessly and rapidly transfer value to people in your network instantly.\\n- Buy real-world items with your earnings such as houses, cars or travel.\\n- Get a job working for a decentralized autonomous organization (DAO) that pays you based on your contributions and output rather than your credentials or job title.\\n- Create and sell digital goods and profit from them in new ways, without any \u201cmiddlemen\u201d taking the majority of your profit.\\n\\n#### **Regulatory and Legal Concerns**\\n\\nIf you follow the conversation around Cryptocurrencies on social media, you will receive mixed signals. Some people think Crypto is all a giant scam. Others believe they will be regulated out of existence. Still, others think that cryptocurrencies only offer value to criminals in the form of money laundering (or worse). Finally, a large and passionate group of dreamers believe that cryptocurrencies are a true revolution that will completely reshape the modern world for the better.\\n\\nThe reality is that cryptocurrencies are a permanent shift in the fundamental nature of money and will disrupt the entire world economy. The speed of innovation and creativity of entrepreneurs working in crypto has shown that this is an innovation with far-reaching and permanent consequences. Regulatory activity tends to follow technological innovation, and global governments are responding by adapting to this change with new laws and regulations.\\n\\nCryptocurrencies unlock many new types of financial transactions not previously possible for individuals. With cryptocurrencies, it is possible to take out loans against funds stored in a DAO, for example. I recommend reading up on the topic of taxes for cryptocurrencies or loans extensively before engaging in any significant activity. [Here are some guides to get started](https://tokentax.co/guides/defi-crypto-tax/#:~:text=If%20you%20lend%20your%20crypto,depends%20on%20your%20DeFi%20platform.).\\n\\nFor the most part, the simple \u201cbuying and selling\u201d of cryptocurrencies are all you need to worry about and these are taxed using standard calculations. It is important, however, to have some understanding of the regulatory and tax environment in advance. A common practice is to keep [a spreadsheet of any trading activities to track cost-basis for tax purposes](https://www.zenledger.io/blog/tracking-cost-basis-across-wallets-exchanges). There is a growing ecosystem of services to help automate tax tracking such as [ZenLedger](https://www.zenledger.io/).\\n\\n#### **Step 1: Get A Wallet (And Lock It Down)**\\n\\nThe starting point for most people\u2019s journeys into crypto will begin with setting up a wallet to store their funds in. There are dozens of wallets available. Below are a few interesting ones worth investigating:\\n\\n- Klever (really simple, easy to use iOS wallet)\\n- MetaMask (works with a very wide range of the decentralized applications (dApps) out there)\\n- Trust Wallet\\n- Coinbase Wallet\\n- Ledger\\n- Crypto.coin\\n- Keplr\\n\\nDepending on which tokens or coins you want to experiment with, you may need to download or make use of different wallets. [You can find a recent list of wallets here](https://theislandnow.com/blog-112/2021s-best-bitcoin-wallet-cryptocurrency-wallets/).\\n\\nThere are also \u201chot\u201d and \u201ccold\u201d wallets. A \u201chot wallet\u201d is a wallet that is connected actively to the internet and enables transfer into and out of it via a connected service. A \u201ccold\u201d wallet is a wallet that is stored offline. In most situations, \u201ccold\u201d wallets are a measure taken to avoid hacking or theft of the funds being stored. Hot wallets are considered to be less secure and more prone to hacking or theft. [You can read more about wallet security here](https://www.investopedia.com/news/bitcoin-safe-storage-cold-wallet/).\\n\\n#### **Step 2: Get Money Into The Cryptoverse**\\n\\nGetting money into the cryptoverse is often burdensome and time-consuming. Many banks may not make it easy to shift dollars into cryptocurrency exchanges. It can take as long as 10+ days or more to initiate a bank transfer in some cases. In many cases, you will need to provide a government ID (called a KYC or Know Your Customer check).\\n\\nOnce your money is in the system, things get easier and much more instantaneous. The best way to get money into the cryptoverse is often via an exchange. There are many to choose from. [You can see the list of largest exchanges here.](https://coinmarketcap.com/rankings/exchanges/)\\n\\n#### **Step 3: Purchase and Swapping of Coins**\\n\\nOnce your funds are in an exchange, you can either purchase coins directly or shift your funds from the exchange into one of your wallets. You can either choose to keep your money in an exchange or move it to one of your wallets. Once in a wallet, you can often swap the coin for other coins that look interesting using a variety of built-in or decentralized services.\\n\\nA big area of development is in swapping and moving coins from one blockchain ecosystem to another. Decentralized Liquidity Providers such as Uniswap have become popular which allows users to readily exchange one token for another (with a fee). There are also a group of services building \u201cbridges\u201d between ecosystems to enable users to shift their coins from one ecosystem to another.\\n\\n#### **Step 4: Researching Coins &amp; Tokens**\\n\\nHere is where the complexity and speed of innovation in the cryptocurrency space become a challenge for anyone wanting to get started. A general filter I use when evaluating coins to invest in looks like this:\\n\\n- Strong social media activity and engaged founder.\\n- The rapid rate of innovation, constantly pushing out new updates.\\n- Strong community activity on Telegram, Discord, Reddit, Twitter.\\n- Not redundant tech (there are a million \u201cliquidity provider\u201d types, for example).\\n- Does the coin offer additional features such as staking or deflationary benefits?\\n- Look for a direct relationship with a major exchange (often important).\\n- Interesting and unique technology that solves a real problem.\\n- Strong partnerships and deal-making.\\n- Has a unique story or advantage.\\n\\nHere is how I decide what to buy:\\n\\n- I follow the coin on Reddit, Telegram, Discord, Twitter.\\n- I check the community activity, what are they talking about, is there anything disqualifying that I see immediately?\\n- I read the Reddit for that coin and learn about any upcoming news or announcements.\\n- Try to gauge if the community is insane or not, many of the communities tend to be highly delusional or only focused on price. If they do not have rational reasons for buying and holding, I avoid it.\\n- Check the Coinmarket cap for the coin, is it sub $1 billion dollars? Or less? I like to buy coins that have a market cap in the hundreds of millions before they \u201cbreak out.\u201d\\n\\nThere is no wrong answer for what to buy or how to go about selecting tokens or coins to invest in.\\n\\n#### **Understanding Different Algorithms and Blockchains**\\n\\nAn important thing to understand about the current cryptocurrency ecosystem is that there are many blockchain ecosystems. A few prominent ones:\\n\\n- Ethereum\\n- Bitcoin\\n- Binance\\n- Solana\\n- Cardano\\n- Cosmos\\n- Tron\\n\\nEach of these blockchains represents fundamentally different approaches to solving the challenge of digital currency. Each of these blockchains also has spawned dozens or hundreds of tokens based on their respective ecosystems.\\n\\nIn crypto terminology, a \u201cCoin\u201d tends to be the fundamental unit of a Blockchain such as Ethereum, Bitcoin, Solana etc. A \u201cToken\u201d is a unit of exchange based on someone else\u2019s blockchain. For example, Ethereum has thousands of Tokens such as UNI (Uniswap) based on its ERC-20 standard.\\n\\n#### **Some Terms You Might Encounter**\\n\\n- \u201cWrapped Token\u201d A coin from one blockchain that has been packaged for sale on another blockchain. For example, I could buy \u201cWrapped Bitcoin\u201d using Ethereum so I can buy, hold and sell Bitcoin without actually leaving the Ethereum ecosystem.\\n- \u201cUtility Token\u201d A token that can be used for something. For example, you could buy AVA token from Travala and use it to get discounts on travel.\\n- \u201cBridge\u201d A big challenge in the crypto space is translating tokens or coins from one blockchain to another as there are frequently significant technological differences. Bridged allow you to do this.\\n- \u201cOracle\u201d An oracle, in the crypto space, is a program that read a datafeed from the \u201creal world\u201d and transports it into the crypto world. For example, Mirror Protocol uses Oracles or Observers to track the prices of stocks like Tesla and convert them into assets which you can buy and sell that track Tesla stock in crypto space\\n- \u201cCBDC\u201d Central Bank Digital Currency. These are coins issued by governments to represent their local currency. Increasingly, major governments are considering using these as replacements for their previous systems\\n- \u201cStable Coin\u201d This is a token or coin which is designed to track the value of $1 or other similar currency. Stable Coins come in many shapes and sizes and are often used as convenient stand-ins for dollars which can be used instead of transferring money into and out of the cryptoverse\\n- \u201cSmart Contract\u201d A piece of code which lives on the blockchain and can be used to execute programmatic behavior\\n- \u201cLiquidity Provider\u201d A service which incentivizes users to make their tokens available as the basis for \u201cLiquidity Pools.\u201d These liquidity pools make it possible to ensure there is always ample of supply for rarer tokens to be \u201cSwapped\u201d for other tokens.\\n- \u201cDAO\u201d A decentralized autonomous organization. It has become increasingly popular to launch autonomous organizations which are run programmatically in a distributed fashion. A popular example is the MakerDAO\\n- \u201cdApps\u201d Decentralized Applications which live on the blockchain and can perform various programmatic functions\\n- \u201cDeFi\u201d Decentralized Finance, a growing movement towards shifting finance to smart contracts, DAOs, blockchains and dApps\\n- \u201cNFT\u201d Non-Fungible Token. A token which represents a digital good such as a JPEG. Ownership of an NFT is tracked via the blockchain, they can be bought and sold\\n\\n#### **Closing Thoughts**\\n\\nThat\u2019s it for now. Once again, this is a rapidly evolving space and new innovations and trends are occurring every day. I recommend spending significant time joining and researching the many online chats and communities available to gain a more recent understanding and keep your knowledge up to speed with the market.\\n&quot;],&quot;collection&quot;:[0,&quot;Blog&quot;],&quot;data&quot;:[0,{&quot;title&quot;:[0,&quot;Crypto 101&quot;],&quot;description&quot;:[0,&quot;Why Does Crypto Matter?&quot;],&quot;pubDate&quot;:[3,&quot;2021-10-21T00:00:00.000Z&quot;],&quot;draft&quot;:[0,false],&quot;categories&quot;:[1,[[0,&quot;Developers&quot;]]],&quot;tags&quot;:[1,[[0,&quot;Developers&quot;],[0,&quot;Insights&quot;]]],&quot;contributors&quot;:[1,[[0,&quot;AkashDudeBro&quot;]]],&quot;bannerImage&quot;:[0,{&quot;src&quot;:[0,&quot;/_astro/banner-image.CrYlfTCk.png&quot;],&quot;width&quot;:[0,1024],&quot;height&quot;:[0,532],&quot;format&quot;:[0,&quot;png&quot;],&quot;fsPath&quot;:[0,&quot;/home/runner/work/website/website/src/content/Blog/crypto-101/banner-image.png&quot;]}]}],&quot;render&quot;:[0,null]}],[0,{&quot;id&quot;:[0,&quot;akash-network-partners-with-kava-labs-to-provide-decentralized-hosting-for-the-ka/index.md&quot;],&quot;slug&quot;:[0,&quot;akash-network-partners-with-kava-labs-to-provide-decentralized-hosting-for-the-ka&quot;],&quot;body&quot;:[0,&quot;Akash Network has been selected by Kava Labs as the preferred distributed cloud hosting solution for the Kava Ecosystem.
