And make sure to watch out for future badge announcements!&quot;],&quot;collection&quot;:[0,&quot;Blog&quot;],&quot;data&quot;:[0,{&quot;title&quot;:[0,&quot;Become an Akash Founding Member and Earn Token Rewards&quot;],&quot;description&quot;:[0,&quot;As the world\u2019s first supercloud for serverless computing, Akash needs your support to materialize our vision of empowering the architects and builders of the internet with greater access, freedom, and efficiency to create products that improve the human experience.&quot;],&quot;pubDate&quot;:[3,&quot;2019-11-06T00:00:00.000Z&quot;],&quot;draft&quot;:[0,false],&quot;categories&quot;:[1,[[0,&quot;Community&quot;]]],&quot;tags&quot;:[1,[[0,&quot;Community&quot;]]],&quot;contributors&quot;:[1,[[0,&quot;Maly Ly&quot;]]],&quot;bannerImage&quot;:[0,{&quot;src&quot;:[0,&quot;/_astro/banner-image.Bhofo2Ng.jpg&quot;],&quot;width&quot;:[0,1509],&quot;height&quot;:[0,1097],&quot;format&quot;:[0,&quot;jpg&quot;],&quot;fsPath&quot;:[0,&quot;/home/runner/work/website/website/src/content/Blog/become-and-akash-founding-member-and-earn-token-rewards/banner-image.jpg&quot;]}]}],&quot;render&quot;:[0,null]}],[0,{&quot;id&quot;:[0,&quot;akash-network-validator-rewards/index.md&quot;],&quot;slug&quot;:[0,&quot;akash-network-validator-rewards&quot;],&quot;body&quot;:[0,&quot;\\nAkash employs a blockchain secured by a&nbsp;*Proof-of-Stake*&nbsp;consensus model, managed by 128 independent&nbsp;*Validators.*&nbsp;Validators perform the vital role of providing economic security to the Akash blockchain.&nbsp; To participate, validators \u2018stake\u2019 Akash tokens (AKT). AKT has three primary functions.\\n\\n1.&nbsp;**Resolve:**&nbsp;Akash relies on a blockchain where a group of validators vote on proposals. Each proposal is weighed by the proposer\u2019s voting power, which is the total tokens they staked and the tokens bonded to them (anyone can delegate their stakes voting power to validators).\\n\\n2.&nbsp;**Reward:**&nbsp;Providers on Akash stake tokens to subsidize operating and capital expenditures. Stakers are rewarded proportional to the number of tokens staked, the length of lockup time, and the overall tokens staked in the system. Lock up times can vary anywhere from one month to one year.\\n\\n**3\\\\. Reserve:**&nbsp;Fees on Akash can be settled using a multitude of currencies, however, the market order book uses Akash Token (AKT) as the reserve currency of the ecosystem. AKT provides a novel settlement option to lock in an exchange rate between AKT and the settlement currency. This way, providers and tenants are protected from the price volatility of AKT expected to result from its low liquidity.\\n\\n### **Income Sources (Earnings)**\\n\\n![](https://www.datocms-assets.com/45776/1620922421-annual-inflation-1.png)\\n\\nAnnual inflation over the years when tokens are locked with long and short commitments\\n\\nUnder certain network conditions, a validator can earn anywhere between 56% APR to 176.5% APR depending on tokens locked up, time committed, and various mining strategies (liquidate mining compensation or re-stake mining compensation). The high inflation reaches asymptotically to zero in 10 years.\\n\\nThe implicit value of AKT depends on its earning potential from the below income sources:\\n\\n**1\\\\. Transaction Fees:**&nbsp;Every transaction on the blockchain is subject to a small fee (gas fee). A typical deployment takes ~10 transactions. See the&nbsp;[design spec](https://akash.network/docs/overview/design#transactions)&nbsp;for details.\\n\\n**2\\\\. Make (selling compute) and Take (buying computing) Fees:**&nbsp;Every trade on Akash is subject to maker and taker fee. (Sec 5.D in&nbsp;[Economics paper](https://akash.network/static/akash-econ.pdf)).\\n\\n**3\\\\. Commission:**&nbsp;Akash\u2019s blockchain allows for 128 validators in the first year (that\u2019ll increase to 442 in 10 yrs). Validators charge a commission to delegators (Sec 3 in&nbsp;[Economics paper](https://akash.network/static/akash-econ.pdf)). Check out the&nbsp;[Cosmos commission rates](https://www.mintscan.io/validators)&nbsp;to get an idea. The fee structure is fully governed by validators and subject to change if the community votes to change it.\\n\\n### **Network Demand**\\n\\nThe earnings are proportional to marketplace activity, naturally depends on sufficient demand-supply equilibrium. Initially, we use inflation to bootstrap supply in our marketplace by borrowing from the future ([more on bootstrapping supply in a 2-sided marketplace framework here](https://akash.network/blog/bootstrapping-a-free-market-by-borrowing-from-the-future/)).\\n\\nWhen there is not sufficient demand, we use inflation to reward participation. We solve the supply problem by bootstrapping organic demand from the market that creates an attractive incentive for buyers \u2014 up to 10x lower cost than market in early stages.\\n\\nThis is extremely attractive to cost-sensitive applications such as Machine learning.\\n\\n### **The Journey Ahead**\\n\\nOur current focus partnering with validators to secure the Akash Network blockchain and to grow our community of builders. If you\u2019re a validator, or interested in becoming one, please reach out!\\n\\n[**Find Out More About Akash\u2019s Validator Program**](https://akash.network/validators)\\n\\n### Join Us to Build the Future of the Cloud!\\n\\nRiot:&nbsp;[https://akash.network/chat](https://akash.network/chat)\\n\\nTelegram:&nbsp;[https://t.me/AkashNW](https://t.me/AkashNW)\\n\\nTwitter:&nbsp;[https://twitter.com/akashnet](https://twitter.com/akashnet_)\\n\\nGithub:&nbsp;[https://github.com/ovrclk](https://github.com/ovrclk)\\n&quot;],&quot;collection&quot;:[0,&quot;Blog&quot;],&quot;data&quot;:[0,{&quot;title&quot;:[0,&quot;Akash Network Validator Rewards&quot;],&quot;description&quot;:[0,&quot;Akash employs a blockchain secured by a&nbsp;Proof-of-Stake&nbsp;consensus model, managed by 128 independent&nbsp;Validators.&nbsp;Validators perform the vital role of providing economic security to the Akash blockchain. To participate, validators \u2018stake\u2019 Akash tokens (AKT).&quot;],&quot;pubDate&quot;:[3,&quot;2019-10-31T00:00:00.000Z&quot;],&quot;draft&quot;:[0,false],&quot;categories&quot;:[1,[[0,&quot;Community&quot;]]],&quot;tags&quot;:[1,[[0,&quot;Community&quot;]]],&quot;contributors&quot;:[1,[[0,&quot;Greg Osuri&quot;]]],&quot;bannerImage&quot;:[0,{&quot;src&quot;:[0,&quot;/_astro/banner-image.DjA_A-Qd.jpg&quot;],&quot;width&quot;:[0,1356],&quot;height&quot;:[0,986],&quot;format&quot;:[0,&quot;jpg&quot;],&quot;fsPath&quot;:[0,&quot;/home/runner/work/website/website/src/content/Blog/akash-network-validator-rewards/banner-image.jpeg&quot;]}]}],&quot;render&quot;:[0,null]}],[0,{&quot;id&quot;:[0,&quot;decentralized-serverless-computing-coming-to-cosmos/index.md&quot;],&quot;slug&quot;:[0,&quot;decentralized-serverless-computing-coming-to-cosmos&quot;],&quot;body&quot;:[0,&quot;In a market expected to exceed $198 billion by 2024, the leading cloud providers\u2013Amazon Web Services (AWS), Google Cloud, and Microsoft Azure\u2013dominate the market with 56% market share, and this figure is expected to increase. This accelerated growth is tied to increased consumer demand for throughput and content, a global surge of smartphones, rapid development of web and mobile applications, and high costs of DevOps for on-premise server management.\\n\\nCurrent services are inflexible and come at a high recurring cost with lock-in agreements. Outside of the large incumbent providers, organizations do not have many options for cloud computing. With an estimated 85% of server capacity underutilized and accelerated global demand for cloud computing, there is a critical need for flexibility, cost management, and automation. The cloud needs to evolve to a more distributed and decentralized infrastructure for greater flexibility, efficiency, and security.\\n\\nIn parallel, new innovations such as serverless technology is a paradigm shift in computing, freeing developers from set-up and server management, and enabling them to manage the resources needed to run applications.\\n\\nAs the Cosmos hub continues to grow and attract a diverse set of developers, we see the increasing need for simplicity and flexibility that serverless computing brings and a decentralized infrastructure that supports this growth.\\n\\nThat\u2019s why&nbsp;[Akash](https://akash.network/)&nbsp;is bringing serverless computing to&nbsp;[Cosmos](https://hub.cosmos.network/), and better enabling the builders of today and tomorrow. Akash is the world\u2019s first peer-to-peer supercloud for serverless computing, offering developers an open, permissionless, and secure marketplace for unused compute cycles.\\n\\nOn Akash, anyone with a computer can become a cloud provider by offering their unused compute cycles in a safe and frictionless marketplace.\\n\\nThrough Akash\u2019s platform, developers can easily and securely access cloud compute at 10x lower cost than the current market providers (AWS, Google Cloud, and Microsoft Azure). The platform achieves these benefits by integrating advanced&nbsp;[containerization](https://techcrunch.com/2017/11/21/overclock-labs-bets-on-kubernetes-to-help-companies-automate-their-cloud-infrastructure/)&nbsp;technology with a unique staking model to accelerate adoption, built on Tendermint and Cosmos.\\n\\n### **Akash <3s Cosmos**\\n\\n[Tendermint](https://tendermint.com/)&nbsp;attracted us because of its flexibility as a library with a modular and pragmatic design. We chose to build on Tendermint because of its iteration speed and community momentum. As a Go library, it was a natural fit in our&nbsp;[stack](https://github.com/ovrclk).\\n\\nWe\u2019re drawn to innovations that enable us to iterate and deploy quickly and without friction, and that enable us to increase efficiency. We made a bet on&nbsp;[kubernetes](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Z-JSQpScYck&amp;t=4s)&nbsp;in 2014 and now 80% of the cloud is deployed on kubernetes. We made a bet on Cosmos SDK in&nbsp;[2018](https://github.com/ovrclk/akash/commit/ce720c089ad2f33408abe32ac514a29a81f6a3c1)&nbsp;and it\u2019s exciting to see its continued rapid growth and adoption.\\n\\nOur economic model is built on the foundation laid down by Cosmos. We\u2019ve developed a serverless cloud that is the most interoperable to date. Akash serves as a gateway for developers to leverage and connect with other decentralized services, such as&nbsp;[NuCypher](https://www.nucypher.com/)&nbsp;for key management,&nbsp;[Storj](https://storj.io/)&nbsp;for cloud storage, and&nbsp;[Handshake](https://handshake.org/)&nbsp;for domain name services, with the least amount of friction possible.&nbsp;\\n\\nThe way it works is simple:\\n\\n1.  Developers define their needs in a&nbsp;[simple contract language called SDL](https://github.com/ovrclk/akash/tree/master/sdl).\\n    \\n2.  They place an order on the marketplace for which the providers bid for workloads, thereby guaranteeing the lowest price possible and this pricing happens using a native token, the AKT.&nbsp;\\n    \\n\\nOnce a lease is created, deployments happen automatically and settlement happens using a multi-token mechanism \u2013 we accept different tokens for fee settlement. For example, if you use NuCypher with Akash Network, you can pay using Bitcoin and have it swapped for NU without any effort on your end.\\n\\nFor the Cosmos community, we provide a production-ready&nbsp;[open-source stack](https://github.com/ovrclk/stack)&nbsp;for bare metal. We recently open-sourced Akash Stack, a secure, scalable, and standardized software stack for developing, delivering, and debugging decentralized networks. We are exploring future payment support for stablecoins.\\n\\n### **The Akash Token (AKT)**&nbsp;\\n\\nThe Akash Token (AKT) performs three main functions,&nbsp;_Resolve_,&nbsp;_Reward_, and&nbsp;_Reserve_:\\n\\nThe AKT token is used to achieve economic security, incentivize early adoption, and normalize exchange rates.&nbsp;&nbsp;\\n\\n**Resolve:**&nbsp;For governance, Akash relies on a blockchain where a set of validators vote on proposals. Each proposal is weighed by the proposer\u2019s voting power, which is the total tokens they staked and the tokens bonded to them (stakers can delegate voting power to validators).&nbsp;\\n\\n**Reward:**&nbsp;Providers on Akash stake tokens to subsidize operating and capital expenditures. Stakers are rewarded proportional to the number of tokens staked, the length of lockup time, and the overall tokens staked in the system. Lock up times can vary anywhere from one month to one year. Flexibility in lockup encourages stakers that stake for shorter periods (bear markets), in a self-adjusting inflationary system that is designed to optimize for lower price pressure during bear markets.\\n\\n**Reserve:**&nbsp;Fees on Akash can be settled using a multitude of currencies, however, the market order book uses Akash Token (AKT) as the reserve currency of the ecosystem. AKT provides a novel settlement option to lock in an exchange rate between AKT and the settlement currency. This way, providers and tenants are protected from the price volatility of AKT expected to result from its low liquidity.\\n\\n### **The Journey Ahead**\\n\\nOur current focus is to partner with great validators to secure the Akash Network blockchain and to grow our community of builders and developers.\\n\\nIf you\u2019re a validator, or interested in becoming one, find out how you can earn 56% APR to 176% depending on AKT\u2019s locked up, trade factor and lockup time.\\n\\n[Find Out More About Akash\u2019s Validator Program](https://akash.network/validators)\\n\\n### **Join Us to Build the Future of the Cloud!**\\n\\n**Riot:**&nbsp;[**https://akash.network/chat**](https://akash.network/chat)\\n\\n**Telegram:**&nbsp;[**https://t.me/AkashNW**](https://t.me/AkashNW)\\n\\n**Twitter:**&nbsp;[**https://twitter.com/akashnet\\\\_**](https://twitter.com/akashnet_)\\n\\n**Github:**&nbsp;[**https://github.com/ovrclk**](https://github.com/ovrclk)&quot;],&quot;collection&quot;:[0,&quot;Blog&quot;],&quot;data&quot;:[0,{&quot;title&quot;:[0,&quot;Decentralized Serverless Computing Coming to Cosmos&quot;],&quot;description&quot;:[0,&quot;In a market expected to exceed $198 billion by 2024, the leading cloud providers\u2013Amazon Web Services (AWS), Google Cloud, and Microsoft Azure\u2013dominate the market with 56% market share, and this figure is expected to increase. This accelerated growth is tied to increased consumer demand for throughput and content, a global surge of smartphones, rapid development of web and mobile applications, and high costs of DevOps for on-premise server management.&quot;],&quot;pubDate&quot;:[3,&quot;2019-10-23T00:00:00.000Z&quot;],&quot;draft&quot;:[0,false],&quot;categories&quot;:[1,[[0,&quot;News&quot;]]],&quot;tags&quot;:[1,[[0,&quot;News&quot;],[0,&quot;Product&quot;]]],&quot;contributors&quot;:[1,[[0,&quot;Greg Osuri&quot;]]],&quot;bannerImage&quot;:[0,{&quot;src&quot;:[0,&quot;/_astro/banner-image.BYg_B_Wz.jpg&quot;],&quot;width&quot;:[0,1780],&quot;height&quot;:[0,720],&quot;format&quot;:[0,&quot;jpg&quot;],&quot;fsPath&quot;:[0,&quot;/home/runner/work/website/website/src/content/Blog/decentralized-serverless-computing-coming-to-cosmos/banner-image.jpg&quot;]}]}],&quot;render&quot;:[0,null]}],[0,{&quot;id&quot;:[0,&quot;bootstrapping-a-free-market-by-borrowing-from-the-future/index.md&quot;],&quot;slug&quot;:[0,&quot;bootstrapping-a-free-market-by-borrowing-from-the-future&quot;],&quot;body&quot;:[0,&quot;The survival of an early market economy depends on its ability to solve the cyclical dependency of demand and supply until a healthy equilibrium can be achieved to unlock its network effects.  \\n\\nBy solving for either side of the equation, we can create the right conditions to achieve equilibrium.&nbsp; Our goal with this article is to share our learnings by providing a framework for bootstrapping marketplaces in any industry challenged with underutilization of resources; and we achieve this by rewarding sellers for network contribution, enabling the creation of incentives to attract buyers.  \\n\\nA True Free Market\\n------------------\\n\\nA free market is a system in which the prices for goods and services are determined by the open market and by consumers. In a free market, the prices for goods and services are set freely by the forces of supply and demand and reach their point of equilibrium without intervention by external forces.&nbsp;  \\n\\n> \u2026the obvious and simple system of natural liberty establishes itself of its own accord. Every man\u2026is left perfectly free to pursue his own interest in his own way\u2026. The sovereign is completely discharged from a duty \\\\[for which\\\\] no human wisdom or knowledge could ever be sufficient; the duty of superintending the industry of private people, and of directing it towards the employments most suitable to the interest of the society\\n\\n\\\\-- Adam Smith, The Wealth Of Nations, Book IV, Chapter IX\\n\\n  \\nFor a market that relies on network effects to unlock value, it\u2019s critical to sustain demand or supply until equilibrium is achieved. We\u2019ll present a model where an inflationary system is leveraged to create the effects of liquidity (counterparties at a reasonable price) and bootstrap demand.  \\n\\nFor a truly free market to be possible, it\u2019s critical that the market remains permissionless and self-sovereign with an open ecosystem or risk&nbsp;[market-failure](https://courses.cit.cornell.edu/econ335/out/bator_qje.pdf).  \\n\\n1.  **Permissionless**: Participation does not require anyone\u2019s permission.\\n    \\n2.  **Self-Sovereign**: The price of goods and services is driven purely by market forces and not external forces. Monetary policy that dictates the value of the currency used in the market should be determined by its stakeholders and not external forces.\\n    \\n3.  **Open Ecosystem**: The incentives are distributed fairly to all the participants in the market so they benefit from the prosperity of the market.&nbsp;  \\n    \\n\\n  \\nBackground\\n-------------\\n\\nThis article is derived from&nbsp;[Akash\u2019s Economic Model](https://blog.akash.network/2019/09/25/akash-network-economics). Akash is a permissionless, open, and secure marketplace to trade unused compute cycles.&nbsp;  \\n\\nAkash\u2019s interoperability layer radically simplifies integration with decentralized cloud networks, such as&nbsp;[NuCypher](https://www.nucypher.com/),&nbsp;[Storj](https://storj.io/), and&nbsp;[Handshake](https://handshake.org/). Each of these systems performs a unique function in an overall solution for a decentralized application.  \\n\\nTo enable a friction-free exchange of value and provide more liquidity, which is essential for automation, Akash enables transacting in a multitude of currencies such as BTC, XRP, ATOM.&nbsp;  \\n\\nThe full potential of&nbsp;[Akash Network](https://akash.network/)&nbsp;is unlocked when the system reaches economies of scale. Until then, Akash has to not only sustain supply but also offer compelling incentives to attract buyers. By leveraging this model, Akash is able to offer compute at 10x lower cost than developers are paying in the market \u2014 an extremely attractive value proposition for data-intensive applications.  \\n\\n  \\nEconomic Security by Monetary Sovereignty\\n--------------------------------------------\\n\\nIf money is an abstraction that measures value, it\u2019s essential the monetary policy \u2014 that influences the value of money itself \u2014 should act in the best interest of the market it serves.  \\n\\nA native digital currency (token) \u2014&nbsp; whose value is driven purely by market forces \u2014 can provide economic sovereignty when monetary policy is determined by a market\u2019s stakeholders.  \\n\\nBy enabling permissionless commerce without the influence of external forces, a token can be leveraged to establish the economic integrity of the marketplace in low trust environments. Strangers can transact directly with one another without an intermediary (external force) arbitering trust&nbsp; \u2014 truly enabling internet scale.  \\n\\nThis is possible by using a system like Proof-of-Stake (PoS), where the token utility is augmented with the ownership of the network. In a PoS system, the nodes \u201cstake\u201d tokens (collateral) to transact on the blockchain and the chain that represents the majority of the tokens is considered the honest-chain. Each token holds a vote.&nbsp;&nbsp;  \\n\\nFor example, in a PoS algorithm like&nbsp;[Tendermint](https://tendermint.com/docs/introduction/what-is-tendermint.html), anyone can propose to write to the blockchain as long as 2/3rd\u2019s of the validators approve the transaction. A validator\u2019s voting power (weight) is based on the number of tokens they hold (or the number of tokens delegated to them).\\n\\nPoS networks such as&nbsp;[Cosmos](https://cosmos.network/),&nbsp;[Kava](https://www.kava.io/), and&nbsp;[Akash](https://akash.network/)&nbsp;offer on-chain governance models. On-chain governance enables the token holders to have ultimate sovereignty over all aspects of the protocol. The \u201cstake\u201d can also be used as collateral to disincentivize bad behavior.  \\n\\n  \\nSubsidizing Supply using Inflationary Rewards\\n------------------------------------------------\\n\\nThe maintainers of the blockchain can be incentivized using a Proof-of-Stake scheme. The incentives could include mined tokens (by means of inflation) and usage fees collected by the network.  \\n\\nTo sustain the market value of the token and attract sufficient liquidity, the value of the token should be derived from its earning potential. Earning potential could be based on commission or subscription-based models. For example, in Akash, the Akash Token (AKT) holders earn income from transactions and usage fees (make and take).  \\n\\nThe network has to offer value (beyond inflation) to its stakeholders or risk insolvency.&nbsp;  \\n\\nIn the early stages of a market economy, when there is no demand-supply equilibrium,&nbsp; there isn\u2019t sufficient demand to attract supply (which in turn affects the buy-side). To solve such a cyclic dependency, the seller can be incentivized for their contribution to the network, in addition to earning income from selling goods in the market.  \\n\\nThe seller earns income regardless of demand. When that additional income can generate expected margins (as when goods are sold), the seller can offer goods at an exponentially lower cost without sacrificing margins to attract demand.&nbsp;  \\n\\nBy effectively de-risking seller participation, we can offer a highly compelling value proposition to attract buyers.  \\n\\nRewards based on contribution\\n-----------------------------\\n\\nSince staking provides economic security to the chain (a critical function of the network) anyone who stakes tokens is eligible to receive a share of the overall income. To encourage long-term participation, stakers who commit to longer terms receive a high portion of the reward compared to stakers who commit to short terms.  \\n\\nAs a primary objective to ensure supply, a staker\u2019s compensation also depends on the supply they commit to the network. Stakers who sell goods or services receive more income than stakers who are not selling but contributing to economic security.  \\n\\nFor example, in Akash, a staker can earn anywhere from 56% APR to 176.5% APR depending on tokens locked up, time committed, and various mining strategies (liquidate mining compensation or re-stake mining compensation).  \\n\\nIn summary, a staker\u2019s contribution is measured by:&nbsp;\\n\\n*   **Locked Tokens**: the number of tokens they stake.&nbsp;\\n    \\n*   **Trade Factor**: the amount of goods they sell.&nbsp;\\n    \\n*   **Lockup Time**: how long they\u2019re committed to the network.\\n    \\n\\nThe income generated by the network (staking rewards and usage fees) goes into a pool which is distributed to the miners based on their contribution factor.  \\n\\n  \\nA Self Regulating Inflation System\\n-------------------------------------\\n\\nSince the goal of the inflation system is to bootstrap the market until a healthy economic equilibrium can be achieved, the inflation rate should asymptotically reach zero on reaching this threshold. The time it takes to reach zero-inflation is variable, as it depends on inflation at a given time. Higher inflation means it\u2019ll take less time to reach zero.&nbsp;  \\n\\nThe inflation rate also depends on lock-up times. Shorter lockup times lead to lower inflation. A self-adjusting inflation rate based on time commitment is critical to providing adequate price-support. In bear markets, when stakers commit for shorter time frames, a lower inflation rate leads to less price pressure. The initial inflation rate should be determined by the desired growth rate of the network. A self-regulating inflation rate based on performance ensures a healthy market value for the token.&nbsp;  \\n\\n![](https://www.datocms-assets.com/45776/1620922422-annual-inflation.png)\\n\\nAnnual inflation over the years when tokens are locked with long and short commitments\\n\\nIn Akash, initial inflation is expected to be 100% APR (with an assumption of 60% of lockup for a year) and asymptotically reaches zero in approximately ten years. Under these conditions, a compute provider offering a server rack is able to generate an income of $790,294 with a net profit of $166,777 in three years by staking $207,972 without having to sell any capacity.&nbsp;  \\n  \\n\\nEffects of Liquidity\\n--------------------\\n\\nA model that grows with inflation relies on attracting sufficient liquidity for the token to retain meaningful value for facilitating trade. the market value of the token is determined by investors speculating on the future earning potential of the token, and the system needs to incentivize investors (speculators) to buy-in.  \\n\\nThis system also minimizes the concentration of wealth \u2013&nbsp; any non-functioning tokens that do not contribute to the essential functions of the ecosystem are taxed by means of inflation. This ensures the efficiency of the economy and discourages pure speculators who hold on to tokens for self-gain without making any meaningful contributions to the prosperity of the network.  \\n\\nIn Akash Network, the Akash Token (AKT)&nbsp; is specifically designed to achieve economic security, incentivize early adoption, and normalize exchange rates. Any AKT not involved in the intended use cases risk dilution of value, given market capitalization remains stable. The fees may be settled in a multitude of tokens, including AKT. AKT holders, however, are discouraged from using it for settlement considering its illiquid nature.  \\n\\n  \\nConclusion\\n-------------\\n\\nAt Akash, we believe that by using the power of a free market, we can unlock 85% of capacity in 8.4 million data centers currently underutilized today. We created the tools to activate an incentive structure that not only fairly distributes but will unlock network effects to accelerate growth.  \\n\\nPlease&nbsp;[subscribe to our newsletter](https://akash.network/newsletter)&nbsp;to stay informed on future articles that might interest you.&nbsp; Also, find us in our&nbsp;[community](https://akash.network/community)&nbsp;if you\u2019d like to continue the conversation.&quot;],&quot;collection&quot;:[0,&quot;Blog&quot;],&quot;data&quot;:[0,{&quot;title&quot;:[0,&quot;Bootstrapping a Free Market by Borrowing from the Future&quot;],&quot;description&quot;:[0,&quot;The survival of an early market economy depends on its ability to solve the cyclical dependency of demand and supply until a healthy equilibrium can be achieved to unlock its network effects.&quot;],&quot;pubDate&quot;:[3,&quot;2019-10-07T00:00:00.000Z&quot;],&quot;draft&quot;:[0,false],&quot;categories&quot;:[1,[[0,&quot;Insights&quot;]]],&quot;tags&quot;:[1,[[0,&quot;Insights&quot;]]],&quot;contributors&quot;:[1,[[0,&quot;Greg Osuri&quot;]]],&quot;bannerImage&quot;:[0,{&quot;src&quot;:[0,&quot;/_astro/banner-image.CsLKPbu0.png&quot;],&quot;width&quot;:[0,1568],&quot;height&quot;:[0,915],&quot;format&quot;:[0,&quot;png&quot;],&quot;fsPath&quot;:[0,&quot;/home/runner/work/website/website/src/content/Blog/bootstrapping-a-free-market-by-borrowing-from-the-future/banner-image.png&quot;]}]}],&quot;render&quot;:[0,null]}],[0,{&quot;id&quot;:[0,&quot;the-economics-of-akash-network-and-token/index.md&quot;],&quot;slug&quot;:[0,&quot;the-economics-of-akash-network-and-token&quot;],&quot;body&quot;:[0,&quot;With 8.4 million data centers, an estimated 85% of server capacity underutilized, and accelerated global demand for cloud computing, Akash aims to create efficiencies in the cloud hosting market through algorithms for allocating compute resources that go to waste in the current market.\\n\\nThe leading three providers \u2014 Amazon Web Services (AWS), Google Cloud, and Microsoft Azure \u2014 dominate the cloud computing market with 56% market share and this figure is expected to increase. These providers are complicated, inflexible, and restrictive, and come at a high recurring cost with lock-in agreements. Outside of the large incumbent providers, organizations do not have many options for cloud computing.\\n\\nAkash is the&nbsp;_world\u2019s first and only supercloud for serverless computing_, enabling anyone with a computer to become a cloud provider by offering their unused compute cycles in a safe and frictionless marketplace.\\n\\nAt Akash, we believe that for a system to reach (or exceed) the scale of the internet, the system has to improve upon the foundational principles of the internet while solving the apparent inefficiencies inadvertently introduced. So we designed Akash to be an open ecosystem that is censorship-resistant and self-sovereign:\\n\\n*   **Censorship resistant**: Your information is safe and can\u2019t be tampered with (permissionless).\\n    \\n*   **Self-sovereign**: You own and control your assets, identity, and data. Akash is built on a globally consistent state machine (blockchain), publicly maintained and governed by its stakeholders.\\n    \\n*   **Open ecosystem:**&nbsp;Everyone gets value from new contributions. The state being a shared resource, its maintainers (validators that provide economic security) earn income from transaction fees. Providers\u2019 costs are subsidized (for under-utilization) using block rewards, and users get to compute at an exponentially greater capacity at the same cost they were paying before.\\n    \\n\\n[We\u2019re excited to release the economic model for Akash](https://akash.network/l/econ-paper). In this paper, we present an economic system that uses a native currency to solve for volatility (one of the biggest challenges for adoption in crypto) while ensuring economic security of our public blockchain. We also present various strategies to mitigate inherent adoption challenges that face an early market economy \u2014 lack of sufficient demand from the tenants (consumers of computing), which in turn hurts demand because of lack of supply. This is a model that can be applied to any marketplace to bootstrap early supply by subsidizing using inflation (i.e., borrowing from the future).\\n\\nAkash Token (AKT): Resolve, Reward, and Reserve\\n-----------------------------------------------\\n\\nThe Akash Token (AKT) performs three main functions:&nbsp;_Resolve_,&nbsp;_Reward_, and&nbsp;_Reserve_.\\n\\n### **Resolve**\\n\\nAkash relies on a blockchain where a set of validators vote on proposals. Each proposal is weighed by the proposer\u2019s voting power, which is the total tokens they staked and the tokens bonded to them (stakers can delegate voting power to validators).&nbsp;\\n\\n### **Reward**\\n\\nProviders on Akash stake tokens to subsidize operating and capital expenditures. Stakers are rewarded proportional to the number of tokens staked, the length of lockup time, and the overall tokens staked in the system. Lock up times can vary anywhere from one month to one year. Flexibility in lockup encourages stakers that stake for shorter periods (bear markets), in a self-adjusting inflationary system that is designed to optimize for lower price pressure during bear markets.\\n\\n### **Reserve**\\n\\nFees on Akash can be settled using a multitude of currencies, however, the market order book uses Akash Token (AKT) as the reserve currency of the ecosystem. AKT provides a novel settlement option to lock in an exchange rate between AKT and the settlement currency. This way, providers and tenants are protected from the price volatility of AKT expected to result from its low liquidity. This paper also presents a method \u201cTransaction Ordering using Consensus Weighted Median\u201d to establish exchange rates without the need for an oracle.  \\n  \\n  \\n**.:**&nbsp;[**Download The Akash Network Token Economic Model to Learn More**](https://akash.network/l/econ-paper)&nbsp;**:.**&quot;],&quot;collection&quot;:[0,&quot;Blog&quot;],&quot;data&quot;:[0,{&quot;title&quot;:[0,&quot;The Economics of Akash Network and Token&quot;],&quot;description&quot;:[0,&quot;With 8.4 million data centers, an estimated 85% of server capacity underutilized, and accelerated global demand for cloud computing, Akash aims to create efficiencies in the cloud hosting market through algorithms for allocating compute resources that go to waste in the current market.&quot;],&quot;pubDate&quot;:[3,&quot;2019-09-16T00:00:00.000Z&quot;],&quot;draft&quot;:[0,false],&quot;categories&quot;:[1,[[0,&quot;Insights&quot;]]],&quot;tags&quot;:[1,[[0,&quot;Insights&quot;]]],&quot;contributors&quot;:[1,[[0,&quot;Greg Osuri&quot;]]],&quot;bannerImage&quot;:[0,{&quot;src&quot;:[0,&quot;/_astro/banner-image.GSt_NTsm.png&quot;],&quot;width&quot;:[0,500],&quot;height&quot;:[0,359],&quot;format&quot;:[0,&quot;png&quot;],&quot;fsPath&quot;:[0,&quot;/home/runner/work/website/website/src/content/Blog/the-economics-of-akash-network-and-token/banner-image.png&quot;]}]}],&quot;render&quot;:[0,null]}],[0,{&quot;id&quot;:[0,&quot;akash-vs-the-grid/index.md&quot;],&quot;slug&quot;:[0,&quot;akash-vs-the-grid&quot;],&quot;body&quot;:[0,&quot;\\nAt Akash, we do quite a bit of&nbsp;[thinking](https://docsend.com/view/yvgseww),&nbsp;[writing](https://hackernoon.com/decentralized-infrastructure-is-a-moral-imperative-2ec13dc3138d), and&nbsp;[presenting](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=JUGjvs6IsrU)&nbsp;on decentralized infrastructure. It\u2019s our business after all \u2013 Akash is a decentralized marketplace and deployment platform for cloud compute. &nbsp;Using The Akash Network, companies make slack server capacity in their colo and on-prem datacenters available for containerized deployment. As a result, Akash-connected datacenters form a decentralized network of compute providers as an alternative to the hyperscale providers that currently dominate the cloud infrastructure market.\\n\\nWe\u2019re not the only game in town though; several other projects are dedicated to bringing decentralized or distributed compute power to users. &nbsp;And to be clear, we see this as a very&nbsp;[good thing](https://memegenerator.net/img/instances/60763191/its-a-good-thing.jpg)&nbsp;indeed. &nbsp;Compute is an essential commodity and the world needs a healthy ecosystem of platforms that allow it to be traded quickly, freely and transparently. This article compares Akash with those other projects and attempts to draw relevant distinctions.\\n\\n### **The Grid Projects: Apples and Oranges**\\n\\nOther players in the decentralized compute space include DFINITY, Golem, 0chain, iExec, SONM, and Hypernet. We will consider them as a group \u2013 let\u2019s call them the Grid Projects \u2013 since they all have a similar approach to aggregating compute power. &nbsp;If you\u2019re interested in specific differences among the Grid Projects, check out&nbsp;[this post](https://medium.com/@hypernet/how-hypernet-compares-to-golem-sonm-iexec-etc-d5aec79e51d6)&nbsp;or maybe&nbsp;[this post](https://themerkle.com/iexec-vs-golem-vs-sonm/)&nbsp;or even&nbsp;[this thread](https://www.reddit.com/r/GolemProject/comments/7kmqx2/is_iexec_a_direct_competitor_of_golem/)&nbsp;because&nbsp;**those differences aren\u2019t relevant**&nbsp;to a comparison with Akash. Why aren\u2019t those differences relevant? &nbsp;Because Akash\u2019s approach is fundamentally different, so it ends up being an&nbsp;[apples-to-oranges comparison](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Apples_and_oranges).\\n\\n### **How Akash is Different**\\n\\nEach of the Grid Projects implements a particular variation of a single theme: Grid Computing. &nbsp;In a grid compute model, many devices are connected to form a single \u201cvirtual supercomputer\u201d that is optimal for running&nbsp;**highly parallelizable, short-term batch jobs**&nbsp;like CGI rendering, financial modeling, or DNA sequencing. In some cases, the Grid Projects\u2019 compute occurs on-chain and in some it\u2019s off-chain, but in all cases they require an application to be implemented specifically to run on this single virtual supercomputer.\\n\\nThe Akash Network is fundamentally different because it uses generic compute resources to host Docker containers in which&nbsp;**any cloud workload**&nbsp;can run. &nbsp;Short-term batch jobs like CI/CD pipelines, ETL or Spark jobs? &nbsp;Yep. Long-term workloads like web stacks, application servers, queues, or (this is important) databases? &nbsp;Also yep. Any workload that can run in containers on AWS, GCP, Azure, or your own hardware can be run on Akash without rewriting it to run on a supercomputer. Akash also differs in that users have access to block storage on the servers running its containers. The Grid Projects either only offer compute with no storage at all or object storage \u2013 useful for storing large amounts of unstructured data but not for applications or databases.\\n\\n### **Enter the Blockchain**\\n\\nAnother critical difference between Akash and the Grid Projects is in the use of blockchain. &nbsp;Each of the Grid Projects approaches it slightly differently, but all of them perform compute tasks on chain and so all of them are bound by the performance of their blockchains. &nbsp;And some solve this performance problem better than others.\\n\\nAkash, on the other hand, uses the blockchain to provide an open and transparent marketplace on which generic compute resources are traded. In other words, space on a server is bought and sold on chain, while deployment is off chain in Docker containers, orchestrated by Kubernetes, residing on specific servers, within datacenters with user-specified characteristics such as region, cross-connections, certification level, end-user latency, reputation, and provider identity.\\n\\nAkash\u2019s blockchain marketplace also provides a significant price advantage because each workload is bid on by all providers willing and capable to host it. &nbsp;This auction process is visible to all and the resulting competition will provide downward pressure on prices charged by all providers. Since today\u2019s IaaS providers currently&nbsp;[bring in about US$45B per year](https://www.gartner.com/newsroom/id/3815165), all cloud use cases bring in in over US$300B, and the IaaS market is growing at 36%YoY, we believe there is plenty of room for price relief.\\n\\n## **In Summary**\\n\\nThe world needs supercomputers to run batch jobs to solve complex computational problems and the Grid Providers bring this power to the world. So if you need a supercomputer, check them out.\\n\\nHowever, most compute workloads are not complex computational problems that demand supercomputing resources. &nbsp;They\u2019re applications, databases, and batch jobs managed by overworked DevOps engineers with a budget. So if you need to run your enterprise workload on the provider you choose, at a price you want, using familiar and time-tested tooling, check out&nbsp;[Akash](https://akash.network/).\\n&quot;],&quot;collection&quot;:[0,&quot;Blog&quot;],&quot;data&quot;:[0,{&quot;title&quot;:[0,&quot;Akash vs The Grid&quot;],&quot;description&quot;:[0,&quot;At Akash, we do quite a bit of&nbsp;thinking,writing, and&nbsp;presenting&nbsp;on decentralized infrastructure. Regulators need tools that only legislators can provide.\\n\\nNo question blockchain is going to rival the web, and its essential innovation doesn\u2019t leave this country. As a community, we think it is vital to provide the tools necessary for regulators and as part of our continued commitment to the eco-system, I testified as an expert witness for the first ever blockchain bill ([AB 2658](https://leginfo.legislature.ca.gov/faces/billTextClient.xhtml?bill_id=201720180AB2658)) introduced in California.\\n\\nI\u2019m excited to announce the Assembly Committee on Privacy, and Consumer Protection has unanimously passed AB 2658; this is a small step but an essential first step. Below is the full draft of my testimony.\\n\\n> My name is Gangadharam Osuri. I\u2019m the co-founder and CEO of Overclock Labs. Our Akash network is a blockchain-based, open marketplace for cloud computing services. We\u2019re in support of AB 2658.\\n> \\n> I\u2019d like to thank Majority Leader Calderon, Chairman Chau, Vice-Chairman Kiley and the rest of the Committee for its attention to this important area of technological development.\\n> \\n> Blockchain technology is in its infancy, but its potential impact on and benefits for commerce rivals that of the world wide web itself. &nbsp;And as with web technology, California is at the forefront of innovation. We\u2019re grateful to the legislature for its leadership in protecting and educating consumers as this innovation proceeds at ever-increasing speed.\\n> \\n> In my opinion, expanding UETA\u2019s definitions of \u201celectronic record\u201d and \u201celectronic signature\u201d to include a record or a signature that is secured through blockchain technology is a no-brainer. Why? Because blockchain is inherently immutable and auditable. In other words, once a record is written to a blockchain, it is there forever; it cannot be altered, and it is visible to anyone with access to the chain. A blockchain is a database that cannot be hacked.\\n> \\n> Furthermore, security is baked in using cryptography. When I sign a record with my public key, it is unalterably attributed to me on the blockchain. This is because a cryptographic key is actually a pair of keys \u2013 a public key seen by everyone joined mathematically to a private key seen only by me. So a bad actor cannot hack a database to steal my password because my private key never leaves my computer.\\n> \\n> However, I\u2019d suggest caution regarding smart contracts. Written contracts are often difficult to understand, but they\u2019re at least theoretically human-readable. &nbsp;Smart contracts on the other hand are written in computer code. As a professional software engineer, it can be difficult for me to understand someone else\u2019s code, to say nothing of a layperson\u2019s ability to do so. And of course, code often has bugs which cause unintended behavior. As a result, there is a greater risk of a person committing to a smart contract that has provisions they, or even the contract issuer, do not fully understand. In my opinion, legislation regarding smart contracts must consider these important characteristics. So, we support the amendments to the bill.\\n> \\n> Again, I thank the committee for the opportunity to speak and I look forward to collaborating in the future.\\n\\n&nbsp;_Special thanks to @nalesandroakash for helping draft this testimony._&quot;],&quot;collection&quot;:[0,&quot;Blog&quot;],&quot;data&quot;:[0,{&quot;title&quot;:[0,&quot;My testimony as an expert witness for the first ever blockchain bill (AB 2658) introduced in the state of California&quot;],&quot;description&quot;:[0,&quot;The most significant hurdle for blockchain today is legislative as US companies today face an uncertain legal regime. You can learn about Akash to your heart\u2019s content by&nbsp;[visiting our site](https://akash.network/)&nbsp;or&nbsp;[reading our light paper](https://akash.network/paper.pdf)&nbsp;(a friendly version of the traditionally-impenetrable crypto whitepaper), so I\u2019ll dispense with a long description of Akash to focus instead on something more meta:&nbsp;**why**&nbsp;we\u2019re doing this and&nbsp;**how**&nbsp;we\u2019re going to do it.\\n\\n## The Akash&nbsp;tl;dr\\n\\nFirst, in case you didn\u2019t read the whitepaper, here\u2019s&nbsp;**what**&nbsp;we\u2019re doing:\\n\\nOverclock Labs is a company whose projects include the Akash Network. The Akash Network allows companies with idle server capacity (there are a lot of them) to make it available for cloud deployments. Developers who want to deploy to Akash specify their deployment criteria in a declarative file posted to our native blockchain, where it\u2019s picked up and bid on by any provider capable of meeting the criteria. Low bid wins and then the parties move off chain to distribute the workload in Docker containers. Once a workload is live, the agreed-on count of Akash tokens is transferred from the tenant\u2019s wallet to the provider\u2019s wallet on a periodic basis for as long as the workload is live, with all that settlement activity written to chain.\\n\\n## Why Akash?\\n\\nWe\u2019re on a bit of a mission. Today\u2019s cloud infrastructure providers have a real oligopoly, which allows them to charge non-commodity prices for commodity compute,&nbsp;[inhibits real competition](http://www.platformonomics.com/2017/04/follow-the-capex-cloud-table-stakes/), and crowds out open-source projects. We think that\u2019s wrong. Wrong for companies and individuals that use cloud compute; wrong for their customers to whom costs are ultimately passed; and wrong for society as a whole because one of its basic building blocks is controlled by three huge companies.&nbsp;[I wrote about the situation in more depth here](https://blog.akash.network/2018/03/19/decentralized-infrastructure-is-a-moral-issue/).\\n\\n### Distribute then decentralize\\n\\nWhile the current cryptocurrency landscape is&nbsp;[undeniably fascinating](https://youtu.be/e5nyQmaq4k4?t=42s), the real power of blockchain lies in its ability to create a cryptographically-enforced,&nbsp;**distributed**, and open source of truth.&nbsp;[From banking to real estate to voting to identity to file storage and more](https://hackernoon.com/popular-use-cases-of-blockchain-technology-you-need-to-know-df4e1905d373), we\u2019re entering a technological era where \u201ctrusted\u201d (serious quotes around that one) central sources of truth are not always necessary. Central authorities are inherently vulnerable and even corruptible\u200a\u2014\u200abut even when working as designed they\u2019re not always incented to act on behalf of the communities they serve. So public companies are obligated to&nbsp;[maximize shareholder value](https://www.marketwatch.com/story/amazon-is-worth-so-much-because-aws-is-techs-true-unicorn-2017-04-27), not, say, to work toward fairly-priced cloud infrastructure.\\n\\nA distributed approach is perfect for cloud infrastructure because the ideal cloud is&nbsp;**decentralized**, with thousands of globally-distributed points of presence\u200a\u2014\u200away more than the handful of hyperscale datacenters offered by big providers. So how to build and run this ideal cloud?\\n\\nUsing a centralized approach, we\u2019d make a massive capex investment to build out those points of presence. Instead we use the capacity that\u2019s already present in thousands of companies\u2019 on-prem and colo datacenters.\\n\\nUsing a centralized approach, we\u2019d make a massive opex investment to manage, support, collect/distribute revenue, AND assume liability for the network. Instead we use blockchain to connect providers and tenants as peers and to allow direct payments between peers.\\n\\nUsing a centralized approach, we\u2019d make another massive investment of time and resources to build a new brand that users trust with their workloads. Instead we use blockchain to ensure every marketplace transaction is visible to everyone, including payment histories and adverse events\u200a\u2014\u200aso users can trust facts instead of a brand.\\n\\nIn other words, we\u2019re using blockchain\u2019s natural strength as a distributed and open source of truth to facilitate the development of decentralized cloud infrastructure. Not for nothing, this approach also allows a small project like ours to present a credible alternative to the hyperscale, centralized providers.\\n\\n### Transparency\\n\\n[We are indeed living in interesting times](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/May_you_live_in_interesting_times). Technology-driven decentralization will affect the social and political domains in unpredictable ways. Token sale-driven funding models will affect which types of projects become viable and how they grow, again in unpredictable ways. And from a purely technological perspective, blockchain is new and will evolve rapidly and unpredictably, with new capabilities forming a feedback loop with social, political, commercial, and of course&nbsp;[regulatory](https://www.wsj.com/articles/sec-launches-cryptocurrency-probe-1519856266)&nbsp;domains.\\n\\nSo here we are in the&nbsp;[early days of something big](https://www.pcmag.com/article/351486/blockchain-the-invisible-technology-thats-changing-the-wor), and we\u2019re all (yes all of us) pretty much figuring it out as we go. We\u2019re drawing on historical precedents, making mistakes, enjoying successes, and reasoning our way through innumerable issues. And we\u2019re doing all this while working with a technology that is inherently open and transparent. So we, and the organizations we belong to, must also be open and transparent. It\u2019s the right thing to do.\\n\\nIt\u2019s the right thing to do because we learn from one anothers\u2019 mistakes and successes. It\u2019s the right thing to do because admitting you don\u2019t know something opens a path to learning\u200a\u2014\u200aboth for yourself and for those unwilling to admit it. It\u2019s the right thing to do because investors and customers deserve full information to make effective decisions. It\u2019s the right thing to do because the technology demands it. And, at the risk of hyperbole, it\u2019s right because history needs a contemporaneous record of how this all went down.\\n\\nWith this in mind, we\u2019ve made a firm commitment to transparency. The software that drives the Network is still under development, but we\u2019ve open sourced it now.&nbsp;[Follow our progress, warts and all, on GitHub](https://github.com/ovrclk/akash/). We actively communicate with our investors and&nbsp;[make our monthly investor letters public](https://github.com/ovrclk/updates/)&nbsp;(full disclosure, we do sanitize them slightly). And more softly, we\u2019re committed to using direct and plain language in all our communication and equally committed to responsiveness with our&nbsp;[growing telegram community](https://t.me/AkashNW). We\u2019re grateful to other transparent projects in the space and look to them for ways to improve. Let\u2019s make transparency a default expectation\u200a\u2014\u200alet\u2019s be brave!\\n&quot;],&quot;collection&quot;:[0,&quot;Blog&quot;],&quot;data&quot;:[0,{&quot;title&quot;:[0,&quot;Introducing Akash&quot;],&quot;description&quot;:[0,&quot;This week we introduced The Akash Network to the world with a press release and the open sourcing of our software. You can learn about Akash to your heart\u2019s content by&nbsp;visiting our site&nbsp;or&nbsp;reading our light paper&nbsp;(a friendly version of the traditionally-impenetrable crypto whitepaper), so I\u2019ll dispense with a long description of Akash to focus instead on something more meta&quot;],&quot;pubDate&quot;:[3,&quot;2018-03-25T00:00:00.000Z&quot;],&quot;draft&quot;:[0,false],&quot;categories&quot;:[1,[[0,&quot;News&quot;]]],&quot;tags&quot;:[1,[[0,&quot;News&quot;]]],&quot;contributors&quot;:[1,[[0,&quot;Nick Alesandro&quot;]]],&quot;bannerImage&quot;:[0,{&quot;src&quot;:[0,&quot;/_astro/banner-image.zqgur--L.jpg&quot;],&quot;width&quot;:[0,1779],&quot;height&quot;:[0,720],&quot;format&quot;:[0,&quot;jpg&quot;],&quot;fsPath&quot;:[0,&quot;/home/runner/work/website/website/src/content/Blog/introducing-akash/banner-image.jpg&quot;]}]}],&quot;render&quot;:[0,null]}],[0,{&quot;id&quot;:[0,&quot;decentralized-infrastructure-is-a-moral-imperative/index.md&quot;],&quot;slug&quot;:[0,&quot;decentralized-infrastructure-is-a-moral-imperative&quot;],&quot;body&quot;:[0,&quot;As businesses across the globe adopt cloud-based infrastructure strategies, three providers (Amazon\u2019s AWS, Google\u2019s GCP, and Microsoft\u2019s Azure) have solidified their positions as dominant players in the $247 billion-dollar cloud infrastructure market.\\n\\nTheir success is well-deserved \u2013 these companies have effectively created the cloud we know today. Unfortunately, this success has also enabled them to build&nbsp;[competitive moats](http://www.platformonomics.com/2017/04/follow-the-capex-cloud-table-stakes/)&nbsp;around their positions. Large providers\u2019 hyperscale data centers and other infrastructure projects effectively prevent competition by establishing a massive capex barrier for potential competitors. Over time, this has created an oligopoly, which hurts consumers as a whole.\\n\\n**What Is an Oligopoly?**\\n\\nIn a monopoly, one company maintains complete control over a market, keeping all other competitors out. This can be done through regulatory restrictions, such as in the case of local utilities service providers, or simply by being an undisputed leader in a particular field. With an oligopoly, multiple companies maintain that control, keeping others out.\\n\\nAs demand for cloud infrastructure grew, several already-dominant tech businesses were able to use revenue from other lines of business to rapidly scale their infrastructure businesses. That let them capture market share, and build their moats. With&nbsp;[85 percent of enterprises](https://www.rightscale.com/blog/cloud-industry-insights/cloud-computing-trends-2017-state-cloud-survey)&nbsp;now having a cloud strategy in place, this means that a handful of providers are now powering a large, and growing, chunk of the business landscape.\\n\\n**Why Is It Bad for Society?**\\n\\nCorporate consolidation has become&nbsp;[an ongoing problem](https://www.washingtonpost.com/blogs/post-partisan/wp/2017/04/12/beyond-united-how-oligopolies-hurt-americans-pocketbooks/?utm_term=.93c6af7aa94a)&nbsp;for consumers, as mergers and acquisitions shrink the number of companies competing in each space. In the cloud computing sector, this cost is first paid by businesses, which then raise prices to finance the software they use to conduct business. This creates a service tax that all consumers must pay. Without real competition to drive down prices, there\u2019s no incentive for large cloud providers to keep costs low.\\n\\nThis \u201ccloud tax\u201d is paid by all members of society, including those who don\u2019t directly use cloud infrastructure at all. The money goes directly to three large corporations whose duties are to their shareholders, not to society. We shouldn\u2019t begrudge their enormous profits or control \u2013 they are behaving precisely as they\u2019re obligated to. But neither should we accept this situation as inevitable.\\n\\n**What Can We Do?**\\n\\nOne small company may not be able to disrupt the space, but working together, multiple companies can. At Akash, our goal is to empower any company that runs its own on-premise or colocated data centers to join our network of cloud providers by simply adding their unused server capacity to the Akash Network. Providers automatically bid to host users\u2019 cloud workloads on an open, transparent marketplace, driving down costs as much as 90 percent.\\n\\nPerhaps more importantly, the Akash Network also decentralizes control over cloud infrastructure. So many of the applications we use in our daily lives are run in the cloud, and the data they generate stored in the cloud, that we need to consider whether it\u2019s appropriate for three companies to effectively&nbsp;_control_&nbsp;the cloud. The Akash Network is not controlled by any one entity. All participants \u2013 providers and consumers \u2013 have a role in its governance; all network transactions, including pricing and performance, are open on the blockchain; and the software that runs Akash is open source and available for all to see.\\n\\nOverclock Labs, the team building&nbsp;[Akash](https://akash.network/), believes that compute is a commodity that should be traded in a transparent and free marketplace, priced accordingly, and over which a small number of large companies should not be able to exert control. The Akash Network is the manifestation of these beliefs.&quot;],&quot;collection&quot;:[0,&quot;Blog&quot;],&quot;data&quot;:[0,{&quot;title&quot;:[0,&quot;Decentralized Infrastructure is a Moral Imperative&quot;],&quot;description&quot;:[0,&quot;As businesses across the globe adopt cloud-based infrastructure strategies, three providers (Amazon\u2019s AWS, Google\u2019s GCP, and Microsoft\u2019s Azure) have solidified their positions as dominant players in the $247 billion-dollar cloud infrastructure market.&quot;],&quot;pubDate&quot;:[3,&quot;2018-03-19T00:00:00.000Z&quot;],&quot;draft&quot;:[0,false],&quot;categories&quot;:[1,[[0,&quot;Insights&quot;]]],&quot;tags&quot;:[1,[[0,&quot;Insights&quot;]]],&quot;contributors&quot;:[1,[[0,&quot;Nick Alesandro&quot;]]],&quot;bannerImage&quot;:[0,{&quot;src&quot;:[0,&quot;/_astro/banner-image.DvzFgAEj.jpg&quot;],&quot;width&quot;:[0,660],&quot;height&quot;:[0,480],&quot;format&quot;:[0,&quot;jpg&quot;],&quot;fsPath&quot;:[0,&quot;/home/runner/work/website/website/src/content/Blog/decentralized-infrastructure-is-a-moral-imperative/banner-image.jpg&quot;]}]}],&quot;render&quot;:[0,null]}],[0,{&quot;id&quot;:[0,&quot;serverless-is-bigger-than-faas/index.md&quot;],&quot;slug&quot;:[0,&quot;serverless-is-bigger-than-faas&quot;],&quot;body&quot;:[0,&quot;There is a growing excitement in the developer community around the serverless paradigm, an idea that lets developers to deliver workloads without provisioning or managing servers.\\n\\nAt its core, serverless architecture relies on orchestrating a vibrant eco-system of fully managed services. With increasing number of such backend services \u2014 namely backend-as-a-service (BaaS) \u2014 supported by all the key cloud infrastructure (IaaS) providers, I think it\u2019s fair to say 2018 will be the year of serverless.\\n\\nWith all the excitement, there\u2019s also confusion as to what constitutes to serverless architecture. Conventional wisdom \u2014 catalyzed by cloud providers\u2019 rhetoric \u2014 is that only Function-as-a-Service (FaaS) implementations represent a serverless architecture.\\n\\nI wrote this post to challenge some of those viewpoints in a hope to present a case for expanding this definition beyond functional level abstraction to application level abstraction to be considered as serverless.\\n\\n#### Serverless 1.0\\n\\nThe idea of an absence of the server concept during software development \u2014 or serverless \u2014 is not new. Heroku was perhaps the first to introduce this concept around 2008 that had broad adoption by the developer community (a case can be made about Google App Engine being the first, but will keep that for another post).\\n\\nWith a developer first mentality, Heroku promised three main things:\\n\\n1.  Cheaper, by isolating workloads in much small container images compared to VMs by IaaS providers, optimal to run most application workloads\\n    \\n2.  Comprehensive set of fully managed backends, accessible from a marketplace with federated identity and consolidated billing\\n    \\n3.  Great developer experience using a fantastic command line tool to develop, debug and deliver workloads\\n    \\n\\nFor applications written in a language/framework that Heroku supports and adhere to a simple standard \u2014 called the 12-factor methodology \u2014 developers could follow a very familiar git-based workflow to deploy their code. Heroku would seamlessly handle the availability and scaling of the workloads. The declarative formats of 12-factor methodology promised to maximize iteration speed and provided a clean contract with the underlying OS, offering maximum portability\\n\\nAs containers have much smaller footprint than VMs, they allowed Heroku to efficiently schedule workloads across a diverse set of machines with various configurations and optimize for price-performance.\\n\\nTo make this a reality, Heroku built container runtimes and orchestration engines that ran on top of Amazon Web Services that were closed off from the user.\\n\\nThe simplicity promised by the 12-factor design, however, lacked the flexibility do deploy workloads with complex needs. You couldn\u2019t deploy any workload that was wasn\u2019t 12-factor or have your workloads run in a private network. The marketplace \u2014 being comprised mostly of external vendors \u2014 paid little or no attention to latency between the application and backends that often resulted in degraded performance.\\n\\nThe closed approached, the lack of flexibility and a degraded performance kept Heroku away from being adopted by enterprises with complex needs and drove it to remain as a much-loved platform for \u201chobby\u201d developers.\\n\\nThis gap in the market gave birth to platforms \u2014 called platform-as-as-services (PaaS) \u2014 like CloudFoundry (an EMC and VMWare spin-off), Makara (RedHat OpenShift) and DotCloud (Later renamed to Docker)\\n\\nBy embracing an open approach, these platforms promised the ease-of-use of Heroku style workflows while providing the flexibility or using your own hardware with a focus on simplicity\\n\\nLike Heroku, these platforms also relied heavily upon Linux containers \u2014 a relatively old but unknown concept at the time \u2014 as a packaging and isolation mechanism to deliver workloads. The native container runtime provided by Linux \u2014 called LXC \u2014 was hard and unpleasant to use; limited its adoption to advanced teams at companies like Google and ones building infrastructure tools.\\n\\nDotCloud, a relatively unknown company with a product that couldn\u2019t differentiate from the competition \u2014 facing a possibility of extinction \u2014 open sourced a tool they\u2019ve developed to simplify the use to LXC called \u201cDocker.\u201d\\n\\nDocker\u2019s key to simplicity was the image format \u2014 contents the image, declared in a manifest file is then used to build an image that can be built anywhere and shared with others by storing in a central repository. This build once, run anywhere approach gave way for developers to solve the particularly tricky, development-to-production parity problem.\\n\\nIt didn\u2019t take long for developers to embrace Docker that lead to a Cambrian exposition of the cloud-native ecosystem. While Docker provided the image format and runtime for a single workload, tools like Kubernetes were born to orchestrate a variety of these workloads and schedule them in a fault tolerant manner.\\n\\nWhat began as a serverless promise by Heroku \u2014 the application runtime abstraction \u2014 paved the way for a thriving ecosystem that changed the fundamental way we design the delivery of distributed workloads\\n\\n#### Serverless 2.0\\n\\nWith increased number of workloads moving to the cloud, it didn\u2019t take long for IaaS providers to understand the value of providing fully-managed backends \u2014 such as databases, caches, load balancers, etc \u2014 the support infrastructure required by the workloads\\n\\nFor providers such as Amazon Web Services (AWS), that began with a simple, managed object store offering, expanded into over 70 services (as of the writing of the post); for many providers, a way to orchestrate these rich set backends was evident next step. By leveraging the orchestration and containerization wave, it made it possible to rethink abstraction levels.\\n\\nThis gave birth to a new level of abstraction \u2014 function-as-a-service. AWS Lambda is a product that provides functional abstraction with the same promise of faster iteration speed, zero administration, and a much granular pricing model.\\n\\nThe difference here is that development focus is on a single function or module rather than a service with a large surface area like in the application runtime abstraction.\\n\\nAnother fundamental difference between application level abstraction and functional level abstraction is where and how you define invocation mechanism for workloads. In application abstraction, the invocation mechanism is described in the application code itself and provides the flexibility for the developer to choose the framework. For functional, the invocation is defined in a manifest file designed by provider. In case of AWS Lamda, an asynchronous invocation by placing a message on a managed queue (SQS), and a web-based invocation by calling a predefined endpoint on a managed router (API Gateway)\\n\\nIn essence, FaaS is an application framework created and managed by the provider. This makes FaaS appealing for developers that don\u2019t necessarily care about vendor lock-in and are flexible to adopt the provider\u2019s manifest in exchange for a piece of mind.\\n\\n#### Conclusion\\n\\nIt\u2019s evident by now that application and functional runtime abstraction deliver the promise of serverless \u2014 a future where developers can focus on writing code that provides functionality to their users instead of dealing with complexities of delivering that code.\\n\\n_This post was originally published on_&nbsp;[_Hacker Noon_](https://hackernoon.com/serverless-is-bigger-than-faas-a5fe0f088981)&nbsp;_on Nov 28, excitement in the developer community around the serverless paradigm, an idea that lets developers to deliver workloads without provisioning or managing
